talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the member for Wentworth claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do indeed.
—The member for Wentworth may proceed.
—In yesterday's Daily Telegraph on page 9, there is a statement that the:

quote.para: ... member for Wentworth ... wasted no time ... securing a life after politics, accepting a legal brief for a case in the Solomon Islands in May.

speech.para: This appears to have been a misrepresentation founded upon an assertion by the member for Grayndler in the debate yesterday in the House, which I led, relating to Centenary House, when the member for Grayndler got rather excited and said—

talk.start.para: —The member for Wentworth must come quickly to the point of his misrepresentation.

—that I had taken a brief in the Solomon Islands. The true position is that I have done no such thing. What I said on ABC Radio on Monday when asked about it was that I had been approached by my former clerk, who had thought that I would have been immediately available for taking briefs and had asked whether I would be prepared to take a brief in the Solomon Islands, in an area where I normally practised.
—I am extending to the member for Wentworth more licence than is normally tolerated under a personal explanation.
—The misrepresentation is that there was no such brief secured at all.
—I have received a letter from the honourable member for Griffith proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The Government's public exaggeration of the Iraqi WMD threat as demonstrated by the conclusions of the parliamentary joint committee on intelligence report.

interjection.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —I am gratified that the Minister for Foreign Affairs has chosen to remain with us for this debate. The report that has been tabled by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD has proved beyond any reasonable doubt that the Howard government exaggerated the intelligence information it received to politically justify its decision to go to war with Iraq. This is now an established fact in the political debate. This is not a Labor Party conclusion. It is not a partisan political conclusion. It is the bipartisan and unani-mous conclusion of the joint parlia-mentary committee on intelligence, chaired by the Liberal Party.

speech.para: Some have questioned why we went down this road of supporting this form of parliamentary inquiry. The reason was simple: we wished to construct an agreed evidence base for the debate about the government's past actions. We also wanted to have a base on which recommendations could be made for the future so that we could get the intelligence bases right for our future war against terrorism. The committee has done a commendable job: first, it has now been established that the government did exaggerate the Iraq WMD threat; second, it has now been established as a matter of fact that there was also intelligence failure; and, third, there will now be an independent commission of inquiry to deal with the future. These are the proven facts to emerge from this report.

The government's response to this has been what I can only describe as hyperactive spin control: first of all, a briefing out of the press gallery over the last couple of weeks that `we, the political arm of government, did not have a problem, only the intelligence community had a problem'—hence that remarkable brief delivered by certain advisers to the Sydney Morning Herald, among others—and then, on top of that, the frantic exercises in spin control by `Tony O'Leary Enterprises' up there in the press gallery, whizzing around to make sure that everyone had got the line. What we had was spin control on spin control. They sought to control the spin on the war by exaggerating the Iraqi threat, and now they seek to control the spin on having been outed for their spin control on the war. That is what they are up to. But when we peel it back, when you peek underneath, when you actually look underneath, at what has gone on here, we see a very unattractive performance by this minister on Iraq of the dance of the seven veils.

We have had a few veils on display here over the last two sitting weeks. We had Danna Vale the week before last with a remarkable performance on veterans' entitlements and we had Mark Vaile today with a remarkable performance on the status or non-status of the free trade agreement with the United States—whenever that might be agreed to, though we have been asked to support it in advance of that happening—but these two veils pale into insignificance compared with the seven translucent veils of our foreign minister, Mr Downer, in his defence—the Howard's government's defence—of taking this country to war with Iraq. When you peek beneath these veils, it is not a pretty picture at all. Veil No. 1 on the part of the minister is the government's defence, `We did not sex anything up.' This is a minister who uses the terms `sex up' and `sex' in this debate with worrying levels of repetition. The charge being levelled by this minister against himself is, `We, the political arm of government, are off scot-free unless a committee established, as a matter of evidentiary fact, that either I the minister or my advisers sat down and physically doctored documents.' That is what it is all about.

Can you picture Alexander up there in the office with all the advisers sitting down with their texta colours, their white-out, and in comes the stuff from ONA, scribble, scribble, scratch, scratch, until you produce a satisfactory document. The minister and his advisers are not that dumb—that is not what it is all about—though we wait with interest the Andrew Bolt outcome and what that will show. No, the challenge here is to tell the Australian people the whole truth, the whole picture, accurately and completely. They are the terms used in the parliamentary inquiry report. That means telling the Australian people the doubts about the Iraqi WMD threat as well, not just shading it up.

When we look at this evidentiary basis, this document, this report, we see demonstrated 12 specific occasions on which the government have misled the Australian people by being selective in what they put out to the Australian people. To allay any doubt on this score, if you think this is some grand rhetorical flourish, I draw the attention of honourable members and the public to sections 2.40, 4.40, 4.82, 5.16, 5.17, 5.20, 5.21, 5.22, 5.23, 5.27, 5.29 and 5.32 and the second reference of 5.29—12 specific occasions on which the Howard government exaggerated the Iraqi threat. This is not Labor's conclusion, this is not a partisan conclusion, but the unanimous conclusion of the parliamentary inquiry.

Let us look at some specific examples. Exhibit A is an ONA report of 2001 which says that the scale of threat from Iraq WMD is less than it was a decade before. Then in 2002 we have the minister saying, `I do not think there is any doubt about Saddam Hussein having stockpiles of biological and chemical weapons. There is a very grave concern that he has been enhancing those stockpiles in recent years.' And what does the parliamentary joint committee conclude? It says:

quote.para: Therefore, the case made by the government was that Iraq possessed WMD in large quantities and posed a grave and unacceptable threat to the region and the world, particularly as there was a danger that Iraq's WMD might be passed to terrorist organisations.

speech.para: The parliamentary committee concludes `This is not the picture that emerges from an examination of all the assessments provided to the Committee by' ONA and DIO. You cannot have a clearer conclusion unanimously by the parliamentary committee that this matter was not taken on the basis of the advice which had been provided by the intelligence agencies. That is exhibit A. For exhibit B we turn to what DIO had to say in October 2002:

quote.para: DIO assesses that Iraq's capability to deliver a CBW agent in any substantial quantity to be restricted—the delivery of an agent by ballistic missile ... would probably only result in limited casualties. This suggests that, in the short term, Iraq's capability will be limited to a weapon of mass effect rather than a weapon of mass destruction.

speech.para: What does the Prime Minister say here in this parliament in February 2003? He says:

quote.para: ... my purpose today is to explain to the House ... why Iraq's ... possession of chemical and biological weapons and its pursuit of a nuclear capability poses a real and unacceptable threat to the stability and security of our world ...

speech.para: What does the parliamentary committee say? It says:

quote.para: ... there appears to be a gap on the matter of immediacy of threat. Assessments by Australian agencies about possible degradation of agents and restricted delivery capability cast doubt on the suggestion that the Iraqi `arsenal' represented a `grave and immediate' and a `real and unacceptable' threat.

speech.para: That is exhibit B. Go to exhibit C. We have Mr Downer saying in the parliament in March 2003, on what was then a UN Security Council veto, that the veto denied the Security Council any further role in disarming Iraq. But he goes on to say:

quote.para: Australian intelligence agencies provided hardly any explicit assessment on the question of the immediacy of the threat posed by Saddam Hussein.

speech.para: Time and again, exhibit after exhibit, we find that what this minister has done in his presentation and in relation to the Prime Minister's presentation is look at an intelligence report and then, when it comes to public presentation, excise the doubts and the uncertainties—in other words, present a magnification of the threat that exists.

To allay any further doubt about the specific accuracies in relation to the Prime Minister's claim that Iraqi WMD represented a real and unacceptable threat—as claimed by the PM on the eve of the war—what did the head of the Defence Intelligence Organisation say in this report? The head of the DIO—not a member of the Labor Party; the head of the DIO—said that the Prime Minister's judgment was `not a judgment that DIO would have made'. This is a direct assault on the credibility of the case which the government put into the public domain.

If there are any doubts overall on this, I draw honourable members' attention to section 5.20 of the report, where it says that ministerial statements plainly were more strongly worded than most of the Australian intelligence community judgments. In other words, the government exaggerated. They gilded the lily; they shaded it up; they did not tell the whole truth and nothing but the truth. Why? Because they wanted to magnify the nature of the Iraqi WMD threat to justify the political case, when they had already taken the decision to go to war. That is what it was all about.

Mr Downer, the foreign minister, says he is vindicated by this report. I do not know what language the foreign minister understands on these matters but, as I read this report, there are 12 specific examples of clear indications—by way of what the report has said—of the intelligence being, on the one hand, over here and the government saying something on the other hand, as well as the concluding observations in the report that this simply does not stack up.

But I said there were seven veils. That was the first—that is, that we did not sex anything up. We will dance through the others, because this is, on the minister's part, a dance of the seven veils. We then had the Saddam Hussein defence. What does the minister say there? He says, `It doesn't matter if we got WMD wrong. Why? Because we got rid of Saddam Hussein.' Minister, point me to one sentence in your memorandum of legal advice where there is one reference to eliminating a dictator as being your legal justification for going to war—one sentence. No, Minister, point me to one word. Find me a single word that argues that, prior to going to war, this was the basis for going to war. Minister, this is a post facto rationalisation—and you know it.

Howard defence No. 3, the third of the veils, is the second Pearl Harbour argument—that is, we need to pre-empt in case we are going to be attacked. That rests on first-class intelligence. Does anyone now believe, based on this report's findings, that we have had first-class intelligence on Iraq? The case has been established entirely to the reverse. Then, last night, to the embarrassment of the government, the chairman of the parliamentary committee, Mr Jull, said that the conditions which have been outlined in the report—conditions relating to a pre-emptive attack—were not met as far as his judgment was concerned. Frankly, Minister, on that matter, your third defence falls apart.

Then we come to the other element of the dance of the seven veils, which is called `blame the intelligence community'. If you had looked at the press in the last several weeks, you would have seen that the thrust of the briefing was: `the spooks are in trouble but the government is okay; the spooks might have got it wrong, but we the government didn't exaggerate anything'. I will remind the minister of one thing: the Westminster principle. Who was it who said in this House in an intelligence debate back in 1995, `The simple fact is that ministers under our system are responsible for departments and agencies within their portfolios'? That was this gentleman, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in a debate with Senate Evans about responsibility for actions and activities within the Australian Secret Intelligence Service. In other words, Westminster then—owning responsibility for what your agencies do rather than kissing it goodbye.

In eight years of Howard government, you have been responsible for the structure of your intelligence services, and here is your central failing: when you embarked upon a policy of global pre-emption with the United States, you did not engage in a parallel restructuring of the Australian intelligence services to give them the resources and capabilities to look at new theatres of potential military operation. The bulk of our intelligence agencies' resources are concentrated in our own immediate region—and this government decides to focus on Afghanistan and Iraq. When it comes to Iraq, when we get to the lead-up to the war, how many analysts in the Office of National Assessments does this government have working on Iraq related matters? A total of three analysts—and then not even full-time—were supposed to consume and independently analyse the totality of the global intelligence product and make some independent assessment of it. Minister, you have got to be dreaming!

Defence No. 5, the fifth of the seven veils, is: if you can't blame the spooks, blame the Yanks and the Brits. They say that 97 per cent of the intelligence came from offshore. Well, that is terrific. The purpose of ONA is to vet the offshore product—and, based on what I just said, you had three officers within ONA whose job it was to do that. You did not equip them with the capacity to do that.

Defence No. 6 is the one I love most of all: blame the opposition. The sixth of the seven veils is that it was our fault that the government took us to war based on false intelligence. This is terrific—the ultimate Orwellian triumph as far as your truth management in this entire exercise is concerned. It was the opposition's fault, honourable members, that we were foolish enough to believe what the government said to us at the time—it was our fault and not theirs. It was our fault that we believed the intelligence briefings that we were given at the time—our fault and not theirs. Minister, what language are you speaking?

The seventh of the seven veils, as the minister has said, is: why would we need a royal commission? Minister, how can you read this report and not conclude that we need an independent commission of inquiry to restructure our intelligence services in the future and to ensure that we have confidence that your government will not politically manipulate intelligence information in the future? I would suggest that the case for that is now rolled gold and clear for everybody who reads this report with any clarity and objectivity. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Griffith might care to check the Hansard as to the number of times he directed his speech through the chair and the number of times he used `you' and `your'.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr DOWNER
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —What a display of mock indignation from a man who, since 23 June last year, has asked me as the foreign minister one question on Iraq and weapons of mass destruction. If this were such a big issue for the Labor Party, instead of an issue inspiring mock indignation, wouldn't they have moved censure motions or submitted MPIs on Iraq and weapons of mass destruction? I may be wrong, but I think this is the first MPI we have had on this issue for a very long time. In the end I think that the core issue of debate here is about Iraq and Saddam Hussein's regime. That is the only issue that really matters. When the Leader of the Opposition, on radio 2UEon 12 January, said, `Well, I think they made a mistake in going to war in Iraq. Now, whatever the reason or motivation was, I think it was a mistake,' he was making a point that we as a government profoundly disagree with.

speech.para: Essentially, when it comes to the next election in this country the public, insofar as they reflect on events that have come and gone, will make this judgment: do we think that this world would have been a better place if the regime of Saddam Hussein had remained in power, with its weapons of mass destruction programs, its appalling record of human rights abuse, its slaughter of some 300,000 of its own citizens, its use of chemical weapons against its own people—the Kurds—and its use of chemical weapons against its next-door neighbours? The public will judge whether the world would have been a better place if that regime had remained in office or whether the world is a better place without it. That is ultimately what this boils down to.

The opposition can huff and puff all they like, trying to find little quotes here and there, sexing up bits of information—as they so often do—and trying to claim that these are issues of enormous and monumental importance. But ultimately the only issue of importance is whether the people of this country think that we as a nation have done the right thing in overthrowing and getting rid of the evil regime of Saddam Hussein or whether the world would have been a better place if it had implemented the policy of the Labor Party and Saddam Hussein was still in power. That is the core issue.

The parliamentary joint committee report vindicates the government's use of intelligence in making the case for action against Iraq. The bipartisan report confirms that there was no evidence that political pressure was applied to agencies and there was no overt pressure from the government to change assessments. I tried to explain this on the radio this morning. It is obvious that the government would not try to change assessments. These are classified assessments that come to the government. They are not written for publication; they are assessments that we read in the privacy of our offices. Sure, from time to time we use material from these assessments—of course we often use material from the assessments—but the actual assessments physically come to us in classified form. The government would not have any motive—let alone have done it—in getting our intelligence agencies to modify the assessments they make. The point I make here is—

talk.start.para: —The member for Griffith seems to forget that he was warned by the Speaker before the MPI.

—People like the member for Griffith impugn the integrity of our intelligence agencies by suggesting that the people in our intelligence agencies are somehow politicised and are not professional after all. I resent very much the attack on our intelligence agencies by the member for Griffith and by the opposition more generally. It has to be said that there is a limited number of the so-called anti-war commentators—as they might call themselves—who share that view. We see the articles from time to time. The member for Griffith looks at people in the gallery with a wry smile. It says it all. The fact is that the intelligence agencies of this country do an extraordinarily good job. The fact that we facilitated the cooperation by ONA and DIO with the inquiry simply demonstrates that we are quite happy to be transparent about these issues.

speech.para: The opposition spokesman says there should be a royal commission. He was calling for a royal commission before this inquiry was even complete. The opposition spokesman is not to be taken seriously. To call for a royal commission before an inquiry has even been finished demonstrates the point that he never stops playing political games. The public are right on to that. There is not a serious point to be made.

We have to understand that one of the assumptions on which the arguments used against the Australian, British and American governments are built is that actually Saddam Hussein had nothing to do with weapons of mass destruction. These people accept that he was a human rights abuser; I am not saying that people in the Labor Party, the anti-war lobby or the media thought that Saddam Hussein was a great guy—of course they did not. But they seem to think that, since the war is over, we can now safely conclude that Saddam Hussein had no worse a record on weapons of mass destruction than the Prime Minister of Samoa.

talk.start.para: —That's false.

—The member for Blaxland says that is false. If that is false, it must be true that Saddam Hussein has a bad record on weapons of mass destruction. But that is not what we are hearing from the opposition. The fact that the Iraq Survey Group has found that Saddam Hussein maintained weapons of mass destruction programs is something that they quickly sweep over. They do not want to tell the Australian public that Dr Kay and the Iraq Survey Group have found that Saddam Hussein did indeed maintain dozens of weapons of mass destruction programs. That was revealed in the interviews and the investigations that have taken place since the end of the war.

speech.para: Sure, we all understand that the stockpiles have not been found and we all know what George Tenet has said about that. On 5 February he said, `The Iraq survey group is nowhere near 85 per cent finished'—and David Kay had said that it was 85 per cent finished. The fact that Saddam Hussein still had weapons of mass destruction programs—and you can convert such programs into actual weapons within a very short period of time, which is demonstrated by the DIO report that has been quoted constantly in the last couple of days—apparently does not matter. Apparently, according to these people, it does not matter that Saddam Hussein was found to have weapons of mass destruction programs and also, according to Dr Kay, was in clear breach of Security Council resolution 1441.

I hear the Leader of the Opposition say—it is one of his constant platitudes—that the opposition's foreign policy is built on three principles: the alliance with America, relations with Asia, and the United Nations. Everybody is in favour of those things. But, if the United Nations is so important, why does it not seem to matter that the Kay report has demonstrated that Saddam Hussein was in breach of Security Council resolution 1441, which was an enforceable and mandatory Security Council resolution? Why do they avoid ever mentioning that? Why is that not germane to this debate?

This debate has to be very much about the quality of the person who used to lead Iraq: the endeavour by Saddam Hussein to circumvent United Nations inspections, the endeavour by Saddam Hussein to maintain weapons of mass destruction programs, and the record of Saddam Hussein in using those weapons against his own people and his neighbours. You would not think from listening to the member for Griffith that any of those things mattered. I do not mind what the member for Griffith or other members opposite say; for me, those issues and the human rights issues to boot are profoundly important.

There will not be a day between now and the day I die that for one minute I will regret the decision we took to participate in the overthrow of the regime of Saddam Hussein. It was and always has been a difficult issue politically. But I and my colleagues in the coalition know that, if it were not for us and the Americans and the British, the regime of Saddam Hussein would still be there today. He would still be there with his weapons of mass destruction programs. He would still be there abusing human rights—and that is the policy that is supported by those opposite: to have left him there in office. That is a debate that we are happy to have between now and polling day. We will have it over and again, and we are happy to do that.

Today is one day after the publication of that report and the opposition spokesman has asked only one question on this issue. What could be the explanation for the opposition spokesman getting only one miserable question up on this issue? I suspect there is a very clear explanation for that and it is not just tied up with the personal relationship between the opposition spokesman and the Leader of the Opposition; I think it is much more to do with the fact that the opposition knows in its heart only too well that the arguments I make here today are arguments that so many of the good people in this country agree with.

Let me finally make this point about the opposition: the opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, the excitable and garrulous member for Griffith, was out there arguing before the war that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction. He said:

quote.para: ... Iraq plainly possesses chemical and biological agents and there is some evidence that those agents have been weaponised.

talk.start.para: —Did you lie to us?

—This is interesting. In an unparliamentary way, as you would expect from the garrulous, excitable and always over-the-top member for Griffith, he says: did you lie to us? Just a second. He made these statements before he had any briefings from our intelligence agencies.
—That's the pot calling the kettle black.

—The member for Griffith was saying in his doorstop this morning that it was the intelligence agencies that briefed him and that was why he was making those statements. Now he is suggesting that these people lied to him; that is what he is saying.
—Not you.

—I did not give you any briefings. So base are the people in our intelligence agencies that they somehow lied to him. But hang on; he made these statements about Iraq's weapons of mass destruction before he had the briefings from the intelligence agencies. The former Leader of the Opposition gave the game away because his source—one of the important sources often quoted by the government and others, which is fair enough as it was one of the opposition's main sources—was the 1999 UNSCOM report on the inventory of undiscovered and unknown weapons of mass destruction components. And who drew up that inventory? None other than Richard Butler, well known to many opposite, the Governor of Tasmania. I say no more about Richard Butler, except that the opposition regarded him as one of their prime sources.

speech.para: There is no point in turning around and saying that my speeches have been so persuasive; that the member for Griffith always agreed with everything I said because of the persuasion of my rhetoric or alternatively, which is the latest position, that the ONA was lying to him when it gave him briefings. These are base allegations by an extremely dishonest member of this House, if I may say so.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—The Minister for Foreign Affairs will withdraw that comment.

—I withdraw; but he is certainly a member who finds it very difficult to put forward a straight argument. But let me say this: the government made the right decision to support the overthrow of the regime of Saddam Hussein but, more than that, that decision to overthrow that regime has reinforced the global nonproliferation regime. Libya has given up its WMD, Iran is now at least cooperating with the International Atomic Energy Agency and North Korea is engaged in talks about nuclear disarmament. That is a good outcome. (Time expired)

—I am pleased to speak on this matter of public importance. I would like to acknowledge the tremendous work done by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD in looking at this issue of weapons of mass destruction; I think it is a very profound report. It contains only three recommendations, but they are fundamental; and, in the best traditions of the parliament, it is a unanimous report. Chaired by the member for Fadden, the committee has some big hitters, I must say, on the Labor side. But I commend all the committee members for the work they have done.

speech.para: Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, you may remember another report, but I have never seen a report so extensively leaked to the media prior to its tabling. I think on the Labor side and perhaps even on the government side there are few doubts about where the leak came from. I want to make it quite clear that I accuse no member of the committee of leaking it. The only other group of people who had the report of course were the ministers. But I will leave that aside. I think it is a tragedy to see such a fine report extensively leaked to the press and to see nothing done about it. And this is not some mere incidental item, of passing interest to the Australian people; this is a report on our intelligence agencies, this is a report on the probity of our ministers in dealing with the advice that they received from our intelligence agencies and this is a report that was extensively leaked to the newspapers before its release. It is an utter disgrace. But I think it gives a clue that the ministers in this most serious matter—where, more than any other ministers, they have special responsibilities because of the trust they hold on behalf of the parliament and on behalf of the Australian people—have not been open and honest with the Australian people.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs was in here saying, `Labor, you accused us of unfairly influencing the intelligence agencies'—the DIO, the Office of National Assessments, ASIS; that that is what we accused the government of. We did not accuse the government of that. We have never accused the government of unduly influencing the agencies. In fact, the committee say that they questioned the heads of the intelligence agencies, and they said that they were not subjected to that sort of pressure. So why the minister should come in here and say, `Look, this vindicates us,' because they have been found innocent of something we never accused them of—and that hinges the whole argument—I will never understand.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs says we should be pleased that Saddam Hussein, a dictator, is no longer in Iraq; Saddam Hussein, who persecuted minorities and majorities in Iraq, is no longer a dictator in Iraq; Saddam Hussein, who used chemical weapons on Kurds in Iraq, is no longer there; and we should all be pleased. We all object to those things.

talk.start.para: —What have you done about it?
—No--one has ever said they supported Saddam Hussein. The member for Flinders interjects, but let me just tell him the Prime Minister in his National Press Club speech of 13 March said:

quote.para: ... I couldn't justify on its own a military invasion of Iraq to change the regime.

speech.para: That was your Prime Minister, member for Flinders. He said further:

quote.para: I've never advocated that.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—If the member for Flinders wants to participate in the debate, he will be silent.

—You go into a war not advocating a regime change, and then you justify the war because you have had a regime change! What flaming hypocrites you are. No wonder 62 per cent of the Australian people do not trust your Prime Minister, do not trust your Minister for Foreign Affairs and do not trust your Minister for Defence—nor should they, and that is what this report says.

speech.para: What I am surprised about is that the foreign minister did not say, `The report cleared us of exaggerating the assessments to the extent that our US counterparts did or our British counterparts did.' In fact, the government do say that. But they do not say they told the whole truth. In fact, this report says they left out significant parts of the truth. When there were qualifiers in there, they were never enumerated. In the latter part of his speech on this MPI, the Minister for Foreign Affairs talked about the inventory of chemical weapons that the Prime Minister used to go to war. What he did not say, and knew well, was that that was a list based on possible weapons, not probable weapons. Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, even you I think would agree that there is a vast distinction between `possible' and `probable'.

talk.start.para: —I am sure the member for Chifley knows the chair has no opinion on that.

—You have no opinion on the truth? I beg your pardon. I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. We on this side and on behalf of the Australian people feel very strongly about the truth; we feel very strongly about the positions of trust that the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Defence are placed in.

speech.para: There were a few things that I wanted to draw to your attention, Mr Deputy Speaker, and to the attention of the House. It is interesting that our intelligence organisations probably performed a little better than our US and British counterparts, but they still got it wrong, and that has to be an issue of concern. When I said that there was no political interference, there is one fact that the committee draws upon that I think all members and the Australian public should be conscious of. That is that the Office of National Assessments—which, admittedly, as the shadow minister for foreign affairs pointed out, had three people working on the Iraqi brief; three part-timers—on 12 September made a statement that there was no firm evidence of new chemical and biological weapon production but then on the next day, on the 13th, issued an assessment that Iraq had almost certainly been working to increase its capability to make chemical and biological weapons. In 24 hours, what changed?

But the equally important question is: what did the Prime Minister do in regard to this 24-hour turnaround? What questions did he ask that led to such a dramatic flip-flop? What questions did the Minister for Foreign Affairs ask that led to such a dramatic flip-flop? What did the Minister for Defence ask of those assessments that resulted in such a dramatic flip-flop?

This is a very important MPI. It goes to the heart of national security. Already, we have had the intervention by the shadow minister for foreign affairs about what constitutes military pre-emption being valid under international law. The answer is that you must have clear evidence of weapons of mass destruction existing which constitute a real and present danger. The committee found the truth: that that did not exist.

I want to say to the House that I have just come back from Indonesia and that they are very interested in John Howard's ideas on military pre-emption. I accept that Iraq does not normally constitute a high priority area for us getting raw intelligence about. But certainly Indonesia does. If the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Prime Minister are going to continue to repeat their determination to have military pre-emption against terrorists in our region, it is utterly critical that intelligence has to be bloody better than what it was. It has to be a lot better.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—I am sure the member for Chifley can find a better term.

—It really does have to be better. What is significant about the call by the committee—repeated by the opposition—to have a commission of inquiry is that it is about the future; it is not about the past. We want to learn what the mistakes the intelligence organisations made were. We need to know that. But it is its application in the future that is utterly critical. (Time expired)

—There are two fundamental questions for Australia in assessing the action in Iraq which led to the ousting of Saddam Hussein, Qusay Hussein, Uday Hussein and the Baathist regime of Baghdad, which held not just Iraq but neighbouring states in its thrall for over two decades. The first of those questions is whether or not there was a misuse of intelligence informing the judgments, developing the decisions and leading to the actions which the government took. Secondly, there is the core question which really underpins this whole debate: was there an essential justification for the action, which the Australian government participated in, of helping to oust the regime led by Saddam Hussein, Uday Hussein, Qusay Hussein and the Baathist regime? Those are the two questions.

speech.para: In looking at those two questions, let me begin with the first issue, of whether or not there was misuse of intelligence. I want to begin with four simple quotes. The first is from the member for Griffith on 24 September 2002 on Lateline:

quote.para: There is no debate or dispute as to whether Saddam Hussein possesses weapons of mass destruction.
He does.

speech.para: I remind the House that these are the member for Griffith's own words:

quote.para: There's no dispute as whether he's in violation of UN Security Council resolutions.
He is.

speech.para: The second quote is from the then Leader of the Opposition and current member for Hotham. On ABC Radio on Thursday, 14 November 2002 he said:

quote.para: What was disturbing was the regime saying that they didn't have any weapons of mass destruction. Well, I don't believe that.
We know they have weapons of mass destruction ...

speech.para: The third quote is from someone not reliant in any way upon the Australian intelligence system or the international intelligence which passed through it but who was perhaps the world's single greatest expert on the condition within Iraq in relation to weapons of mass destruction: Richard Butler, the current Governor of Tasmania and the former head of the UN Special Commission on Iraq, which was charged with seeking Iraq's weapons of mass destruction capability. His words on 15 September 2002 on the Sunday program were:

quote.para: The greatest threat against the non-proliferation regimes in nuclear, chemical and biology that exists today is the regime of Saddam Hussein. And we are threatened by that.

speech.para: That was from Richard Butler, former head of UNSCOM. The fourth quote—and this is a captivating piece of information that is rarely acknowledged—is from the head of the Iraq Survey Group, David Kay, who did not give a clean bill of health on everything, who was robust in what he said. His words on NBC on 27 January 2004 were:

quote.para: ... I think at the end of the inspection process we'll paint a picture of Iraq that was far more dangerous than even we thought it was before the war. It was of a system collapsing. It was a country that had the capability in weapons of mass destruction areas and in which terrorists, like ants to honey, were going after it.

speech.para: He draws a picture of a country which had more than was expected, although not everything that was expected, and that had links to terrorists units, cells and groups. Those relate to some of the veracity of this debate. What is the background we see there? We see that throughout the different sources of information there was a unified agreement and belief that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction programs. And it did. The facts have been borne out: Iraq had a sophisticated and developed weapons of mass destruction program, the facts of which were exposed throughout the 1990s.

In looking at the question of truth and the use of intelligence, what we find from the parliamentary joint committee report is a very simple conclusion, ultimately: that in relation to the Australian government's actions there was no pressure on the intelligence agencies, that there was no pressure to change assessments, that there was ultimately a fundamental verification of what was said.

I go back to David Kay, the head of the Iraq Survey Group. They did not find everything that was expected; that is absolutely true. But they have found many things which far exceeded that which they had ever expected to find, and that is a frightening reminder that we went with a purpose, we pursued that purpose and that purpose has been borne out in fact and empirically. There are three key points from David Kay, the head of the Iraq Survey Group: (1) that there were extensive concealment efforts in Iraq, (2) that it was more dangerous in Iraq than we thought before the war and (3) that there were dozens of weapons of mass destruction related programs in Iraq. Those are the facts, the realities, the findings, the empirical truth of what was the case and what has been discovered since the conflict in Iraq. We see that all of that goes to this point: here we had a brutal regime which was pursuing weapons of mass destruction capability.

This leads to the second great issue in this debate: was there a fundamental justification for the actions taken by the United States, by the United Kingdom led by Tony Blair, and by the Australian government? There are three critical reasons, which are linked, each of which, in their own right, would have been sufficient justification but which together form an undeniable base for the action. I say this knowing that 20, 30, 40 years from now what I say today is something for which I should be held to account.

The following are fundamental reasons why this action was justified. First, there was a weapons of mass destruction capability, and there was a program which was highly developed and had been developed over a period of years. You start with the fact that there was use. You have Halabja in 1987: 5,000 people were exterminated using poison gas, within Iraq, by the Iraqi regime. That is use, possession, ownership, extermination. Second, in the conflict with Iran, there was exactly the same pattern. Third, in 1995, after declaring themselves to be entirely free of weapons of mass destruction, we found that there were defections from within Saddam Hussein's own family, and 8,500 litres of anthrax and botulin toxin was released, and other chemical agents were exposed—all of which had been denied, all of which had been concealed, all of which had escaped the awareness of the UN Special Commission.

In 1998, the UNSCOM chief, Richard Butler, on leaving Iraq pointed to hidden and undisclosed amounts of VX nerve gas, chemical munitions, anthrax, sarin. Those were real, and those were the findings—not of Australia, not of other individual countries but of the international community. In 1999, troops surrounded Kerbala, wearing white chemical suits, sending a very powerful message to the Shiites and Marsh Arabs in the south. Iraq had clear terrorist links to the MEK—the Mujaheddin al-Khalq—the Palestinian Liberation Front, the Abu Nidal organisation and Ansar al Islam; and this is irrespective of al-Qaeda. So even if there was never any contact, there were four core groups with terrorist histories, links and activities closely integrated with the Iraqi regime. And that builds on the fact that there was a highly sophisticated program in relation to weapons of mass destruction.

Finally, this was a regime which, in the last 20 years, had an unprecedented record of human rights atrocities: 300,000 deaths, including extermination of the Marsh Arab population, the Shiite population and the Kurd population. Amnesty and Human Rights Watch found instances of beheading, machine-gunning, burying people alive, eye gouging, electric shocks, pulling of fingernails. Those were the stock in trade of this regime. So there were costs of action and costs of inaction. The costs of inaction were the continuation of the weapons of mass destruction programs, the continuation of the links with those four terrorist organisations, and, perhaps above all else, the continuation of the human rights abuses which led to the extermination of 300,000 souls. So, at the end of the day, was the intelligence misused? No. At the end of the day, was there a just cause? Absolutely. There was a just cause. It was a difficult choice between action and inaction, but I say this: I have only one regret in relation to this debate, and that is not that we acted but that we did not act sooner, that we waited for a decade whilst 300,000 souls perished. The Australian government was fundamentally justified in its actions. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—Order! The discussion is now concluded.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member for Griffith claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—Please proceed.

—The Minister for Foreign Affairs stated in the MPI today that I had said today that the intelligence services had lied. What I interjected across the table to the minister personally was a question, namely, `Did you lie to us?' The minister was not telling the truth when he then twisted that remark to imply that I had said that the intelligence services had lied.
—The member for Griffith is implying a lie there, which I think is a little bit unfair. The member for Griffith has concluded.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to give a personal explanation.
—Does the member for Grayndler claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The member for Grayndler may proceed.

—The member for Wentworth, after question time, gave a personal explanation in which he suggested that I had, yesterday in the MPI debate, misquoted him. I recalled—I heard it verbally on The World Today yesterday—Mr King said, and I quote, `I got a call this morning from my old clerk telling me there is a brief in the Solomon Islands for a couple of weeks as a barrister, which is my former calling, in May, which looks quite exciting, so I might take that up.' I think that speaks for itself.

Causley)—Mr Speaker has received a message from the Senate acquainting the House that Senator O'Brien has been discharged from the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and that Senator Marshall has been appointed a member of the committee.

talk.start.para: —I present the report of the Selection Committee relating to the consideration of committee and delegation reports and private members' business on Monday, 8 March 2004. The report will be printed in today's Hansard and the items accorded priority for debate will be published in the Notice Paper for the next sitting.

para.inline: Report relating to the consideration of committee and delegation reports and private Members' business on Monday, 8 March 2004

(ac) in the case of an appeal under paragraph (1)(c) against a decision not to make an order under subsection 170MBA(2)—by the organisation or person who applied for the order;
