talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr ANDREWS
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the amendments made by the Senate in place of the amendments disagreed to by the House be agreed to.

speech.para: I am pleased to advise the House that the government has reached an agreement with the Australian Democrats to secure passage of the Workplace Relations Amendment (Transmission of Business) Bill 2002. The agreement has resulted in several amendments to the bill. These replace the Senate amendments disagreed to by this House on 19 August 2003. The amendments clarify appeal rights. The Australian Industrial Relations Commission will also be required to apply a strict no disadvantage test when there is a transmission of business and an order is sought seeking to vary the application of a certified agreement. There is an exception to this requirement where the transmission is part of a reasonable strategy to deal with a short-term crisis in, and to assist in the revival of, a transmitted business. In return, the government has also agreed to hold an independent review of the transmission of business laws in late 2005. Among other things, this review will examine the best approach for identifying whether a transmission of business has occurred, as well as the effectiveness of the commission's new powers to deal with transmitted certified agreements. Finally, I would like to thank the Australian Democrats for their pragmatic and constructive approach to this legislation.

talk.start.para: —The primary purpose of transmission of business provisions in industrial law is to ensure that conditions of employment are maintained on the sale or transfer of a business. Without such provisions, employers would be able to get out of terms and conditions of employment by simply changing the company's name. The government has sought to remove these protections for employees. The government's Workplace Relations Amendment (Transmission of Business) Bill 2002 seeks to give employers the right to avoid their obligations in respect of certified agreements if they are selling or buying a business or even if such a sale is merely likely.

speech.para: The bill was amended in the Senate, with the government accepting amendments insisted on by the Democrats but not those insisted on by Labor. Consequently, Labor remain opposed to this bill as amended. In respect of the Democrat amendments, we acknowledge that they improve the bill by limiting somewhat the commission's discretion to depart from existing arrangements. The amended bill now requires that additional criteria be satisfied before the commission can exempt employers from enterprise agreements on transmission of business. There now has to be agreement of the parties to the agreement, agreement of the majority of employees affected, a finding that the employees would not be disadvantaged in relation to their terms or conditions of employment or a finding that the exemption is part of a reasonable strategy to deal with a short-term business crisis.

While this amendment addresses some of Labor's concerns in relation to the exemption of businesses from agreements, it does nothing to address the primary issue of when a transmission of business is defined as occurring in the first place. Unfortunately, the current transmission of business provisions in the act can be avoided by clever corporate restructuring. The Democrats have acknowledged this deficiency in the bill as amended. However, they passed the bill on the proviso that the government has committed to review the operation of these provisions in mid-2005. Labor are not satisfied by this commitment. Frankly, we do not trust the government, nor do we have any basis for doing so. We cannot support the relaxation of transmission of employee entitlements without being satisfied that the primary definition of transmission of business is adequately settled.

I go now to Labor's amendments, which would have addressed this issue. They strengthened the notion that a deal is a deal and that employment obligations should not be avoided by the sale or reorganisation of a business. Labor's amendments would have addressed this by broadening the test of transmission of business and requiring that the commission consider whether the activities of employees in businesses have been transferred. Labor's amendments also specifically ensured that employment conditions were preserved if a ship was transferred offshore and brought back again. Sadly, the government's only response to this issue was to facetiously precede these provisions with the heading `MUA—here to stay' when the bill was first in the Senate. Not surprisingly, the government did not insist on this amendment when the bill was returned to the Senate.

In conclusion, Labor remain opposed to this bill, as amended, because we are still concerned about the narrow definition of `transmission of business'. We feel that the existing definition does not take account of many business transfers where employees could reasonably expect to retain their conditions of employment. I observe that this is one of nine industrial relations bills in the Senate in this sitting fortnight. It makes you wonder what the government has been doing. It clearly has no third term agenda.

We learned today that the government does not even have a deal on the US-Australia free trade agreement, but it expects Labor to sign the deal. The minister is doing a little on the government's agenda, but no-one else seems to be. I do not want to damn him with faint praise because what he is doing is mischievous and inimical to the interests of working Australians.

The only legislation in this parliament seems to be the nine industrial relations bills that are sloshing around in the Senate. This bill has come back with a message from the Senate. We remain opposed to the bill. We recognise that the Democrats have made some improvements but, frankly, we cannot trust the government to protect the interests of the working men and women of this country.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr ANDREWS
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —It is somewhat ironical that the Labor state minister for workplace relations can trust a federal coalition government to provide for the workers in that state. I think that says more about the federal Labor Party than anything else. The reality is that members of the Labor Party have dealt themselves out of these negotiations. They are implacably opposed to the government's move to make more flexible workplaces and give people choice, which leads to more jobs, higher wages and greater security for Australian families. In contrast, the Democrats were prepared to enter into reasonable negotiations with the government. As a result, we have their agreement for this legislation.

speech.para: In relation to the definition of `transmission of business', I say to the member for Rankin that there is currently a case in relation to the Health Services Union Award of 1993, which is to be heard in the High Court, involving Gribbles Radiology Pty Ltd and the Health Services Union. If the decision of the High Court in that case, after the High Court has heard arguments and has come to a conclusion about it, still leaves some uncertainty about the definition, we propose to have an inquiry. That is a commonsense and sensible way forward. I therefore urge the House to support the Workplace Relations Amendment (Transmission of Business) Bill 2002.

talk.start.para: —I am also concerned with the amendments which have been acceded to by the Democrats. I think the Democrats have, in good faith, looked to improve the policy of the government in this area; however, having looked at the legislation very quickly and briefly, I have concerns about the practical application of the Workplace Relations Amendment (Transmission of Business) Bill 2002 if it were to be enacted in the workplaces of the country. The issue of transmission of business has been one of great importance to the community since Federation. Provisions of transmission of business have been in place since the enactment of the 1904 act. However, what has occurred in the last 20 or more years in the workplace is that there has been another mechanism by which employers have looked to obviate their responsibilities under the federal law regulating industrial relations.

speech.para: In the last 20 years, the use of outsourcing and contracting out was deemed to be an area that would not be covered by transmission of business. From the early 1990s onwards, the judiciary looked at whether the provisions of the act were being properly interpreted. In the late 1990s the Federal Court of Australia found that, in many instances, there were employers deliberately attempting to evade their industrial obligations—award or enterprise agreement provisions—by selling off all or part of a business or by outsourcing fundamental or discrete parts of organisations. That has led to many workers being shortchanged in what was owed to them.

I have looked at some of the amendments which have been accepted by the government and the Democrats. These amendments are somewhat vague, which concerns me. For example, one amendment says that, if there were agreement of the parties to the agreement, transmission of business provisions could be avoided. Many instances where transmission of business may apply would involve new employees and an employer. New employees will agree to a set of conditions, even if they are inferior to what would bind an employer, if they were not to be employed and if they did not accept those conditions. I have concerns if the transmission of business provisions did not apply if agreements were to occur, given that, in practice, the agreement may not be between the employer and existing employees but quite possibly between an employer and potential employees.

I am also concerned if there were a finding that the employees would not be disadvantaged in relation to their terms or conditions of employment and what disadvantage test the minister is assuming would be used. If it is the no disadvantage test currently in the act, that test would apply only against the award, not against the agreement. As we all know, that no disadvantage test definition is a misnomer. It does not apply to conditions or to provisions of enterprise agreements; it applies to awards which are far inferior, in most circumstances, than the enterprise agreement that may have been transmitted. I seek assurance that that is not the definition being applied to this bill.

I am also concerned if there were a finding that the exemption is part of a reasonable strategy to deal with a short-term business crisis and what that could mean. What circumstances would allow a company to evade their industrial obligations? Why is it that a company is able to prevent a law applying to it when it is paying its work force, but cannot prevent a law applying to it when it is paying another company, paying the government payroll tax or paying other fees and charges that it may have to pay? Why would the government allow an employer to evade a contract? (Extension of time granted)

In effect, that is what is happening here. There is one law for the workers of this country and another law in which the government wishes to allow employers to evade their responsibilities. But I do not see that capacity to evade other obligations taking place elsewhere. I therefore think that that exemplifies this government's intention to diminish the capacity of Australian workers to receive a decent income.

I am very concerned that this bill, if enacted, is going to start a spate of applications to the commission to allow employers to evade their lawful obligations under the act. It sends an awful message to the community. It says: `We will give you as many reasons as we possibly can'—as the government is attempting to do for employers—`to find an excuse not to pay your work force.' It says: `We are going to diminish a principle that has been upheld in the federal industrial relations system for decades so that we can allow you to evade your obligations to your work force or to your prospective work force.' Whilst, I think the minister does not accept that that is the case in theory, unfortunately, in practice I think there is a great chance of that happening.

I noticed that the minister did make reference to a matter before the High Court, and I too await the outcome of that matter; I think it is of great significance for the nation and the Australian work force at large. However, I do think the minister should make clear whether or not this bill, if enacted, will provide the capacity for employees to miss out on their current wages. I am not convinced by what has been said. I would like to look at the amendments in detail and perhaps at the regulations, if there are any, as to how they would apply. But, at first glance, it concerns me that this area, which is so important to the security of people's employment and employment conditions is going to be overturned. Unfortunately, I think the Democrats have not got it right on this occasion. I am sure they had the best of intentions, but I am really concerned that thousands, if not tens of thousands, of Australian workers would be left far worse off as a result of the enactment of this bill.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr ANDREWS
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The honourable member for Burke is being unnecessarily alarmist. Under section 149 of the Workplace Relations Act, the commission already has the power to order that the new operator is not bound by an award that bound the former operator. There was no similar provision in relation to certified agreements, and this bill puts in place a similar provision and gives the commission power which it had in relation to awards. The amendment makes it clear that, when an order is sought before the business concerned has been transmitted, the commission must take into account the terms and conditions of employment that apply or will apply to the employees of the incoming employer. So this amendment addresses the concern raised by the Democrats that orders arising from a transmission of business situation may be strategically used by employers to avoid their obligations. The government has met that concern raised by the Democrats.

—I join the member for Burke in expressing alarm, as I did in my first contribution, about these particular provisions. In the message that has come from the Senate, there is now a situation where the commission can exempt employers from enterprise agreements on transmission of business where there is a finding by the commission that the exemption is part of a reasonable strategy to deal with a short-term business crisis. I join the member for Burke in pointing out that the government always seems to put working people last. We understand the need to try and salvage a business if it is subject to a downturn in market conditions, but why is it the case that employees have to bear the brunt of any such downturn? Other creditors presumably do not have to bear it, but the employees are the first to be put off. Their conditions are subject to great threat under this legislation. This is just an ongoing display by this government of the ranking of employees. In situations where businesses are not travelling very well, we know that they like to rank employees very lowly in relation to employee entitlements with the rather inadequate GEERS scheme—except for the mightily adequate arrangements that were put in place for employees of the Prime Minister's brother.

speech.para: We have heard from an experienced practitioner in the member for Burke, who has cited a number of cases of businesses avoiding their obligations to employees throughout the 1990s. He is obviously very well versed in this area, and I think his legitimate concerns have been dismissed in typically contemptuous style by the minister. Our concerns remain, and this debate, in which I understand the member for Burke will be contributing further, reinforces in our minds the need to oppose this legislation, thereby protecting the interests of the working men and women of this country, which is something the government finds totally alien.

talk.start.para: —I want to say something in response to the minister. I am aware that the two separate sections in the Workplace Relations Act, section 149(1)(d) and section 170MB, are both provisions that go to the transmission of business. Section 149(1)(d) refers to the federal awards and how they would bind future employers in certain circumstances. Section 170MB mirrors section 149. However, it does not provide the capacity for the commission to seek a determination, and therefore did not allow the commission to determine whether a matter should be arbitrated or not. The point I am looking to make is that the one thing that has evolved over time, certainly judicially, with respect to transmission of business—and this was seen in a spate of federal court cases—was that there was a need to redress the consequences of employers outsourcing discrete parts of their businesses, thereby evading their industrial obligations to their work forces. I was making the point that the judiciary has already worked out that it is grossly unfair that you can outsource a discrete part of your business and thereby evade your industrial obligations. I thought I was making that perfectly clear.

speech.para: The Federal Court quite rightly in a number of cases have declared that that is not reasonable, and indeed determined that in many of these circumstances—I am not saying in all the cases that went before the Federal Court but in the majority of cases—outsourcing should be deemed to be a transmission of business. I think that a government that was concerned about consistency in law and protecting the rights of the employer and employees would provide protection to employees to prevent those employees losing entitlements by nefarious means, by unfair and inequitable means.

Unfortunately, whilst this bill has been improved somewhat, I have to say that in practice, on the ground, out of this place in workplaces across the country it will be able to be abused and it will be abused by a minority of employers. This will not only be to the detriment of those employed by that minority of employers, it will also be to the detriment of the fair and reasonable employer, because if you allow employers who want to do the wrong thing to get an advantage, they not only get an advantage over their own work force but they get an advantage over the other employers who choose not to take that route. I think this government is allowing those employers to take the wrong step—

talk.start.para: —The low road.

—As the shadow minister says, take the low road on this issue. What Labor is attempting to do is say, `Let's be fair, let's be reasonable not only to the Australian work force but to those employers who refuse to use this means to denigrate the work done by the Australian work force, to the detriment of those workers and employer competitors.'

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr ANDREWS
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I will reply briefly to the honourable member's comments. I suggest he should not quote selectively from Federal Court judgments. The definitive court in this country, namely the High Court, in PP Consultants has already dealt with this issue and, as I said, there is a case on appeal to the High Court in the matter of Gribbles. If there is some further uncertainty which an independent review shows, that can be dealt with in the due course of time.

speech.para: Finally, in response to the honourable member for Rankin in his reference to employee entitlements, I remind the House that in 13 years the Labor Party in government did nothing and that under the GEER scheme some 27,000 employees have received entitlements. That is something that is very pro-worker from this government.
Question put:

motion.para: That the motion (Mr Andrews's) be agreed to.

cognateinfo.title: MEDICAL INDEMNITY (IBNR INDEMNITY) CONTRIBUTION AMENDMENT BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 19 February, on motion by Mr Abbott:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —This is an important health policy issue and, as we proved in question time today, the last thing that you would want the minister for health talking about is a health issue, because that is not where he spends any of his time—and on the medical indemnity issue, it more than shows. This is the third patch-up job that the Howard government has engaged in on the medical indemnity issue. There is another one to come and, by the minister for health's own admission, this series of patch-up jobs will last two years at best. What we know is that the series of patch-up jobs has caused a great deal of uncertainty in the community and amongst doctors, and of course it has cost the taxpayer hundreds of millions of dollars. It did not need to be like this—a crisis with patch after patch after patch put on it. A competent government would have defused the medical indemnity crisis before it became a crisis. But when it comes to health, the government we have does not care, is not interested and, when it tries things, is far less than competent.

speech.para: Back in 1991 the then Labor government established a review of compensation and professional indemnity arrangements for health care professionals, headed by senior bureaucrat Fiona Tito. The report on these issues was handed to the then minister for health, Dr Carmen Lawrence, the member for Fremantle, in January 1996, barely a fortnight before Paul Keating called the 1996 election. The Tito report, as it became known, provided a careful analysis of the arrangements in existence to provide for patients injured through negligence or misadventure. The report identified an array of major problems including, amongst others, that public data was not available on adverse events and negligence actions; many treatments had an inadequate evidence base and were not sufficiently outcome focused; neither health professionals nor health care consumers had access to adequate information on the risks and benefits of treatment options; patients did not have adequate access to their own health care records; the system was plagued by poor communication, particularly if an adverse event had occurred; programs designed to improve quality were poorly designed and not sustainable; there was no guarantee of adequate government funded assistance for people with severe disabilities, and the assistance provided was often poorly coordinated; health care consumers faced significant difficulties in accessing the tort system in cases of negligence; there was no providential scrutiny of the medical defence organisation industry, allowing longstanding inadequate funding of liabilities by medical defence organisations; there was no requirement for health care businesses to hold professional liability cover or cover for their institutional non-delegable duty of care, and laws pertaining to insurance requirements were unclear; there were concerns about the work force effects of indemnity in specific areas of medical practice such as obstetrics.

You would have thought that a competent incoming minister for health, getting a report that pointed to an array of major problems as detailed and severe as these, would have done something. You would have thought that a competent minister for health would have looked at that report, at that list of what was wrong with the system, and would have done something. But a former minister for health, Dr Michael Wooldridge, did not do anything. He allowed the report to sit on his desk, allowing all of these major problems with the health care system to just sit. Let us remind ourselves what we are talking about here: a failure to have proper scrutiny of medical defence organisations that had inadequately funded resources for the long-term claims that they were going to face; severely injured people just getting patch up mixes of care rather than systemic care; treatments being provided to people for which there was no real evidence focus. All of these things were wrong with our health system—poor treatment for people with severe disabilities and an emerging liabilities crisis for medical defence organisations—and Minister Wooldridge just sits.

What is even more shocking is that he sat because he preferred to just sit. You could perhaps forgive incompetence—perhaps he was doing other things in the health system—but he just sat because he preferred to. In fact, he is proud of just having sat and watched the medical indemnity crisis emerge. When speaking at the University of Melbourne in April last year, Dr Wooldridge fessed up to this and said:

quote.para: As Minister, I was accused of doing far too little on medical indemnity. That's completely unfair. I did absolutely nothing whatsoever.

speech.para: This is a Howard government minister proud of his record of doing absolutely nothing. I suspect that there are a number of current members of the frontbench who could go out and make that statement today—and make it truthfully, because we know that this government has completely stalled on the domestic policy agenda.

Because Minister Wooldridge was sitting and sitting and proudly doing absolutely nothing, the medical indemnity crisis gathered a head of steam. We know the medical indemnity situation came to public attention and caused a crisis that even this government in its incompetence and arrogance could not ignore: in May 2002 UMP and its wholly owned subsidiary, Australian Medical Insurance Ltd, went into provisional liquidation—they collapsed.

UMP was the largest medical insurer in Australia. It provided cover for about 60 per cent of medical practitioners nationally and 90 per cent in New South Wales. UMP's capital reserves foundered in the face of unprecedented large insurance payouts; a $30 million loss arising from the collapse of HIH as one of UMP's re-insurers—and the role of the Howard government in the HIH crisis is now a matter of record and history; a claim-spike ahead of the introduction of the new health care liability act; and higher capital requirements imposed by APRA. The failure of the management of UMP to properly price products must also be acknowledged.

Even the Howard government in its incompetence and arrogance could not afford to sit any more when 60 per cent of medical professionals nationally no longer had insurance because UMP had collapsed. We see a government finally startled into action, finally knowing that it needed to do something. So the former minister for health, Senator Kay Patterson, and the current minister for revenue, Senator Helen Coonan, are told to go out and do something. What they do is try to put together a patch-up job, because this government never does anything systemic or to a quality level to address a crisis. It has got a crisis and it says, `What are we going to do? We are going to scurry around and we are going to put the biggest patch we can find over it and hope that it is going to hold.' In its scurrying around, the Howard government said that it would pick up the unfunded liabilities of UMP, that it would recoup from doctors the amount that that was costing the government, and that recouping would be done through the now infamous IBNR levy—the incurred but not reported claims levy. Called the `incurred but not reported claims' because the substantial liabilities of UMP were going to arise from claims that had occurred—for example an adverse medical outcome or misadventure—but had not been reported before UMP collapsed and when the person to whom that had happened later made a claim, obviously a source of funds was needed to draw down upon.

So the first patch is put in place by ministers Patterson and Coonan—Minister Patterson in her capacity as then Minister for Health and Ageing—and what they say is, `We'll pick up the liabilities of UMP and we'll get the money back from the UMP members through the IBNR levy.' They also say that there needs to be prudential regulation of the medical defence organisations and that prudential regulation be put in place. Of course, Labor supports prudential regulation being in place. In fact, if it had been in place at the time that a prudential issue was first pointed to by the Tito report, much of what followed probably would not have happened.

Another part of what happened at that time was that the government decided that medical indemnity cover must be provided through a contract of insurance, and that has changed the medical indemnity system in this country. There was the mutuality model, which enabled medical defence organisations to offer claims incurred insurance—that is, if you were a doctor and you paid your MDO, any claim that was incurred in that period, whether or not it was reported in that period, would be covered by your MDO. There was then a movement to the contract of insurance model, which meant that you could only get coverage for claims made during the period that you were paying your premiums.

I accept that there would now be severe difficulties in trying to take the model back to a model of mutuality and allowing claims in the curved coverage for doctors. But one does wonder whether, in the unseemly haste of trying to put a patch over the UMP issue and with the patchwork that Senator Patterson and Senator Coonan were engaged in—crashing around, desperately trying to find a solution to the medical indemnity crisis and enforcing the medical defence organisations to move to a contract of insurance model—the baby was thrown out with the bath water. As we now know, a lot of what needs to be done to resolve the medical indemnity crisis relates to the circumstance that exists when doctors are no longer practising or having any adverse event being reported but needing to be covered by the premiums they paid when they were practising doctors. So the whole issue about the need for run-off reinsurance—for doctors in retirement and no longer practising needing some separate form of cover—has arisen because of the way in which the industry was moved across to an insurance model. If we all had our time again, we might think about whether that was a wise course. Certainly the Howard government might think about whether that was a wise course; but I suspect that, if it had its time again, it might have got the Tito report off the minister's desk and done something.

That was the first patch, and we know that the first patch unwound in spectacular fashion when levy notices started hitting the desks of doctors in August and September last year, and specialists throughout New South Wales in particular started putting their resignations in at public hospitals, saying, `If that's how we're going to be treated by a Howard government, which doesn't know what it's doing, then we're not going to work as doctors any more under those circumstances.' Faced with the medical work force marching off the job in New South Wales, the Howard government was again stung into action—because nothing they have ever done in this area has been a result of thoughtful planning—and had to do something.

The new minister for health, Minister Abbott—in a flight of panic, negotiating with the AMA and desperate to get doctors back to work—cooks up a scheme whereby there will be an IBNR levy moratorium. Minister Abbott's first version of this scheme is to say to the doctors, `Hey, guys, what about I put a moratorium into place—you don't have to pay money now, at least not as much money now—and we put the whole issue off until after the next election? We're really only interested in a political patch now and we'll worry about the substance of it later.' Fortunately, the doctors were awake to the Howard government's lack of strategic approach—and they are probably awake to the fact that the last thing Tony Abbott will be after the next election is minister for health—so they said, `No, we actually want something done now.'

So the second patch-up is Minister Abbott's IBNR levy moratorium to stop doctors paying the bills, or to at least stop them paying all the bills, while he puts in place a ministerial review panel, which he says he will chair. That process—the ministerial review panel—does go on. Basically, the legislation before the House today deals with some, but not all, of the matters coming out of the ministerial review panel. What we know is that there will be a further series of legislation—a further patch, even on top of this patch—and, endearingly, Minister Abbott conceded that he expects the whole thing to last for about two years because that is as long as it is good for.

The panel recommended that one of the earlier patch-ups—the high cost claims scheme—be changed. This is a claims scheme to assist with meeting the costs of claims that are substantial in nature. The original figure was for claims over $500,000; the panel recommended that that be reduced to $300,000. So there we have a patch on a patch, and that has been achieved by regulation. Then the panel recommended, because of the issue I referred to about run-off cover, that there needed to be a government backed run-off reinsurance vehicle, funded by a charge over medical insurers. It would be this vehicle that people would look to when they reported a claim made against a doctor who had subsequently gone into retirement or was out of the medical work force for other reasons. It is that patch that we are going to see in future legislation. The details of that patch are not available now.

The third thing that the panel recommended was that the existing premium subsidy scheme be replaced by a premium support scheme to be paid to medical insurers for doctors whose actuarially assessed premiums passed a trigger percentage of private medical income. This is in this package of legislation. Once again it is a patch on a patch, because the original Howard government plan was to subsidise the ongoing medical indemnity premiums of doctors in nominated high-risk specialty areas like neurosurgery, orthopaedic surgery and the like. That has not found favour with the doctors or with the panel, so now the premium subsidy scheme will apply to all doctors and their eligibility for it will be triggered if their medical indemnity insurance hits a certain percentage of their income, being 7.5 per cent of gross private income.

This is a very substantial gain for the doctors. Under the new premium support arrangements the standard premium for a New South Wales orthopaedic surgeon with under $200,000 in medical income will fall from $40,000 to $20,000. As you are probably aware, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, most orthopaedic surgeons earn more than $200,000 in medical income a year, I venture to say. So a more realistic example is probably the standard premium for a New South Wales orthopaedic surgeon with a $475,000 income, which will fall from $67,000 to $42,000. All up this initiative is costing taxpayers $24 million. It is a patch on a patch.

Then there is the very vexed IBNR levy. `They are going to levy them.' `No, they're not going to levy them.' `There is a moratorium.' `They've got to sort it out.' So the panel has sorted it out for them, and in response to the panel's findings the Howard government is now going to replace the IBNR levy with what will be known as the UMP support arrangements. Under the old IBNR levy, if you were a member of UMP at a specified date then you owed the system an amount figured from the medical indemnity premiums that you paid. Of course, that did not have any flexibility in it for people who were then working full time but had since withdrawn from the work force or for people who were then practising in a high-risk specialty but were no longer doing so. So it was a flawed scheme.

The government has now moved to say, `Let's replace all of that so that doctors who were members of UMP in 2000 and have medical incomes above $5,000 a year will pay whichever is the least of the former IBNR annual levy— two per cent of gross private medical income or $5,000.' There are some other changes that apply relating to how long you were a member of UMP. This is an arrangement which means you can stand back and ask, `What has happened with the money here?' The current IBNR liability that the Howard government estimates came from the UMP collapse is $483 million. Of this, $233 million will be covered by the high-cost claims scheme and levy exemptions funded by the Howard government. That is all taxpayers' money. Of the remaining $250 million, $120 million will be paid by the Howard government and $130 million will be paid by doctors through the run-off reinsurance vehicle and the UMP support arrangements.

All in all, the Howard government, out of this series of desperate patches and carry-on—a crisis that need not have happened—has basically stepped up to the plate to use taxpayers' funds to pay three-quarters of the estimated UMP liability. I suspect that Australian citizens who are also Australian health care consumers might want to ask themselves whether paying three-quarters of $483 million for a crisis that did not have to happen—it only happened because of Howard government incompetence—is what they would most like to see expenditure of precious health funds on, or whether they would like to see it invested in the local public hospital, in supporting bulk-billing or in paying for vaccines for children, because none of those things are going to happen. But, of course, hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money has gone into this.

One knows that a government is truly desperate for a solution when a conservative minister—and a conservative minister for health—actually flirts with trying to resolve all of the medical indemnity issue by moving to a single national insurance scheme for doctors. From a government that is, as it tells us, opposed to big government, opposed to monopoly provision and certainly opposed to expansion of the public sector, so desperate was this minister for health that he was actively in the cart for a nice big old-world style solution—a nice big public sector solution. He was going to have a single national insurance scheme for doctors. Whatever the merits of that—and there may be people who want to debate the merits of that—you would have to say you are a pretty desperate conservative minister when you decide that what you really need to do is build a single national insurance scheme for doctors. Unsurprisingly, this move was apparently squashed by Treasury and by a number of medical defence organisations.

There we have it: a series of patches on patches. This is the latest of them. What I can absolutely guarantee to this House is that we will be back. We will be back to legislate the run-off reinsurance vehicle. The patches on the patches have not finished yet. And then, according to the minister for health himself, we will be back in two years because he reckons that is all the life that this has got in it. When you actually look at this course of events it should hardly surprise us, because the Howard government history in health is one of patch and failure. They have done it in the medical indemnity area. Now, of course, they are doing it to Medicare overall. The original view of this government, in line with the Prime Minister's often stated goal of the 1970s and 1980s, was to unwind and destroy Medicare. They wanted to do that in this term by sitting idly by—as they had with the medical indemnity issue—as Medicare died and as bulk-billing fell because the Medicare rebate became less and less connected with real health costs and there was less investment in it.

It was only because of Labor campaigning on the bulk-billing crisis that any health statement was made by this government. They would not have made a major health statement in this period of government if it had not been for Labor campaigning on bulk-billing. As we know, the first statement they were startled into making was the so-called A Fairer Medicare package from last May. We now know of course that the so-called A Fairer Medicare package was so spectacularly bad that it led not only to the death of the package but also to the end of a health minister. You do not often come up with a government initiative that is so spectacularly bad that the package ends up stone dead and the health minister that auspiced it is moved on in unseemly haste. But of course that is what happened with the first Medicare patch. Now we have the second Medicare patch before the Senate, and we will find out its fate probably over the coming sitting fortnight.

talk.start.para: —And the fate of the minister.

—Yes. As we know, the Minister for Health and Ageing is not really doing much about health; he does a lot about other things. The second Medicare patch is in the Senate. We will find out in this fortnight whether or not that patch sticks. But my message about that patch remains: how desperate would you have to be to cover up your failure to invest in Medicare that you design a so-called safety net costing $266 million? When you look at it in detail what you can say about it is that 97 per cent of Australians will be worse off under it because they will not get anywhere near the so-called safety net, but they will experience additional health costs caused by the collapse of bulk-billing and the price inflation effects of the sham safety net. Ninety-seven per cent of Australians will be worse off. Of the three per cent who are notionally better off, the architect of Medicare, Professor John Deeble, has said, `Half of them are better off under the current arrangements.' So $266 million is being spent to notionally make 1.5 per cent of Australians better off and, of that $266 million, $72 million is wasted in administration. How desperate a health minister would you have to be to think that a scheme as crazy, ineffective and wasteful as that was anything like a solution? Of course, we know it is not a health solution; it is a political solution because the minister for health wants something to cover up the intention to destroy Medicare, and the sham safety net is it. As he gets about the business of destroying Medicare, he can at least have the political spin which says, `Don't worry about me destroying Medicare, because I have got you a sham safety net.' The message from Labor, well and truly, to senators who say that they believe and support Medicare is, `Do not vote for the sham safety net. Do not be complicit in this fundamental undermining of Medicare.'

speech.para: I want to conclude by noting one other very important patch and failure job in which this government has engaged. Of course, that is the patch and failure job with private health insurance. We were told that the lifetime rating scheme was going to boost private health insurance membership and keep it up and growing. The reverse is true. Whatever spin the minister puts on the membership statistics, the truth—and everybody knows it—is that every time we get private health insurance holding statistics, every time we get the numbers of members in private health insurance, they have gone down. Membership has most particularly gone down in the younger age ranges. These are the members who are most needed in private health insurance because they are subsidising the cost of the older members. The government says it prides itself on private health insurance affordability and it promised to put downwards pressure on premiums. We know what happens every time, and it happened last Friday. It happens every year. You can set your watch by it. It should be marked in the calendar like Christmas. We know that what happens every time is that the conservative minister for health, in this case Minister Abbott, puts a great big tick on increases to private health insurance premiums, as he did last Friday. Private health insurance premiums are going up and up.

We know that increases in private health insurance premiums are hard to sell. The private health insurance industry has had a little bit of expert assistance in selling these private health insurance premium increases because they have had the former director of the Liberal Party and the current pollster of the Liberal Party working out how to sell the message for them. The unanswered question is whether Mr Abbott has engaged in having that kind of assistance provided to him as well, and we will be expecting Minister Abbott to answer the question that he effectively took on notice at question time today. We believe it is inappropriate for the government to be in league with the private health insurers to get Liberal Party advice, paid for by the private health insurers, as to how to snow the Australian public about a private health insurance premium rise.
I conclude by moving the second reading amendment that stands in my name, namely:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the government for:
(1) failing to act to prevent the medical indemnity crisis and engaging in a series of political fixes not long term solutions to the medical indemnity crisis; and
(2) allowing a health crisis to develop including medical indemnity and insurance arrangements”.

talker.name.id: jen10000Jenkins, Harry (The DEPUTY SPEAKER)The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—
talker.name: Jenkins, Harry (The DEPUTY SPEAKER)
The DEPUTY SPEAKER

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—Today I rise to speak on the Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill 2004 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Amendment Bill 2004. We have just heard a wide-ranging debate from the member for Lalor, who prances in here as the shadow minister for health. She talked about responsible, accountable expenditure in relation to health. I want to raise a question which came to mind as she was making her comments: what would Centenary House provide? The $4 million that Centenary House will provide to the Labor Party this year would pay for an extra 20 doctors; it would pay for an extra 40 nurses or an extra 100 aged care beds. That is just in one year. Over the life of the rort, it would pay for an additional 180 doctors, an additional 360 nurses or an additional 900 aged care beds, but instead the Labor Party will choose to pay for around 10 million pieces of direct mail this year—

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I thought this was a serious debate. I draw the member's attention to the bills at hand and also to the second reading amendment, which does allow a slightly more wide-ranging debate but—
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. I know that the honourable member for Paterson knows that he is required to be relevant to the bills and the motion. I have listened carefully.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I did not note you drawing the shadow minister to account on the question of relevance to the bills—

—Order! The honourable member for Paterson will resume his seat. I did not really note that I drew the attention of the member for Paterson to relevance. I gave him latitude, in that he is one minute into his speech, and I thought that my comments related that. If he wants the ruling on the point of order, I was ruling that so far, in his introductory remarks, he had been relevant—and I expect him to continue to be relevant.

—This speech is about the welfare of doctors. Just imagine: if the $4 million this year which is going into the pockets of the Labor Party were going into the health system, that would mean an extra 20 doctors. It would mean, perhaps, an additional 40 nurses or 100 aged care beds, but instead they will spend that $4 million this year on 10 million pieces of direct mail or maybe 800,000 posters of their leader—or, for his vanity, perhaps 600,000 full colour posters.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: this is a guy with record printing allowances. I draw your attention to—
—Order! The honourable member for Hunter will resume his seat. The honourable member for Paterson has the call.
—The member for Hunter is mistaken. He referred to the member for Paterson, but it was the member for Paterson before me who set the records on printing—

—Order! I advise the honourable member for Paterson to ignore the honourable member for Hunter's interventions, and I seek direction from the member for Hunter as to whether he is rising on a point of order.
—I am indeed, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—He will come directly to his point of order.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: obviously I am rising on the issue of relevance, and I ask you to bring the member for Paterson back to the bills before the House.
—I have had that point of order and I am watching very carefully.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, obviously they do not want to hear how they are ripping off from the taxpayer money that could be invested in the health system for their own benefit. But these two bills relate to medical indemnity, and they go straight to the heart of the medical indemnity problem—that is, the need for patient confidence in a health system where they have the right to seek recourse for medical negligence and the need for doctors to be able to be confident that they are covered by their insurance if they are sued for medical negligence.

speech.para: Our government is investing $620 million over the next four years in medical indemnity. These two bills will put into force the government's new medical indemnity measures that were announced on 17 December last year. They do address the problems still facing doctors and they will build on our past measures. But we need to understand something, and we need to be sympathetic towards doctors, in that medical negligence is something that has grown over time, with the court system way out of whack. Huge amounts of money in compensation, a growing volume of litigation and the troubles of UMP and HIH have all had a massive impact on the premiums paid by doctors. The measures introduced in these bills will help doctors get on with the job of caring for patients and providing medical services to our local communities, with affordable medical indemnity. That is what it is really all about. It is about providing service to our community through doctors.

These two bills provide the basis for the government's additional medical indemnity measures, in that they will contribute $181 million from now until 2006-07 towards meeting the costs of medical indemnity, making it more affordable for our doctors. Our doctors do not have leasing agreements as in the case of Centenary House. These are people who work in the community and pay rent. Fortunately, not many of them have the Labor Party as landlords. Our original measures, introduced in 2002, were developed to address the medical indemnity industry's long-term viability and the affordability of medical indemnity premiums for doctors. The government have continued to enhance this package of measures by extending financial protection to doctors for the costs of claims beyond the level of their indemnity insurance, increasing the number of categories of doctors who are eligible to be exempt from the incurred but not reported liabilities contribution and putting a moratorium on the amount payable under IBNR contributions for 18 months.

These bills address two matters: the issues regarding the current IBNR scheme contribution and reducing its cost to doctors, and the continuing issue of affordability of medical indemnity insurance. I know, as I speak to the doctors in my electorate in the Hunter Valley, that they are concerned that their payments are blowing out. They have concerns about the future viability and affordability of insurance to meet those claims. The government have stepped in and provided that level of protection. For example, under the new premium support scheme we will pay 80 per cent of the costs of premiums over and above 7½ per cent of a doctor's income. If we look at the high-cost claims support scheme, we will now cover 50 per cent of the payments over $300,000.

But we need to see more doctors. We have just heard the member for Lalor talk about the lack of doctors and what that is doing to our community. I would put to the member for Lalor that she should talk to some of the training providers at universities. She would find out that the lack of doctors today is the direct result of Labor Party policy, because the time frame for a doctor to go to university, have their training and be put out in the marketplace is between eight and 12 years. This government has only been in office for eight years, so the lack of doctors that we have seen in the last eight years is because of Labor Party policy. The only policy they seemed to want to work on was how they could rort another deal on Centenary House—how they could take $36 million from the taxpayer and put it into their pockets. For each and every member—including the member for Hunter, who is jumping up with another frivolous point of order—that would work out at about $560,000 in their pockets—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order on relevance. I understand you have ruled on this point of order already. I ask you again to bring the speaker back to the bills before the chamber.
—The honourable member for Paterson will continue to be relevant.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am bringing it back to doctors and how the Labor Party, in its previous term of government, ignored the real concerns of the community. As I said, the reason for a lack of doctors in our community and why bulk-billing is down is that the Labor Party, when in government, did nothing to train an adequate number of doctors. The member for Hunter knows that. The member for Hunter knows that he and his Labor Party are directly responsible for it.

speech.para: What do the Labor Party come up with as offers? There are two people in my community who are also involved in the community of the member for Hunter—that is, Dr Arn Sprogis, who is the head of the Hunter Urban Division of General Practice, and Dr Chris Boyle, who is the chairman of that body. Dr Chris Boyle, in a letter to the editor of the Examiner after the member for Werriwa's visit to our electorate, where he announced what he was going to do in relation to doctors, said:

quote.para: Sir, I was very interested to read what the ALP policy on the Medicare bulk-billing team is (Examiner, February 12). It does not involve new GPs. It simply involves moving GPs from private practice to public service—not one new GP, simply moving the deckchairs on the Titanic. Being a public service facility, I assume that means that the service will be fully funded and resourced so that all the GP has to do is turn up and work from nine to five. All the staff, the nurses, the building, the computers, the insurance and the entire infrastructure would be provided by government. No wonder it is possible to then bulk-bill, because the cost of the service will be heavily subsidised through the government. To bulk-bill and be in private practice is very difficult to do now because the rebate has failed to keep up with the cost of providing the service.

speech.para: I accept that. He continues:

quote.para: This is why bulk-billing is in decline, and this has not been addressed by the ALP's policy. It has been partially addressed by the government's MedicarePlus policy, but even that is a stopgap measure that will only help for two years.

speech.para: I acknowledge that. Dr Chris Boyle then says:

quote.para: Both sides of politics should start to have a real think about health policy and come up with some realistic solutions and stop playing politics with the nation's health.

speech.para: I agree with that. He goes on:

quote.para: Mickey mouse ideas like Medicare bulk-billing teams are irrational and no way is it the sensible sustainable approach that is required.

speech.para: That was written by Chris Boyle, of Raymond Terrace, who happens to be the chair of the Hunter Urban Division of General Practice. But he is not a single voice. He is supported by his CEO, Dr Arn Sprogis, the head of the division. He questioned where the doctors would come from. An article in the Examiner, by Rebecca Biesler, said:

quote.para: Dr Sprogis described the promise as a joke in poor taste. `If Mark Latham thinks he can find two doctors to come to Raymond Terrace, it shows how little he knows about health,' he said. Doctor woes had proved how hard it was to get a doctor in the area.

speech.para: It goes on to say:

quote.para: Dr Boyle said the government was pinching doctors from third-world countries already struggling to meet the demands for medical service but refused to allocate more university medical places in Australia. `Bulk-billing is not the issue,' Dr Boyle said. `The real issue is access to doctors. There just aren't enough of them to go around. Bulk-billing was not viable for doctors as the Medicare rebate was too low. The only reason bulk-billing is on the agenda is because it started to bite hard in the marginal electorates.'

speech.para: Dr Boyle and Dr Sprogis have summed it up in one. The former Labor government failed to train enough doctors, to have in the marketplace now and over the last eight years, to address the bulk-billing problem. The Labor Party can sit there and sprout on—but it is not putting university places in. We will not see the fruits of the education of the people that enter university this year to become doctors for eight to 12 years. What has happened? It is the Labor Party who has failed the people when it comes to bulk-billing. When the Labor Party came out with its policy, Dr Arn Sprogis was interviewed by Warren Moore on 2HD, on 28 October. Of Labor's Medicare policy, he said:

quote.para: I think it's one of the most bizarre notions I've seen in the 12 or 13 years I've been in this game. I think the Labor Party's lost the plot completely to be quite honest.

speech.para: But in the discussion with Cameron Williams on 2HD on 19 November when speaking about the Howard government's MedicarePlus program he said:

quote.para: I think it in all a good package. It gives some certainty to the public. I think it will be widely accepted by the public and I think Tony Abbott is on a winner.

speech.para: I do not think any government will always have it 100 per cent correct on medical policy, because it is a shifting market. We can talk about expenditure; we can talk about a range of things. But the reality is that you have to address the situation here and now, today. Our MedicarePlus package, which is up in the Senate now, provides a safety net that is being refused support by the Labor Party. A commentator in the Daily Telegraph on 12 February, Sue Dunleavy, said that any type of safety net was `sorely needed'. If someone offered you a bag of lollies, would you say, `No, I am not taking it until you give me two bags'?

That is what the Senate is saying on the Medicare safety net. Some 170,000 sick and chronically ill Australians who will qualify for the $266 million safety net program are paying hundreds and sometimes thousands of dollars on medical bills with no help from Medicare and health funds. They would be happy with any money they could get to help with the bills. Labor, Democrat and Independent senators want the government to spend more money on health—that is great. However, they should not hold the chronically ill who will benefit from this safety net to ransom to get the extra money.

We need to address the situation in relation to doctors. We need doctors to feel comfortable in the community so that they can do what they do best, and that is to provide professional, quality health care to our communities. I look at the way the member for Hunter, the member for Lalor and all the other members on the other side carry on and complain. If they were seriously committed to health, they would firstly pass the Medicare safety package in the Senate. Secondly, they would hand back the $4 million this year. And the member for Hunter is on his feet again because he is embarrassed about the $4 million he is going to rip off from the taxpayers this year. (Quorum formed.) What has happened is that the member for Hunter is extremely embarrassed that he is one of many on that side who has his hand in the taxpayers' pocket for $4 million this year. That $4 million—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order that goes to relevance. The previous Deputy Speaker ruled on this matter on at least three occasions. In addition, I take offence at that reflection from the member for Paterson and I insist that he withdraw.

—Does the member for Hunter—

interjection.para: Government members interjecting—

—Mr Deputy Speaker, with respect to his reference to hands in the till, the member for Paterson has reflected not only on me but on all members on this side of the House, and I again ask you to require him to withdraw.
—Earlier today, the Deputy Speaker ruled that a collective reflection is not an abuse of the standing orders.

—With respect, Mr Deputy Speaker, if you care to reflect on the Hansard, it was quite clear that the member for Paterson referred to me individually and, of course, to all members on this side. I ask you to require him to withdraw.
—The member's time has expired.

—On the point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: the member said that the member for Hunter had his hand in the taxpayers' pocket. That is an offensive reflection on the member for Hunter, an individual reflection on the member for Hunter, and we insist that he be required to withdraw.

—Order! I have taken advice from the Clerk. I personally did not hear the comment and nor did the Clerk. However, does the member for Hunter feel that there has been a personal reflection against him?
—I certainly do, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—We will continue the debate. I will call the member for Rankin in a moment. In the meantime, we will ask the member for Paterson to return to the chamber and to withdraw the statement.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Under what standing order are we calling the member for Paterson back to the chamber?
—I have taken advice from the Clerk and it is perfectly within the standing orders to do so.
—On what basis is this ruling being made, Mr Deputy Speaker?
—A member should not leave the chamber while the Speaker or Deputy Speaker is in the middle of hearing a point of order against that particular member.
—Under what standing order is the member required to come back to the chamber, Mr Deputy Speaker?
—To that question, Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to standing order No. 77, which says:

quote.para: When any offensive or disorderly words are used, whether by a Member who is addressing the Chair or by a Member who is present, the Speaker shall intervene.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. If the House paid attention to the words used, I think that inadvertently the member for Paterson used the word `you'—`you have got your hand in the till'. If anybody should be paying attention to the member's words or asking him to withdraw, maybe it would be you.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, further to the point of order: the member for Mitchell was not even in the chamber when this incident took place, so why would he be intervening?
—I was so. Of course I was.
—There will not be a debate on this.

—It is highly disorderly and poor courtesy for the member for Paterson to leave the chamber while you are considering your ruling. And I suggest to the member for North Sydney that he not rise on a point of order if he has no clue what he is talking about.
—I thank the member for Hunter. I have given my ruling based on the advice from the Clerk. I call the member for Rankin in continuation on the debate.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker—and a very wise ruling, I might say. This legislation—the Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill 2004 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Amendment Bill 2004—is the third bandaid solution applied by the government to deal with the medical indemnity insurance crisis. The Minister for Health and Ageing has already indicated that there is another bandaid to come. It seems appropriate, as we are having a health debate, that the government is liberally using bandaids out of the packet. There are plenty more to come—and many have been applied already. It might be a little understandable if the government is using bandaids to deal with some of these health issues, but they are the most expensive bandaids that the people of Australia will ever see—
—And have to pay for.

—or have to pay for, as the member for Braddon has pointed out. I will refer to the cost of these bandaids—the most expensive packet of bandaids, which has run into hundreds of millions of dollars already. Indeed, these costs never needed to be incurred, because the problems of medical indemnity insurance were identified as early as the mid-1990s. Those problems were not only identified but also comprehensively documented in the Tito report. That report was delivered to the previous Labor government a fortnight before the calling of an election. You would think that the incoming coalition government would be grateful for all the work that had been conducted in preparing the Tito report and for the findings of that report. But, instead of utilising the report—instead of even reading the report—the then health minister, Dr Wooldridge, shelved it. He shelved it and boasted about it. He boasted about the fact that he did nothing in relation to solving the medical indemnity insurance crisis in this country.

speech.para: It is not unusual for Liberals to boast that they have done nothing. They have a born to rule mentality. I think many of them come into this parliament believing it is their right to be here—not to represent their constituents and certainly not to represent the people of Australia. The former health minister, Dr Wooldridge, speaking at a Melbourne university gathering in April 2003, said, `As minister I was accused of doing far too little on medical indemnity. That is completely unfair. I did absolutely nothing whatsoever.' What an indictment on a health minister—boasting that he did absolutely nothing to deal with the medical indemnity insurance crisis which was drawn to the attention of this government as an emerging crisis back in 1996. Instead of apologising to the Australian people for his failure to do anything about it and the fact that he put the Tito report on the shelf, he boasted about how he did nothing whatsoever. I remind members of the House that this was the same minister who, before the last election, was asked on Meet the Press, whether—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I understand you recalled me to the chamber.
(Mr Barresi)—Member for Paterson, it would have been very nice to have received you after the member for Rankin had completed his speech but, in light of the circumstances—

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. You did call me. I understand that I made a reflection when I said `you', which would have meant you in the chair had your hand in the till of the taxpayers. Mr Deputy Speaker, I meant all of the members on the Labor side. So I do withdraw the word `you' and correct my reflection to be `all of the members of the Labor Party'.
—No, you said, `the member for Hunter'.
—I suggest that the member for Paterson resume his seat and I suggest that he not leave the chamber.

—As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, it is a requirement of the standing orders that the member withdraw without qualification. I point out that he did use the term `member for Hunter' in the sentence which I found offensive.

—The member for Hunter believes that there was a personal reflection against him and that the term the `member for Hunter' was used during the member for Paterson's speech. The speech had gone on for a period of time. I had been fairly relaxed in my intervention prior to the quorum being called. I do ask the member for Paterson to withdraw the personal reflection against the member for Hunter.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, with all due respect—
—The member—

—Please hear my explanation, Mr Deputy Speaker. I used the member for Hunter's name a lot during the speech because he was constantly interjecting. Mr Deputy Speaker, I would prefer to see the Hansard green and see where I have made a reflection and then, if appropriate, come and withdraw that reflection at that point in time.

—Can I suggest to the member for Hunter, so that this does not become a sideshow—and it is rapidly declining—that I will ask for the transcript of the member for Paterson's speech and I will seek advice from the Speaker and the Clerk on this matter. I have no doubt that what the member for Hunter is saying is correct—I have no doubt about it. But, in order to expedite matters in the chamber, I would ask the member for Hunter to show a bit of flexibility in this regard.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. With the greatest respect, Mr Deputy Speaker, you have already ruled on this matter. You have asked the member for Paterson to withdraw. The standing orders provide that he do so without qualification. It does not really matter what the Hansard or the tapes show; I claim to have been offended by his remarks. You have already ruled that he withdraw, and he should do so immediately. There is no provision or facility for him to debate the issue. Two words: I withdraw.
—I understand that, member for Hunter.
—There will not be a debate on this, member for Paterson.
—I am just seeking advice. If the member for Hunter feels he has been misrepresented, would it be better to make a personal explanation?
—No.
—No, the Deputy Speaker has made a ruling.
—You have to withdraw.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, if they are so sensitive on that side, I withdraw.
—I understand the member for Paterson just withdrew his statement.
—Yes, that is correct.
—I do thank the member for Paterson for the withdrawal. Can we resume the debate?
—Unfortunately, not yet, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—I call the member for Lalor.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The member for Paterson has withdrawn the reflection he made against the member for Hunter. In the course of the exchange that has just happened, the member for Paterson thought that he could excuse that reflection by making the very same reflection against every member of the opposition. I draw your attention, Mr Deputy Speaker, to page 491 of House of Representatives Practice and particularly the rulings of Speaker Aston and Speaker Snedden, whose rulings were that, if there is a reflection relating to dishonesty—and this reflection was one relating to dishonesty—it cannot be excused because it is made against an unnamed set of members. The document states:

quote.para: For example, a statement that it would be unwise to entrust certain unnamed Members with classified information was required to be withdrawn, and Speaker Aston stated that exception would be taken to certain charges, the more obvious of which were those of sedition, treason, corruption or deliberate dishonesty. Speaker Snedden supported this practice—

interjection.para: and extended it—

quote.para: when he required the withdrawal of the term `a bunch of traitors' ...

interjection.para: A lengthy extract of Speaker Snedden's ruling is then reproduced. The allegation the member for Paterson made is an allegation of dishonesty. There can be no other construction of an allegation of receipt of taxpayers' funds. It was made against every member of the Labor Party. Under Speaker Snedden's ruling it cannot be excused by being applied to the generic class, and that additional matter should be withdrawn.

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Lalor for that very thorough explanation and revisiting of the standing orders going back a number of years. I will simply go back to today's question time, when Speaker Andrew made a ruling on a similar point of order. There is no point of order. However, I will take up the matter with Speaker Andrew. It no doubt is a point of order that needs to be discussed with the Speaker. If there is anything further to add to the House then I am sure that the Speaker or the Deputy Speaker will advise the House.
—On indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker. I simply want to point out that the member for Paterson's arrogance in intervening while the member for Rankin was on his feet has now cost the member for Rankin—
—There is no point of order. The member for Rankin will resume his speech.

—I have a ripper speech. I was pointing out that the former minister for health, Dr Wooldridge, not only boasted about his complete unwillingness to do anything about the medical indemnity insurance crisis but also told Meet the Press before the last election that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme was sustainable. He was asked in detail about the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. Obviously, the journalists in question were onto the caper that the government might pull the swiftie of saying that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme was sustainable before the election, only to come into the parliament after the election and increase the cost of pharmaceuticals to the working men and women of this country.

speech.para: Surprise, surprise—what did they do? Dr Wooldridge said that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme was sustainable. The government then came into parliament after the last election and did exactly what it was believed they might well do—the government put to this parliament a bill to increase pharmaceutical costs to Australian consumers. Of course, that is now a double dissolution bill. The moral of the story is: do not believe Dr Wooldridge. I might add that it calls into serious question his credentials as a health minister, just as this crisis calls into serious question the credentials of the current minister for health as a minister of the Crown.

The fact is that UMP collapsed, and it was a collapse that was waiting to happen. The government's first response to that collapse—a response not of anticipation but of reaction—was to apply the first bandaid, which was to pick up the unfunded liability of UMP and to get that money back through a levy called the IBNR levy—that is, liabilities incurred but not reported. Those levy notices, we may all remember, started arriving in August and September last year. The medical work force, in response to getting the shocking mail saying that they were up for thousands of dollars, withdrew from the work force, most particularly in New South Wales. Doctors in New South Wales began walking off the job because they got these shock notices from the government.

The government then had to respond to the crisis. What was its response? The Minister for Health and Ageing, who was new in the saddle, implemented an IBNR moratorium, the purpose of which—just as it was the purpose of the previous health minister—was to get the government past the next election. That is what this health minister tried to do. This is the Liberal way: do not fix something; just try to scrape past the next election. But the AMA were awake to the caper. They insisted on a more comprehensive solution, and therefore required the government to establish a review panel, which it did. Today's legislation is the first instalment in response to the recommendations of the review panel that was established.

Even the minister has conceded that the whole scheme that is being put in place through this particular bill and further bills to come will last for the grand total of two years. It is clear that doctors have done pretty well, because the Liberals have not wanted to create too much of a fuss with the AMA and the doctors. But the fact is that they should not trust this government. The cost to taxpayers has been $233 million plus another $120 million—a total of $353 million, which means that taxpayers have funded three-quarters of the UMP liability. Some $353 million has been allocated to deal with a crisis that the government could have prevented if, back in 1996, the then minister for health had read the report instead of putting it on the shelf and boasting later that he did absolutely nothing about it.

This is a crisis that could have been averted. Instead of averting it the government let it fester and fester and then applied three very expensive bandaids costing a total of $353 million. That is well over $100 million per bandaid. I hope they do not have a big box of them there, because at $100 million a go this is the most expensive box of bandaids the Australian people will ever have to buy. It is therefore worth asking within the health arena: to what alternative uses could this money have been applied? I have only another few minutes, but we could spend half an hour talking about the alternative uses of $353 million of taxpayers' money in the health arena.

I want to focus on one in particular, and that is the pneumococcal vaccine. The pneumococcal vaccine for all children would cost in the order of $100 million a year for this government to cover, but it is refusing to do so. It is saying that it will cover the cost of pneumococcal vaccine for those children who are at risk. I say that all children are at risk of pneumococcal disease. It is not widely known, but more children contract pneumococcal disease than meningococcal disease, and more children die of pneumococcal disease than of meningococcal disease.

An independent expert advisory committee that has been advising Australian governments for years on vaccines recommended that the government cover the cost of pneumococcal vaccine. The government's response? For the first time in the post-war era a government has said it will not cover the cost of a recommended vaccine for all children in Australia but rather that it will cover only selected children. It is an outrage that this government would put at risk the health and even the lives of children by refusing to cover pneumococcal vaccine costs. It means that parents are confronted with the cost of $435 for this vaccine. This is a disease that obviously can lead to death, but even those children who survive are often disabled through vision impairment, the impairment of hearing, delays in development and even the loss of fingers and toes through septicaemia.

This government, during or before the budget, should reverse its cold-hearted decision and fund the pneumococcal vaccine. In my own electorate of Rankin, 2,000 signatures have been gained on petitions which I have tabled, and more will be tabled in the future. Jill Leonarduzzi of Regents Park has been very active in obtaining these petitions. I pay tribute to Jill: she is the grandmother of a young girl who contracted this disease and has been severely disadvantaged. Fortunately she did not die, but she has been severely disadvantaged as a result of contracting this disease.
