It is not the Australian way for a government to refuse to implement the recommendations of its own advisory committee as to which vaccine should be made available free of charge for children in this country, but that is what this government has done.

It is a government that has very warped priorities in relation to health. It has presided over a collapse in bulk-billing around Australia. It will not do anything to arrest the decline in bulk-billing. It will not fund the pneumococcal vaccine. But I can give this commitment to the people of Rankin: I will continue to advocate strongly on their behalf—on behalf of the parents of Rankin and the parents of the children of Australia—for the funding of pneumococcal vaccine, because it is totally unacceptable that this cold-hearted government has refused to do so. It has now put itself in the position where it has had to cough up $353 million of taxpayers' money to try to deal with a crisis through bandaid solutions that it could have averted if the then minister for health back in 1996 had not been so bone lazy in ignoring the report that was available to him, in allowing a crisis to develop and then boasting about it. That minister was a disgrace and this current health minister wants to debate anything in this parliament other than health. That is how sincere they are about Medicare in this country. The Prime Minister said back in 1987 that he would take a scalpel to Medicare. He has been doing that in his eight years in the prime ministership, and at the next election we will throw him out so that the people of Australia can get decent, affordable health care.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak on the Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill 2004 and the cognate bill, the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Amendment Bill 2004. I listened with interest to some of the comments from the member for Rankin, and I have to say that he has not really explained the history of the worldwide crisis in the insurance sector which gave rise to the need for the government to step in and resolve this crisis. I believe the public are well served in our Minister for Health and Ageing having consulted widely and stepped in to avert what could have been a very serious crisis with implications for the public.

speech.para: We all know that there was a worldwide insurance crisis. That deepened after September 11 2001, and there was a knock-on effect that no government could have prevented. Prior to that the medical profession was running its own insurance system, and nobody could have predicted or foreseen those terrible events that had a very major impact on the whole insurance sector. Of course the affordability of insurance has become a very big headache for many professionals, but for the medical sector it has reached crisis point with the threatened collapse of United Medical Protection, which is the only medical defence organisation currently participating in the IBNR scheme.

One of the key areas of concern was the IBNR scheme, covering `incurred but not reported' liabilities—that of course is what `IBNR' stands for. The UMP support payment arrangements replace the IBNR contribution. I know that people in my electorate were greatly relieved that the government stepped in to strengthen the medical indemnity situation; without government intervention it might have been difficult to retain current levels of medical practitioners and medical services.

In both outer metropolitan areas and rural areas there has been an acute shortage of medical practitioners. The federal government's response to this—the rural and outer metropolitan doctor scheme, designed to provide incentives for doctors to locate to areas with a GP shortage—has begun to have a very positive impact, one which might have been negated by a crisis in the medical indemnity insurance industry. Undoubtedly there would have been wider ramifications if the government had not acted, so I think the member for Rankin is quite wrong; I think the Australian public expected the government to do something about this, and if that was the way in which we maintained a high level of medical service to our communities then that was money well spent.

In addition to incentives for doctors to locate to areas outside the inner metropolitan area, the government have made provision for additional university places in faculties of medicine. This will, along with the short-term measures that the government have taken, ensure a long-term easing of the current GP shortage. We certainly did not need to add to those difficulties by not responding to the medical insurance crisis.

There were a number of reasons for the crisis in medical insurance, as I said. While there has been a tendency for public debate to focus on blame and counterblame, the fact is that the court decisions awarding very large payouts for events that occurred decades ago were one of the major concerns regarding the viability of medical indemnity schemes, increasing premiums and making medical insurance unaffordable for GPs. So, while there were a number of reasons why this crisis occurred, that was certainly one of the factors.

It is of vital concern to the public that medical indemnity insurance remains affordable for doctors so that they can continue to provide medical services. This bill gives legislative effect to the government's new medical indemnity measures, building on past measures. In 2002-03 the government legislated to provide a secure prudential and financial framework for the medical indemnity industry and for doctors.

Elements of the government's response to the medical insurance crisis included: introducing a single billing arrangement for doctors so that they can receive one bill from their medical indemnity provider, which certainly helps to simplify things; linking the UMP support payment to the doctors' capacity to pay, making these payments more affordable for doctors; bringing medical indemnity cover under the supervision of the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority; ensuring that cover is available through general insurers under contracts of insurance, providing certainty of cover for doctors; and a $181 million investment by the government between now and 2006-07 to ensure affordability of medical indemnity insurance for doctors.

The government's response also included: underpinning the UMP's unfunded incurred but not reported liabilities—that is, the IBNR claims—and removing the very real threat of permanent liquidation for UMP; funding half the cost of all claims in excess of a $500,000 threshold through the High Cost Claims Scheme, limiting the financial pressure on doctors' premiums; removing the element of personal liability for the amount of any claim which exceeds their level of insurance provided they have $20 million worth of cover under the Exceptional Claims Scheme; the provision of direct financial assistance to obstetricians and neurosurgeons; working closely with state and territory governments in pursuing tort law reforms to reduce the volume and cost of claims against doctors; establishing the Medical Indemnity Policy Review Panel; and introducing a moratorium on the IBNR contributions, capping them at $1,000 per annum for 18 months to December 2004.

The Medical Indemnity Policy Review Panel played a very important role in advising the government on the issues around insurance. The government have adopted some of the panel's recommendations, including: reducing the High Cost Claims Scheme threshold further, to $300,000, and introducing a new, broader based Premium Support Scheme to replace the Medical Indemnity Subsidy Scheme. Under the Premium Support Scheme more doctors will be assisted with their medical indemnity costs than under the medical indemnity scheme. Further panel recommendations adopted by the government include replacing the IBNR levy with UMP support arrangements and establishing a run-off reinsurance vehicle to provide free run-off cover to certain groups of doctors when they have left the medical work force. I think it has been demonstrated that this government have acted decisively, quickly and responsibly to manage a very difficult issue—the increasing cost, uncertainty and adequacy of medical indemnity insurance.

This bill gives legislative effect to the new UMP support payment arrangements and provides a broad framework for the Premium Support Scheme. The Premium Support Scheme will replace current subsidy arrangements that will continue to operate until 30 June 2004. It will cover 80 per cent of the medical indemnity costs incurred over a 7.5 per cent threshold. It will also provide increased support for procedural GPs working in rural areas. That is certainly important in an electorate like Pearce, which has very large rural community. We do have some extremely capable and good doctors in our wheat belt. In fact, some of those have come to the area as a result of the government's incentive scheme for rural doctors. To lose them because the government failed to act on such an important issue as medical indemnity insurance would not have served the people in the rural areas of my electorate.

I am in close touch with the Central Wheatbelt Division of General Practice, and they do a mighty job in providing member doctors to look at the range of health issues across the electorate, ensuring that there is a comprehensive medical and health service available to people living in those areas and regions. I have had the privilege of working with the two chairs: Dr Gogna, who came in as an overseas trained doctor and who has really endeared himself to many in the community and who has worked very hard to improve and move forward medical issues and medical health provision within the rural sector; and the now chair, Dr Frank Kubicek. Under him, that consultative process continues.

Our minister is always very responsive to the suggestions and ideas of these doctors. To have ignored this problem of medical indemnity would have caused endless difficulties for doctors working in rural areas, and I am glad to see that the provisions of this legislation take into account some of those rural area issues. The minister has foreshadowed further legislation to implement the run-off reinsurance vehicle, and this scheme is being developed in consultation with the medical profession and the insurance industry.

Success in reducing medical claims in future will depend on the cooperation of medical practitioners, who will need to continue to improve their own risk management in their individual practices. That is obviously a very important factor in ensuring that the premiums do not blow out further and in being able to manage the medical insurance issue in the longer term. I know our minister is working very closely with the sector to ensure that all of these features are taken into account in the design of the system.

Designing a medical indemnity scheme that provides a fair outcome for litigants and reasonable insurance premiums for doctors and the maintenance of medical services at a level the public have come to expect does require a very comprehensive and consultative approach. I believe that our minister for health has approached this issue with great determination and with a willingness to consult with all those within the sector. The government has, with the minister's guidance, been able to avert what may have been a very serious crisis in the provision of medical services.

Rather than condemn the government, I think the member for Rankin should be thankful that his constituents will continue to receive a high level of medical care from our practitioners because we have resolved the problems with the medical indemnity insurance system. As I said, this worked very successfully over a number of years with the medical profession running its own insurance system. It was not appropriate for governments to intervene in those circumstances.

But there are circumstances beyond the control of medical practitioners and beyond the control of the government. Because of those circumstances, it has been necessary for the government to step in, to be responsive, to go through the consultative process and to ensure the funding is there to provide to the Australian public a system with a level of medical care that the public have come to expect. I commend and congratulate our minister for the work he and his department have done to ensure that we can continue to have good medical services. I support the bills.

talk.start.para: —I believe I could be forgiven for thinking I am going to be talking about a totally different scenario to the one that the previous member was talking about. I am dismayed that I find myself yet again returning to this House to speak on legislation dealing with medical indemnity insurance because this government has mishandled the medical indemnity insurance issue.
—Then why don't you pass the vote? What are you doing?
—I hear the minister on the other side of the House joining with me and expressing his concerns at the way the government has handled this issue and putting on record—

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. If the member wants to make a claim about me she can move a substantive motion. Otherwise, her assertion is totally incorrect and I ask her to withdraw it.
(Mr Barresi)—I did not hear the member's comments at all. The member for Shortland will return to the bills.

—I am actually talking to the Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill 2004 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Amendment Bill 2004, and I in no way reflected on the character of the minister. Rather, I reflected on the legislation that we have before us here and the abject failure of this government to resolve the issue. Even this legislation is not the last word on medical indemnity insurance within this House. This government threw our health system into chaos with its failure to act to resolve the medical indemnity crisis. The Howard government, through a series of health ministers, did nothing as the crisis in medical indemnity went from bad to worse and then to a situation where the entire health system was verging on collapse. It created a situation of uncertainty for everybody: uncertainty for the doctors, uncertainty for Australian families and uncertainty for the health system—which the Howard government brought to the brink of collapse.

speech.para: It is important to note that the one thing that is really important for a health system is that the people of the nation can have faith in it. It is important for the patients to have certainty that the system will deliver to them, and it is important for the doctors to have certainty that they will be covered for medical indemnity insurance. This government have handled the situation very badly. They have grossly mishandled it, I have to say, and they have demonstrated to us on this side of the House and to the Australian people just how incompetent they are when it comes to matters of health care and providing health services and certainty to the Australian people.

Within the area that I represent in this parliament, the Central Coast of New South Wales, 11 doctors resigned because of the uncertainty created by this government. At least one of those doctors has not returned, and this has created quite a void in services on the Central Coast. Furthermore, doctors have been so intimidated by the medical indemnity insurance situation and frightened about their ability to cover the extra costs it has imposed on them that they have been forced into charging additional fees—which places health care outside the financial ability of many Australians.

I think I should go through some of the background to this legislation and some of the bungling that has taken place in relation to it. I want to share with the House the feelings of doctors and people in the area that I represent. In November 2001, UMP collapsed, and it had an estimated liability of $460 million. That was incurred liability, not purported. The government agreed to take responsibility for UMP's IBNR liabilities. The cost of the bailout was to be passed on directly to UMP members and former members by the now infamous IBNR levy. It is important to note here that in New South Wales the majority of doctors were insured with UMP, so that had a bigger impact in New South Wales. As members would be aware, that is where the electorate of Shortland is.

The Howard government put in place a plan. We are always hearing about `a plan' or `a new approach'—`We'll get it right this time.' They put in place a plan to recoup $580 million over 10 years from doctors who were members of UMP as at 30 June 2000. That led to the mass resignation of doctors in August and September last year when they received their IBNR levy notices. The levies were extraordinarily high and made the ongoing practice of medicine unviable for doctors in many areas.

talk.start.para: —Because of your laws!

—I am sure the minister would be most grateful for the action taken by the New South Wales government, because the New South Wales government were responsible for acting initially and saving the system in New South Wales. The New South Wales government acted while the minister and the Howard government sat on their hands and did nothing. As I was saying, when doctors received their notices it led to mass resignations in New South Wales, particularly on the central coast of New South Wales, the area that I represent in this parliament; and nothing the minister can say will change that fact. That situation was badly handled and it still leaves a lot to be desired, Minister. I have mentioned briefly that New South Wales tort law reform did a lot to resolve the problem in that state; they acted quickly.
—Why won't you pass them in the Senate?

—I notice how loudly those on the other side of the House protest. That they protest so loudly really indicates to me that they are very sensitive about the fact that the New South Wales government brought in tort law reform way ahead of this government doing so. I have been watching this debate and I can see how sensitive they are on that side of this House. It is because they know they have failed the Australian people time and time again.
—You're a bad joke.

—Mr Deputy Speaker Barresi, I think that the minister's comments are anything but parliamentary and that he does not know the rules of debate. Turning to the legislation that is before us today, we on this side of the House will be supporting it. This legislation has resulted from the last attempt by the Howard government to put together the Medical Indemnity Policy Review Panel. That panel came out with recommendations which have been encompassed within this legislation. The recommendation that deals with highcost claim schemes will cost $11 million for 200405, but it will add certainty and will help doctors who have been left feeling very uncertain and out on a limb by this government.

speech.para: This legislation also puts in place a recommendation to deal with claims made against doctors who are retired, on maternity leave or permanently out of the work force. It also puts in place new premium support arrangements, which will benefit doctors. Its cost for the year 2004-05 is $24 million. However, the thing that really concerns me about this legislation is that this will not be the final time that we debate it. We will be back here again after the next election, looking at further legislation that will need to be brought in to make this ongoing.

talk.start.para: —You will still be in opposition.

—Mr Deputy Speaker Adams, government members constantly interject whilst I am speaking about this legislation—and I know and understand fully why: it is because their performance in relation to medical indemnity insurance has been appalling. They have been abject failures in resolving this issue. All they have done is create uncertainty for doctors and for Australian families. It really is an indictment on their performance as a government. The Australian people know just how poor their performance has been in the area of medical indemnity insurance and in health generally.

speech.para: I will quickly turn to some of the problems that have been experienced within my own electorate of Shortland. One of the local hospitals—Belmont Hospital, a fine hospital—within the electorate has been placed in a situation where it has had to consider the ongoing viability of providing maternity services. This is directly related to the issue of medical indemnity insurance. The government's inaction has created a situation where there is quite a chronic shortage of anaesthetists within the Hunter, to the extent that anaesthetists have even been flown from South Africa on a rotating basis to make up the shortfall within the local area.

Doctors are frightened about taking on the more dangerous specialities, and this legislation deals with and addresses that to a large extent. But there has been so much angst and heartache within the community caused by the inaction of the government. One specialist who lives within the Shortland electorate has spent a lot of time detailing to me the weakness of the government's approach. This specialist is a Liberal voter. He has come to me and said that, because of the way the government have handled this issue, he will be thinking twice about voting for them.

This has been a problem for GPs too. They have felt very uncertain about the handling of the issue and about their futures. If there is one thing that people involved in the health system need—be they doctors or health service providers—it is certainty. Under this government, we have had a regime that works on disaster and crisis management. That has been their approach to medical indemnity insurance and, for that matter, to all matters relating to health. They have overseen a collapse in bulk-billing in Australia. Bulk-billing has declined by an enormous rate. In the Shortland electorate, since 2002 bulk-billing has declined from over 78 per cent to 51.3 per cent. In the adjoining electorate of Dobell, bulk-billing has declined from 83.4 per cent to 58.2 per cent.

These figures represent real hardship to the people that I represent in this parliament. These figures show that people can no longer go along to their doctors and expect them to bulk-bill. The average difference between a doctor's fee and the rebate for people living in the area I represent in this parliament is $7 to $13. In some cases it is more. I have heard of an example of one medical practice within the Shortland electorate that has taken to charging an extra $5 for Saturdays, and I know that many practices charge after-hours fees. This is all making it less and less affordable for people to go and see a doctor when they need to.

I am absolutely disgusted with the government's refusal to release quarterly bulk-billing rates. I have been able to track the decline in bulk-billing in the Shortland electorate. Since 1998 bulk-billing has been declining in Shortland. Since this government came to power, they have pursued the destruction of Medicare, and that has manifested itself in the decline in bulk-billing.

talk.start.para: —Rubbish!

—Nothing any member on the other side of this House can say will change that fact. And now the health minister is refusing to release the quarterly bulk-billing rates. The next lot of bulk-billing rates we will receive as members of parliament—as people representing our electorates—are the figures that will be released after the next election. That is not good enough, and I am going to make sure everyone in the electorate that I represent, the electorate of Shortland, is aware of the massive cover-up by the government.

speech.para: Over the last two years there has been a constant upward movement—a 15 per cent increase—in health insurance premiums. This year we are going to be faced with an average increase of 7.5 per cent. Whilst at my local shopping centre last Saturday, I had people coming up to me who had already made calculations as to whether or not they could afford to maintain their health insurance. Overwhelmingly people were saying that they can no longer afford it. They were very upset; they felt that they had been duped by the Howard government. The Prime Minister promised the Australian people lower health insurance premium rates and he has not delivered on that promise.

We have the 30 per cent private health insurance rebate and we have government members of a Senate committee suggesting that maybe we should move to 40 per cent. This money is going directly into the pockets of big business, into the health insurance industry. The people of Australia want not only affordable private health insurance rates but also treatment in a private hospital without having to pay the enormous gap. One gentleman I spoke to at the local shopping centre had to pay $1,827 for an anaesthetist. He received approximately $570 back from Medicare and approximately another $160 from his private health insurance company, leaving him out of pocket by over $1,000. This is hardly a system that is working for the average Australian person.

The Howard government is destroying the health system. Little by little it is undermining the confidence Australians have in our health system—be it the doctors' confidence that they will be able to afford medical indemnity insurance or that the medical indemnity insurance they have is sustainable, or be it in the patients' confidence that they will be adequately covered by the medical insurance of the day.

Australians lack confidence in the government's ability to ensure that bulk-billing will survive and in the Howard government's ability to ensure affordable private health insurance. The Howard government stands condemned for its failure on medical indemnity insurance and its failure to preserve the health system in Australia.

talk.start.para: —Once again I find myself following the member for Shortland and, once again, I am amazed at the utter hypocrisy of members of the opposition. In particular, it is most concerning that the ALP member who preceded me in this debate, the member for Shortland, talked about taxpayers' money going into the pockets of big business.

speech.para: To put it in context, the comment was made in light of the fact that the Howard government has given an ironclad commitment to provide all Australians with a 30 per cent rebate on private health insurance, a rebate that the Labor Party has refused to support, a rebate that the Labor Party, I am sure, will completely get rid of, and we will see private health insurance rise overnight by 30 per cent. Approximately 48 or 49 per cent of people in my electorate of Moncrieff have private medical insurance and are able to rely upon the private medical system and, in doing so, take the burden off the public hospital system—

talk.start.para: —How are their premiums going?
—something that the Labor Party completely ignores.
—Are premiums going up?

—Those opposite interject about private health insurance premiums going up. Let me assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that if there is one thing increasing faster than private health insurance premiums it is the Centenary House rent rort that opposition members are engaging in.
(Hon. D.G.H. Adams)—Order! I ask the honourable member to direct his remarks to the bills before the House.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I ask for the same courtesy that was extended to the member for Shortland. She was heard in silence.
—There is no point of order.
—I ask the honourable member for Shortland to resist the temptation to interject and I ask the honourable member for Moncrieff to direct his comments to the bills before the House.

—My comments are relevant to the bill. The previous speaker commented about the use of taxpayers' funds. The opposition claims that taxpayers' funds are misused when they go into the health system because this government supports not only the public system but also the private system. The comments I make about the best utilisation of taxpayers' funds pertain directly to the health system. The member for Paterson, who spoke in this debate, most ably pointed out that taxpayers' funds could be best used by going into the health system.

speech.para: It is a great shame that Labor members are prepared to stand by and watch the rort of Centenary House, the complete exploitation of taxpayers' funds on Centenary House, at the expense of the health system. A prime example of hypocrisy is when members of the opposition come into the chamber and feign concern about the most effective use of taxpayers' funds.

If the member for Shortland and other members opposite, such as the member for Lingiari, were genuinely concerned about the most effective use of taxpayers' funds, they would stop the Centenary House rort. The member for Paterson stated that the additional funds that flow to the Labor Party as a consequence of this rent rort in Centenary House would fund some 20 extra doctors. There are many ways in which the Australian public health system could be improved if the Labor Party put aside the scheme that is currently operating in respect of Centenary House and their fake concern with private health insurance premiums increasing and dealt with the issue at hand. We could put more taxpayer dollars into making sure that we continue to operate a world class health system if we did not have to waste money on propping up the Australian Labor Party through the Centenary House rort.

The bills before the House today, the Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill 2004 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Amendment Bill 2003, go to the core of ensuring that our health system continues to operate effectively. These bills demonstrate the way in which the Howard government has responded to the problems that have arisen in the past several years with regard to medical indemnity. The problems that arose with medical indemnity were not foreseen on the radar. They arose, unfortunately, as a consequence of the collapse of UMP and of changes in the insurance marketplace. Some very significant payouts have been made against doctors to patients because of doctors' negligence. Many of these problems have arisen because Australian society has become more litigious.

The bills currently before the House try to stem some of the haemorrhaging that has been occurring in this sector as a consequence of these very large payouts. The reality is that there are many examples in which doctors have been placed on the back foot as a result of their MDOs—medical defence organisations—trying to respond to the various pressures that are now arising in the private medical protection insurance industry. The bills currently before the House have two key purposes. They are to make amendments to the `incurred but not reported' indemnity scheme, which was legislated for in the Medical Indemnity Act 2002. In the short-term, these amendments will ensure that the financial burden placed on doctors, under the IBNR scheme, will be lessened. The bills also put in place arrangements for what was formerly known as the blue sky scheme, which is now called the exceptional claims scheme.

With respect to the background of the medical indemnity problems, I highlight that the provision of medical indemnity to cover doctors in Australia has really had problems since early 2002. These problems effectively contain three key elements. The first, as I mentioned, was the collapse of the MDO UMP—which is also Australian Medical Insurance Limited—in May 2002. Prior to entering into liquidation, UMP, or AMIL, provided indemnity to approximately 60 per cent of medical practitioners nationally. On 14 November 2003 the Supreme Court of New South Wales released UMP/AMIL from provisional liquidation, thereby enabling the business to go back into normal operation.

The second key element is the fact that MDOs have not, in the past, made sufficient provision for `incurred but not reported' claims. It has historically been the case that MDOs provided their members with `claims incurred' cover. Under a `claims incurred' policy, doctors were insured against injuries to patients brought about through conduct which took place during the term of the policy. Patients' claims could be notified to the MDO at any time—for example, during the term of the policy or once the policy had lapsed; that could be a period of up to five years after the policy had lapsed. Also, incidents which occurred during the term of the policy gave rise to claims that were reported to the MDO after the policy had lapsed. These are referred to as `incurred but not reported' claims. The third element of the problems that have arisen in the medical indemnity industry is the significant increases in medical indemnity premiums for doctors. These have largely been a consequence of the significant payouts that have arisen as a consequence of our more litigious society.

The government has put in place a range of measures to address the medical indemnity problems. These include: the Commonwealth acting as a guarantor for claims arising out of medical procedures provided by doctors covered by UMP and AMIL; Commonwealth funding for the IBNRs of doctors that were members of MDOs as at 30 June 2002, where the IBNRs were unfunded—to date, the only MDO that is regarded as having had unfunded IBNRs is, of course, UMP, or AMIL; Commonwealth reimbursement to providers of medical indemnity insurance of 50 per cent of insurance payouts that exceed $500,000, where the incident has been notified on or after 1 January 2003—that is, the exceptional claims scheme; premium subsidies to obstetricians, neurosurgeons and procedural general practitioners who undertake Medicare billable procedures; and, finally, measures to ensure that providers of medical indemnity insurance are subject to the same prudential regulatory requirements as other general insurers and this includes prudential supervision by the Australian Prudential Regulatory Authority. These are the ways in which the government has been proactive in providing a solution to a problem which was not of our making but which this government has been called upon to solve.

I was recently fortunate enough to have the Minister for Health and Ageing, the Hon. Tony Abbott, visit my electorate of Moncrieff. On this occasion, I made sure that the health minister had the opportunity to sit down face to face with a number of the Gold Coast's leading doctors to discuss the various problems that have arisen in the industry. I know that as a consequence of these discussions the doctors are more fully informed about what this government is doing to solve the problem. In addition, the doctors were also provided with a first-hand opportunity to put their thoughts directly to the minister. The reality is that this government's response to the medical indemnity problem has been founded on consultation with industry. The response has been good—it has been the response that the industry has called for—but, more importantly, it has been a bipartisan response between the federal coalition government and the various state Labor governments. The reality is that many aspects of reform continue to be made. We need to ensure that there are legislative changes as we grow accustomed to the continuing changes that are occurring with respect to medical indemnity. Having said that, this is yet another piece of the puzzle in which this government has undertaken to ensure that we solve many of the problems with respect to medical indemnity. I commend these bills to the House and urge the Labor Party to support them.

talk.start.para: —There is no doubt that we need to provide for our medical practitioners the medical indemnity cover that the Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill 2004 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Amendment Bill 2004 promise. Already, our medical practitioners and the provision of medical services to ordinary Australians have been stretched to a point that spells crisis for the long-term wellbeing of our health system. In regional and rural areas like Calare, it is already nigh impossible for many people to either afford or access some specialists, especially if they already experience the disadvantages of having little money or no transport and the daily burden of pain or failing health. I am not here to defend some specialists over issues like gap payments in private hospitals, but I will defend them very strongly on this indemnity issue. Already, in regional and rural areas such as Calare, services provided by medical specialists are stretched and any disincentive to continue practice, such as the recent IBNR fiasco, could be devastating for rural health services.

speech.para: The likelihood of a litigious action looming out of left field many years after retirement is obviously a huge disincentive to specialists continuing practice. In many cases they are nearing the age of retirement and some are tempted to take the wiser option, if you like, of an early retirement. It is going to cost rural communities dearly if indeed they take that path and we have not put in place measures to ensure that they are not unfairly sued at a later date.

In May 2002, despite warning signs years earlier, Australia's main medical defence organisation went into liquidation, leaving some 60 per cent of Australia's medical practitioners, most of whom are in New South Wales, without medical indemnity cover. The lower premiums that had been achieved by taking into account only declared and reported claims left bone-dry a well of reserves to pay for the yet to be claimed liabilities. And of course as time went on those unclaimed liabilities mounted until the tail came back to sting the profession, and doctors and specialists were suddenly left with no cover.

Last year, faced with the urgent prospect of doctors and specialists having no choice but to walk away from their professions because they did not have cover, this House passed the Medical Indemnity Act 2002 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Act 2002 to avert the crisis. Under those pieces of legislation the government had to indemnify the sinking medical defence organisation UMP for some $460 million worth of unfunded incurred but not reported claims. This allowed UMP to shake off liquidation and to fund those IBNRs of doctors who had paid for that cover at 30 June 2000. An undertaking was made to reimburse medical indemnity insurance providers 50 per cent of insurance payouts that exceed $500,000, where the incident has been notified on or after 1 January last year under the new High Cost Claims Scheme. Subsidies were promised to offset those already exorbitant premiums for obstetricians, neurosurgeons and procedural general practitioners who undertake Medicare billable procedures. Finally, medical indemnity insurers were also to be brought under the same prudential regulatory umbrella as other general insurers. This includes the prudential supervision by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority.

This is all very well, and in order to pay for this urgently needed fix a large part of the indemnity covered by government would be recouped through a levy imposed on the members of the MDO. In essence, this levy could almost be seen as a retrospective payment of the amount of insurance that government should have ensured was being paid in the first place. The levy was worked out as equalling but not exceeding 50 per cent of the member's annual subscription for the 2000 financial year and it was deemed that this levy would be paid for 10 years. But for a profession that can pay premiums of up to $70,000 a year and more and for those GPs whose costs in running a practice are not recognised in the totally inadequate Medicare rebate they receive another 50 per cent on top of that premium for the next 10 years was a huge incentive to walk away from the profession. Not surprisingly, the solution offered was seen as a piece of quackery, a bandaid solution that the profession rejected.

Again Australia faced a continuing crisis, one among many crises our declining health system seems still to be facing. These bills put in place a number of measures to enable MDOs to afford the cost of those medical insurance payouts, to extend subsidies towards the cost of rising medical indemnity premiums across all specialties, to replace the unpopular IBNR levy with a UMP support arrangement and to provide cover for certain groups of doctors who have left the work force. So from July 2004, while the levy and terms of the moratorium still apply, there are changes to the IBNR levy and its place in the framework within this new Premium Support Scheme. At the conclusion of the moratorium on 31 December, at the end of this year, doctors who do not qualify for exemption from payment of the levy will pay the lesser of their original IBNR bill, two per cent of gross Medicare billable income or $5,000. Eligible doctors will only pay a contribution for the length of their membership of UMP, with a minimum of one year, and will pay no contribution beyond the 2008-09 financial year. They will not have to pay any contribution if they earned less than $5,000 in Medicare billable income in the previous year. There are also a number of available exemptions from the payment.

The new Premium Support Scheme will cover 80 per cent of a doctor's medical indemnity costs that exceed 7.5 per cent of their gross medical income. These costs include the cost of premiums, the IBNR and the run-off cover to be offered. Doctors will not have to jump through administrative hoops to apply for the PSS, as it will be provided directly through the insurer. From 1 January this year, subsidies for procedural GPs performing Medicare billable procedures in rural, remote and metropolitan area classifications 3 to 7 will be increased from 50 to 75 per cent of the difference between the cost of their premiums and the premiums of non-procedural GPs. This will certainly help doctors in my electorate of Calare and indeed throughout the country, particularly in regional areas with their higher costs and workloads. The high cost scheme will now reimburse MDOs 50 per cent of an insurance payout over $300,000, previously $500,000, and up to the limit of a practitioner's insurance.

These bills go a long way to addressing the immediate concerns of the affordability of premiums and security for our medics. I note that the Australian Medical Association cautiously welcomes the package. But we must remember that the cost of this to the taxpayer will be $181 million and there are no long-term guarantees. It is big ask of the Australian taxpayer, and I really do question the long-term viability of the Australian medical indemnity system. While the package provides for greater regulation and control of medical defence organisations, the bottom line is that our medical indemnity system, like our public liability system, remains in the hands of the marketplace. Still the provision of our health care and the activities of our communities remain at the behest of insurance providers, and the provision of profits and the vagaries of the marketplace dictate the security of our health carers and our community activities.

Any solution that does not address the shaky framework on which our protection from litigation hangs remains at best a loosely applied bandaid, likely to peel off under the constant pressure of litigation, rises in the cost of living and litigation legal costs. We still have seriously injured people who are not guaranteed the compensation that will cover their needs, because they must prove someone else is at fault. We still have those who do not have the money to chase compensation and those whose legal and medical fees or lack of financial training have eroded the money desperately needed to provide their care for the rest of their lives. We still have young, catastrophically injured people being parked in the first aged care facility that will take them, because the money is not there to pay for them to be cared for in their home or the facilities do not exist for young people in this condition. And still we have people receiving huge payouts for their terrible injuries, but with the emphasis on `payout' rather than provision—provision of suitable rehab, provision of proper respite care, provision of staged rather than lump sum payments and provision of victim oriented service—with no provisions for where those vast sums of money go should the injured die soon after the payout.

Over two years ago I stood here and argued that to ensure the long-term health and security of those injured or those sued for perceived fault and to ensure the wellbeing of our communities, the Commonwealth must take responsibility away from the profit driven marketplace in this of all areas of public need. The talkfests continue as to how we drive down insurance premiums and how we best provide for public liability, and we see in the ACCC's recently released second monitoring report that public liability premiums continue to rise, despite the modifications, caps and tort law reform that have been mentioned elsewhere in this debate. So we must ask: what will happen with medical insurance?

I continue to wonder, as I have for the past couple of years, at the lack of scrutiny directed at the insurance industry itself and its crucial role in this insurance crisis. With the idea of a long-term, no-fault scheme providing lifelong care for people with catastrophic injuries being promoted again by the likes of the AMA and Premier Bob Carr, I again argue, as I have for two years, for the Commonwealth to seriously consider the New Zealand accident compensation scheme as a possible solution. This scheme provides accident insurance for all New Zealand citizens and residents and temporary visitors to New Zealand. It is now run on a fully funded basis, and its unfunded liability, which accumulated under its previous pay-as-you-go basis—which, as I understand it, incidentally, was outsourced to private industry—has been reduced consistently through the payment of separate levies charged to fund those IBNRs in the same way the medical indemnity levy discussed previously was designed to do here in Australia. Under this scheme, all New Zealanders pay a small premium into one of seven accounts, with the government funding the costs of injuries to people who are not in the paid work force. The scheme provides cover for injuries, no matter who is at fault. However, importantly, it leaves open the right to sue for criminal negligence. It provides for the cost of the consequences for those injuries, such as home and vehicle modification, counselling, job retraining et cetera.

Recently in the Evans shire there was a case which resulted in a huge payout of $16 million to a road accident victim. That victim has sadly passed away, and it raises the question: to what purpose is the balance of that money applied? Surely it is not for the benefit of anyone in terms of medical protection or rehabilitation. How much better could we use the money that is provided through those sources for proper rehabilitation facilities, care facilities, respite care and so on, so that we have enough nurses out there in the community to care for these people, rather than an excessive payment, half of which seems to be skimmed off for the legal fraternity and—

talk.start.para: —Making rich relations.

—`Making rich relations', I hear the member say. I am not accusing anyone of being made rich by the process that happened in my electorate. I do not know the circumstances. But it certainly does raise the question of where the balance of this money goes and for what purpose.

speech.para: I believe the New Zealand scheme eliminates the slow, costly and wasteful processes of using the courts for each injury. It provides timely care and rehabilitation, and it minimises personal financial loss by paying weekly earnings compensation. Why can we not look at this model? There is nothing in the Constitution preventing the Commonwealth from dealing with premiums for any Commonwealth insurance schemes. It would seem that federal legislation is not only possible, but desirable. Doctors and others I speak with all over my electorate and elsewhere strongly support such a scheme, but it seems a government dominated by lawyers will not countenance such a scheme. I wonder why?

An injury compensation scheme would deal with injuries and the consequences thereof. It would remove the courts and the need to prove fault to ensure that an injured person's needs are met for as long as necessary. A scheme such as this would separate the issues of compensation for injury from the issues of criminal, seriously negligent or deceptive conduct. Those issues would continue to be dealt with in a legal setting. I cannot see a more reasonable or logical process than that—except I suspect that there is a sense within this government that it is akin to something like socialised insurance or that there are some strange ideological feelings that we would be going back down a path of government intervention in the marketplace. Well, government intervention in the marketplace for the good of all and the targeting and effective use of resources is what we should be about—not getting hung up on some government involvement in providing the sort of services that most fair-minded people demand.

I support the bill but agree with at least part of the opposition's second reading amendment; that this legislation is no longterm solution. We will be visiting it again and again in catch-up legislation as the years go by—an expensive option at $180 million a pop, as this bill represents. It can only achieve the desired result through a no-fault scheme that circumvents the legal system, allowing of course the criminal negligence cases. As for the recurring theme in this debate of the Centenary House rort—which I expect to hear of in every debate as we head into the election—I would be very wary, if I were a government or opposition member, of using the abuse of public funds as an election-year weapon. The public are not mugs.

talk.start.para: —I note the comments of the member of Calare on the importance of the insurance system providing for care and that a large payout is not always going to result in appropriate care. Appropriate care is what we should be focusing on in this very difficult issue of medical indemnity insurance. The fact that a person can receive a very large payout and regrettably pass away after a short period of time raises questions as to the appropriateness of that payout to the needs of the person. And it is the needs of the person that should always be paramount in the medical indemnity debate.

speech.para: The Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill 2004 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Amendment Bill 2004 are government measures to tackle problems in the medical indemnity insurance market. They follow the recommendations which were made by the Medical Indemnity Policy Review Panel in December last year. The panel adopted a cooperative approach to the problem and brought together key stakeholders including government, medical and legal professionals. It comprised the Minister for Health and Ageing; Senator Coonan; John Phillips, former Reserve Bank Deputy Governor; Nancy Milne, an insurance law specialist from Clayton Utz; Dr Bill Glasson, the AMA president; Dr Andrew Pesce of the AMA; Professor Don Sheldon of the Council of Procedural Specialists; and Dr Sue Page of the Rural Doctors Association.

The measures are welcomed by the Australian Medical Association. Dr Glasson, the association's president, said that the issues of affordability and security have been addressed by these measures. The medical indemnity insurance problem has been of great significance to the community and of great concern to the medical profession, much in the way that public liability has been of great concern to the wider community. In days gone past, when you went into business or launched a career in medicine, the issue of insurance was not foremost in your mind as you embarked on a career. But, regrettably, these days any aspiring doctor, professional or businessperson has to contend with the very real prospect of very large insurance premiums when they commence their business. Many people have left their businesses or professions as a result of these high insurance premiums, and many community groups have been forced to cancel functions and events as a result of the continuingly high insurance premiums.

The reality is that society is becoming more litigious. This is both the perception we get from reports about massive compensation payouts for claims which seem somewhat unwarranted, and also the reality of the fact that insurance premiums are rising rapidly as businesses guard against being sued. It is an important fact to note that it is the community as a whole that bears the cost of litigation. Doctors and other professionals, community groups and businesses pay for it through premiums. The government pays for it, which means the taxpayer is paying for it. The consumer pays for it by way of increased fees and charges which businesses have to levy in order to make a profit.

I believe the ability of lawyers to advertise has exacerbated the problem. There is an aggressive pursuit of plaintiff business by some law firms and practitioners. I believe the `no win, no fee' arrangement and aggressive, unsolicited marketing techniques have created the perception that there are gains to be made out there by people going through litigation. It does not help the standing of the legal profession, nor does it really assist genuine claimants who have genuine causes of action and are seeking recourse. I am pleased that in New South Wales this type of advertising has recently been restricted, and I hope that that trend will continue.

We must be careful to ensure that genuine claimants have adequate recourse. The tort law system developed on the basis of the relationship of duty of care—breaches of that duty and damages caused by breaches of that duty. These are sensible principles, but I think they have been corrupted and carried to an unreasonable extent, well beyond the ratio decidendi that was laid down in earlier common law. A great deal of the problem is the claims that are settled out of court. They are often those claims at the smaller end of the spectrum and they add to the cost of our premiums. Insurance companies tend to settle claims rather than defending them because the high cost of defence means it is not worth while.

It has been said that if you fall off your chair at home it is bad luck, but if you fall off your chair in a supermarket, you are entitled to a payment. I think this litigious attitude is what we desperately need to overcome. It must be realised that accidents happen; sometimes they are caused by negligence, but other times they must be accepted as purely unfortunate events.

I have met a number of doctors about the problems caused by issues associated with medical indemnity insurance. They appreciate the need to compensate, through payments, for wrongdoing and negligence caused by malpractice, but they also cite their frustration at the increasingly litigious nature of our society and the tendency to embark on the blame game. There appears to be an expectation that when a medical procedure does not produce the desired result it is someone's fault—either the doctor, the hospital, the equipment manufacturer or whoever. The community does not appear to accept that, despite the best efforts of all concerned in a procedure, things can go wrong. When something goes wrong, apparently someone must pay. This community attitude comes at great cost. The litigious mentality that there is always someone to blame, or that someone will sue, is causing a great cost to our community. Thankfully this government has taken a leading role in tackling these problems by pursuing solutions with professional, business and community organisations. The civil liability acts in the states, which have changed negligence laws, along with other measures, are certainly good progress and will help.

The collapse of United Medical Protection, or UMP, created a great deal of difficulty for doctors who were members of that medical defence organisation. The government was quick to respond to this problem and agreed in 2002 to take over the unfunded liabilities for claims across the medical sector which had not been lodged—the incurred but not reported, or IBNR, claims. As at June 2003, the cost of IBNR scheme liabilities was estimated to be in the order of $480 million. The government's medical indemnity review panel was established to look into concerns which arose from these measures, including the cost to doctors and the ongoing issues relating to the affordability of medical indemnity insurance. The panel's recommendations have been largely adopted in these bills which build on the 2002 measures.

Under these arrangements, the government's funding of IBNR claims will not be affected. The United Medical Protection support payment scheme replaces the IBNR scheme. The new scheme calculates the payments on a different basis. Under item 23 of the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Amendment Bill 2004, the maximum amount payable by a practitioner will be $5,000 per annum, to be collected through medical indemnity insurers, rather than the Health Insurance Commission—item 25 of the Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill 2004. Doctors and health professionals can receive a low-income exemption from the support payment.

Schedule 4 of the Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill also puts in place a framework of premium support to subsidise premiums for some specialities, like obstetrics and other areas. The premium support scheme will also assist rural procedural GPs. The premium support scheme is being established to replace the current medical indemnity subsidy scheme arrangements. Under the new arrangements, if a doctor's medical indemnity costs exceed 7½ per cent of his or her gross private medical income, the premium support scheme will kick in to cover 80 per cent of the indemnity costs incurred over the 7.5 per cent threshold. The scheme will also help rural procedural GPs by funding 75 per cent of the difference between their premiums and those for non-procedural GPs in similar circumstances.

The need to simplify for doctors the support arrangements relating to United Medical Protection is acknowledged in this legislation. It introduces a single billing system and it changes the basis of the UMP support payment to link it to the doctor's capacity to pay.

There is a significant commitment of public funds—in the order of $620 million over the next four years—to tackle the issues and put solutions in place. I look forward to the continuing changes with respect to the negligence laws and insurance premium levels. Making doctors' insurance affordable keeps doctors in business at affordable prices for patients—and that has to be good news for the community.

Just for a moment, I would like to consider the Medicare safety net. Unfortunately, our Labor opposition is once again pursuing its strategy of mindless opposition in holding back that very important reform—the Medicare safety net. We want to see that legislation passed. I call on members opposite to pass that legislation—to convince their Senate colleagues that the provision of a safety net is a very important thing for the community, that it is not inconsistent with any policy positions that they might have, and that they should pass that legislation.

I also note the member for Shortland's concerns in relation to bulk-billing. A major element in relation to bulk-billing is the supply of doctors. We could certainly train a lot more doctors if we were not having substantial public funds diverted to pay the rent on that terrible Centenary House—which has been very much the subject of discussion.

Before concluding, I would like to turn to another issue of mindless obstruction in the Senate, and that is Labor's obstruction in relation to the reforms necessary to the Trade Practices Act with regard to public liability. The New South Wales Treasurer, Michael Egan, has described the action of the Senate as one of the biggest obstacles to law reform on this very important issue. The public liability issue is very much a parallel issue with medical indemnity. It is one of the last changes to tort law that has been drawn up by the federal government to complement the work of state Labor governments. The changes before the Senate would close important loopholes in the Trade Practices Act and underpin the state level tort law reforms.

Michael Egan has certainly been throwing his weight behind the federal government's attempts to get this legislation through the parliament. Backing this legislation is most noteworthy, and I call on members opposite to talk to their Senate colleagues and get this important trade practices legislation through the Senate for the benefit of the community. I commend the bills to the House.

talk.start.para: —It gives me great pleasure to rise tonight to speak on the Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill 2004 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Amendment Bill 2004. It is very pleasing from my point of view that something is finally being done about this very serious issue—despite the strongarm tactics of the AMA in the early throes of this particular issue, under the chairmanship of its president, Dr Bill Glasson.

speech.para: I refer to the second reading speech that Minister Abbott made on 17 December 2003, when he referred to the government's announcement of new medical indemnity measures, including a contribution of $181 million towards the cost of medical indemnity for three years, making the cost of medical indemnity more affordable for doctors. More importantly, it will assist in ensuring doctors are able to concentrate on using their considerable professional medical skills to assist Australians requiring vital medical assistance in the knowledge that the litigation mania which drives elements within the community will not force them out of the public health system. I do not think anybody would argue against that.

Medical indemnity cover for doctors has been in crisis since early 2002, when a combination of litigation, greed and the collapse of Australia's primary medical defence organisation, UMP/AMIL, saw doctors at the mercy of huge claims, and escalating medical indemnity costs and facing the possibility of financial ruin. It needs to be said that all of these problems came out of the disgraceful and unprofessional way in which that particular medical insurance organisation was handled. It was the doctors' own organisation that was incompetent in terms of not being able to manage an insurance situation with medical indemnity as professionally as it should have done.

Nevertheless, the risk and uncertainty this crisis caused, particularly with regard to incurred but not reported claims, saw doctors threatening to remove their services and mounting a public campaign through their federal organisations in an attempt to convince government that taxpayers' funds were needed to ensure doctors were not only able to have confidence in medical indemnity insurance coverage but also able to afford the cost of premiums.

During that time the doctors were getting a little bit of stick from the journos who were aware of the muscle flexing of an industrial union, which at a meeting with Dr Bill Glasson I likened to the days of the BLF when Norm Gallagher was in control. I reminded him that if he wanted to do something constructive about his members' concerns about medical indemnity he had better stop trying to be the Norm Gallagher of the Australian Medical Association, as their president, and concentrate on people such as me in the community who did have sympathy with the problems of the doctors—even though it was their own doing. We were very concerned about the position that many doctors found themselves in. I did not appreciate the use of the big-stick approach by the AMA when it threatened to campaign in marginal coalition seats instead of undertaking a sensible, conciliatory approach to their problem, which, as I said, was one to which the AMA was the contributing factor.

As I mentioned briefly before, many of the journos that were switched on to this issue did not play politics but saw it for what it was. In the Australian of Wednesday, 17 December 2003, Janet Albrechtsen wrote an article about the issue. The article was headed `Give medicos a dose of their own medicine: Dr, heal thyself—if not, the Government (read: we taxpayers) certainly will'. In this article she said:

quote.para: Doctors had better polish up on their Latin. Nothing too difficult, just a few choice words: quid pro quo. After two days of special cabinet meetings this week, we still haven't heard exactly how the Howard Government will dole out millions of taxpayer dollars to stop doctors striking early next year.

But this much we know: we, the taxpayers, are going to be shafted—big time. We may as well lie back and, given we can't enjoy it, then at least extract some concessions, get something from doctors in return for the payola. This is the only hint of an upside in what looks destined to be a short-term fix.

speech.para: She went on to say:

quote.para: Doctors may shelter under a veneer of respectability as members of the “healing profession” and all that jazz. But take away the stethoscope and they are just another bunch of renegade unionists throwing their muscle around. In fact, the Australian Medical Association is the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union of the professions. It has so much power that even new Health Minister Tony Abbot has caved in to many of its excessive demands just to shut doctors up and keep them at work.

To be fair, Abbott was dealt a dud hand after a few decades of legal and medical vandalism. Enterprising lawyers and sentimental judges trying to do “justice”—never mind the law—left the community with a large dose of injustice in the form of an unsustainable system. Add to that a club mentality where doctors, operating under a cosy cartel, were loath to weed out even the serially negligent among them.

speech.para: Without reading all of the article, I think Ms Albrechtsen touched on the problem very eloquently. It is no wonder that an article by Morgan Mellish of 11 December 2003 in the Australian Financial Review quotes Helen Coonan as saying:

quote.para: “It is not fair that taxpayers should be asked to wear the costs of the mismanagement of a private company owned and operated by doctors.”
That was assistant Treasurer Helen Coonan in September.

speech.para: The articles went on. In the Daily Telegraph of Friday 10 October 2003, an article headed `Doctoring a crisis,' written by David Penberthy, had this to say:

quote.para: “The doctors had an insurance company, their insurance company was unable to meet its financial obligations and it was owned by the doctors,” he said yesterday ...

speech.para: Mr Penberthy was quoting the Treasurer, Peter Costello. He went on to state:

quote.para: This isn't an argument but a statement of historical fact with which the AMA is deeply uncomfortable.
As such, the doctors' rhetoric has homed in on the Government's failure to act, rather than addressing the cause of the issue.

In terms of the tactics, the AMA has led specialists through a fortnight of increasingly hysterical street theatre where, like some well-heeled cult, one by one they threaten to resign from key hospitals in areas of greatest need.

It's worth comparing this approach with that of other unions, such as police, ambulance paramedics and firefighters who, in the rare event of industrial action, are desperate to reassure the public there are no risks to their safety or security. The AMA has inverted this by playing on the fears of public patients with dire warnings that people will go without care unless the Government steps in.

Shame on them. The point is not whether professionals would let things get to that stage. The point is that their rhetoric suggests things could—which, if you're a sick person, uneducated in the manners of ambit claims and industrial hyperbole, is just another thing to worry about.

On the final point, fairness, the breathtaking thing about the AMA position is that they want 100 per cent of this stuff-up to be solved by you, the taxpayer. Their 7-point plan to end the indemnity crisis is predicated on taxpayers covering all medical costs awarded for negligence claims lodged six years after a medical mistake.

speech.para: Those articles eloquently sum up the points that I made to Dr Bill Glasson in the meeting in this place with a number of backbenchers, where he held that industrial gun at the heads of people like me. He did not hold the gun at my head, because he had not threatened to campaign in my electorate. I invited him to do so in order that I could expose him for what he was: just another union thug using fear and apprehension in the community—including small children and aged and elderly people with sicknesses—to try and extract money from the taxpayer over an issue that his organisation, through its profession, had let get out of control. He was looking for a rescue package from the very people that he was threatening with that industrial gun.

Having said that, I also have a very good relationship with many doctors in my electorate of Hume, and I did understand the anxiety which was driving doctors in this direction. I also acknowledge and appreciate the impact any withdrawal of medical service would have on the most vulnerable communities, such as rural and regional communities. Nevertheless, from day one the government has responded admirably in recognising the plight of doctors resulting from the medical indemnity crisis by underwriting UMP's unfunded incurred but not reported liabilities claims by an injection of $485 million of taxpayers' money and by introducing a number of safeguard initiatives aimed at ensuring that doctors can continue to offer their professional skills to the public.

I commend the new minister coming into the Health portfolio on the way in which he went about trying to solve this issue in a very difficult climate—not only a difficult climate from a political point of view but also, more importantly, a very difficult climate in the whole health system right throughout Australia. What did he come up with? He came up with a number of packages after further consultation, which I note have been the subject of some criticism by members of the ALP in this place. One wonders whether at some stage the ALP will start thinking about the way some of these decisions by organisations such as the AMA are affecting the very people that they are allegedly representing as members of parliament or whether they are just going to go down the ideological path of being disruptive and obstructive of anything and everything that the government puts up to assist the community.

This was one issue that I would have thought members of parliament would have had some very real concerns about, because it was hurting people in the community who needed some assistance from politicians in an environment where the taxpayer looked like making a very significant contribution towards what I have already described as a crisis that was created because of the mismanagement of a doctors insurance program, which the doctors themselves should have picked up and done something about in the very early stages. Nevertheless, that is history, and the government has approached the crisis as a very important issue in the community that should not have been allowed to go on as long as it did and has attempted to fix it very quickly.

Through the Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill 2004 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Amendment Bill 2004, the government has come up with a number of measures that need to be implemented to make sure that we come out of this with something positive which will allow the medical system and, more particularly, the hospital system to settle down and allow doctors to get on with their job and become the respected professionals they always have been in the general community.

The government's original package of legislation in 2002 was developed to address the medical indemnity industry's long-term viability and the affordability of medical indemnity premiums for doctors. The government has continued to enhance this package of measures by extending financial protection to doctors for the cost of claims beyond the level of their indemnity insurance, which is called the exceptional claims scheme. The government has also increased the number of categories of doctors who are eligible to be exempt from the incurred but not reported liabilities—commonly referred to as the IBNR contribution—and has put a moratorium on the amount payable under the IBNR contribution for 18 months.

The Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill 2004 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Amendment Bill 2004 address two matters: firstly, a number of issues regarding the current IBNR scheme contribution, including reducing its cost of doctors; and, secondly, the continuing issue of the affordability of medical indemnity insurance. As part of its original package of measures the government introduced the IBNR scheme, and under this scheme the government agreed to take over unfunded liabilities across the medical sector for claims that had not yet been lodged—IBNR claims. As part of the scheme, doctors who were members of medical defence organisations with unfunded IBNR liabilities were to contribute to the cost to the government of meeting those liabilities over time.

Currently, United Medical Protection is the only medical defence organisation participating in the IBNR scheme. Only UMP members as at 30 June 2003 need to pay the IBNR contribution. The current cost of the IBNR scheme liabilities is estimated to be $480 million at net present value as at the time of its introduction on 30 June 2003. The medical profession, of course, responded adversely to the introduction of the IBNR contribution, citing anomalies with its application and general affordability as concerns. In response, the government established a medical indemnity policy review, which reported to the Prime Minister on 10 December 2003. The arrangements set out in the bills reflect the government's response to issues associated with the IBNR contribution.

I am not going to go through all the benefits that flowed as a result of that action by the government, but the doctors, through their industrial union, the AMA, want to think very seriously about the type of people that they put in charge of that organisation to negotiate with government. It does not matter whether it is a coalition government or a Labor government; the reality is that the government—indeed, the parliament and its members—is handling taxpayers' money and it has to handle it very responsibly. It is incumbent upon doctors, as it is upon all professional organisations and individuals, to ensure that they undertake to carry out any work, whether or not it is in overseeing an insurance company that is looking after their problems with indemnity, as professionally as they are expected to by the taxpayers and not expect taxpayers to bail them out for all of the problems that they create as a result of their incapacity to professionally handle those organisations.

In closing, I thank the House for the opportunity to make a contribution to this debate. More importantly, can I say how gratifying it is from my point of view as a federal member for a rural area to see all of the concerns and problems that sprang up as a result of the initial action taken by doctors on this issue disappear, the system now settle down and patients get a little bit more confidence in doctors as they go to hospitals and surgeries to get the professional treatment they have always taken for granted. For me personally it is very pleasing to see the wonderful work being undertaken by specialists and doctors throughout the medical profession—I am a classic example of the wonderful expertise and professionalism we have come to expect from doctors, and the world-class treatment such as I got when I had an unfortunate accident in November last year.

I say to doctors: please think very seriously about the people that you put in charge to voice your concerns to the government—running around with a big stick is not the way to go. And they pick the wrong person when they come and wave a big stick at someone like me, because I have come out of a heavy industrial background and I can assure you if anybody comes at me with a big stick I stand there, take the stick off them and let them know that I am not going to be intimidated by that sort of action. It is not constructive and it is not in the best interests of people in general. I thank you for the opportunity to make this contribution.

talk.start.para: —The insurance industry has been in turmoil throughout the world in recent years as societies have become more litigious and the global landscape has changed, particularly since the appalling events of September 11, 2001. Insurers faced ever-increasing pressure from soaring claim costs, while weak economic activity in Europe and the US meant that insurers received lower returns from international equity markets, which led to funding shortfalls.

speech.para: The problems in international markets were also reflected in Australia. A significant withdrawal of capacity was experienced in some areas of insurance, whilst in other areas insurers were increasing premiums, limiting their coverage or in some cases doing both. For example, in 2001, premiums in the hard-hit classes of public liability insurance and professional indemnity insurance increased by 24 per cent. These difficulties were felt all the more throughout Australia because of the collapse of Australia's second largest insurer, HIH. The collapse of HIH early in 2001 had a catastrophic knock-on effect for United Medical Protection, UMP, which insured more than 50 per cent of the nation's doctors against medical indemnity. HIH reinsured UMP, whose collapse early in 2002 sparked the medical indemnity crisis.

Medical indemnity cover has been offered to doctors in Australia for more than 100 years through medical defence organisations, or MDOs, which are mutual associations of doctors. Traditionally, MDOs provided cover on a claims incurred basis, meaning that doctors paid a premium for a year and knew that they would be covered forever for an incident in that year. But, following pressure from the reinsurance market, MDOs moved to provide cover on a claims made basis. Under this system, doctors have to maintain cover by continuing to pay annual premiums to the same indemnity provider. If doctors wish to change providers or leave practice, they have to purchase run-off cover.

The Howard government has already implemented a number of measures to alleviate the problems associated with medical indemnity insurance, and the Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill 2004 builds on those earlier initiatives. In 2002-03 the government legislated to provide a secure prudential and financial framework for the medical indemnity industry and for doctors.
