For the first time, organisations offering medical indemnity cover were brought under the supervision of the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority.

The government has also invested substantially in medical indemnity. It has taken on the liability to fund some $485 million worth of UMP's unfunded incurred but not reported—IBNR—claims, which were threatening to put UMP into permanent liquidation. Other measures include a scheme to provide assistance with high-cost claims, and direct financial support for doctors undertaking high-risk specialities such as obstetrics and neurosurgery. The government has also continued to work closely with the state and territory governments in pursuing tort law reforms to reduce the volume and cost of claims against doctors. I will come back to the subject of tort law reforms in a few moments.

These and other past initiatives built a solid foundation to ensure the long-term viability of medical indemnity, but they still left doctors with financial challenges and, in some cases, almost prohibitive costs for their medical indemnity insurance. The aim of this bill, together with the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Amendment Bill 2004, is to address some of these problems—particularly those of affordability—to ensure that the nation's doctors continue to provide vital medical services to the Australian community.

One of the features of the current arrangements for medical indemnity is that increased competition between MDOs, combined with pressure from lower risk doctors, has led to increased risk ratings for different sectors of the profession. This means that there are now considerable differences in premium prices between high- and low-risk areas of practice, which are in turn leading doctors to withdraw from particular specialties and so adding to work force problems.

As a result of the continuing difficulties within the industry, the Medical Indemnity Review Policy Panel was set up late in 2003 to conduct a review of medical indemnity affordability, sustainability and the IBNR levy. The panel reported to the Prime Minister on 10 December 2003, and it is on this report that the Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill 2004 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Amendment Bill 2004 are based.

One of the key features of these bills is the funding of half the cost of all claims that exceed a $300,000 threshold through the High Cost Claims Scheme. The previous threshold was $500,000. This will further reduce medical indemnity providers' costs and so limit the financial pressures on doctors' premiums. Another key feature is the introduction of a new, broader based scheme, the Premium Support Scheme—PSS—to replace the Medical Indemnity Subsidy Scheme. Under the PSS more doctors will be assisted with their medical indemnity costs than under the Medical Indemnity Subsidy Scheme.

The bills will also replace the IBNR levy with UMP support arrangements. Under the previous arrangements, the IBNR contribution was specifically linked to a doctor's past risk profile, irrespective of their capacity to pay. However, this created significant anomalies, which the government now proposes to rectify. The government will now fund three-quarters of UMP's pre-2001 liabilities, with only the remaining quarter to be recouped from doctors by affordable contributions under the new UMP support arrangements.

Under the new arrangements, doctors who were members of UMP as at 30 June in 2000 will pay whichever is the least of their original IBNR annual levy, two per cent of their gross Medicare billable income or $5,000. The legislation now links payments to a doctor's ability to pay. No doctor will be required to make payments under the UMP support scheme for more than six years, and the doctors who were members of UMP for less than six years before 2000 will only be required to make a payment for a number of years equal to the number of years they were members of UMP.

Another important aspect of these bills is the Premium Support Scheme, or PSS, which will receive additional government funding of $100 million over four years. At present, through the Medical Indemnity Subsidy Scheme, the government provides funding to assist certain high-risk specialties with the cost of their medical indemnity premiums. The current arrangements only apply to neurosurgeons, obstetricians, procedural GPs and GP registrars undertaking procedural training, and do not take into account doctors' incomes. The PSS will provide funding for 80 per cent of a doctor's medical indemnity costs if these exceed 7.5 per cent of his or her gross income. The PSS will be provided directly through a doctor's medical indemnity insurer so that he or she does not have to make a separate application. This scheme will come into full operation on 1 July 2004.

These extra measures, added to those already implemented, mean the government will now contribute a combined total of some $620 million over the next four years to meet medical indemnity claims. The Howard government has shown true leadership in brokering new medical indemnity solutions. Action taken has reassured doctors and the community that the government takes this issue seriously and is prepared to make tough decisions to achieve a satisfactory outcome for doctors and stakeholders, which in turn will restore confidence to the Australian public.

But these measures alone will not be enough to fully restore confidence. It is essential that the states and territories make sweeping tort law reforms. The recent medical indemnity crisis has not been brought about solely by problems within the insurance industry. The present tort system is adversarial in its process, rather than seeking to provide equitable compensation to plaintiffs, correct mistakes and deter negligence. For doctors, litigation is a very public punishment. The current tort system, where the determination of issues is carried out in an adversarial forum, makes it less likely that doctors will receive constructive criticism. Rather, the system appears to punish defendant doctors.

The reality of the current system is that doctors and patients are set against each other and patients are encouraged, in order to achieve optimum compensation, to maximise any deficiencies in the care given by the doctor. Increasingly, medical negligence cases cease to reflect a mistake made by a competent but fallible doctor but seek to portray the doctor as incompetent or derelict in their duty to the patient.

This situation clearly has an adverse effect on doctor-patient relationships and has a significant impact on a sued doctor, not only professionally and economically but also psychologically. Sued doctors are also more likely to avoid certain categories of patients. General practitioners who have never been sued live daily with the threat of litigation hanging over their head like the sword of Damocles. It is the most significant source of stress in most doctors' lives. Having been a GP in my electorate of Moore for more than 26 years, I can vouch for that.

It is of even more concern that the current tort system has led to a situation where many medical practitioners structure their practices around procedures to avoid being sued. This practice has become known as a `defensive medicine' program. Some instances of defensive medicine include increased referrals or follow-ups that are not clinically warranted and diagnostic tests that are not clinically indicated. Some doctors even avoid patients, treatments and procedures thought to increase the risk of an adverse outcome and litigation. And none of this is good for the patient.

Increased reliance on medical technology increases health care costs unnecessarily, and avoidance of high-risk patients and illnesses reduces the community's access to health services. Diagnostic tests and treatments that are not clinically indicated carry their own risk of side effects and iatrogenic harm. But of even more concern than that is the breakdown of trust between doctor and patient. Doctors who are wary of their patients are less likely to establish the mutual trust that is necessary for optimal patient care. Clinical decisions made for reasons of self-protection compromise both patient care and doctor integrity.

As it stands, the current tort system fails to achieve its aims of optimising the quality of patient care by offering equitable compensation, correction and deterrence. Instead, through its actual effects of punishing defendant doctors and introducing mutual mistrust and antagonism into the doctor-patient relationship, it has made doctors focus more on avoidance of litigation than on improvement of patient care. Fundamental changes are necessary to the tort laws governing medical negligence. Patients and their lawyers must also fundamentally change their approach to making a claim for compensation. Until tort law reforms are put into place, the volume and magnitude of medical negligence claims will continue to put pressure on medical indemnity.

The Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill 2004, together with the government's previous legislation, will help to alleviate problems within the industry and provide certainty and reduce medical indemnity costs for doctors. Although there will be a large cost to taxpayers, the benefits for the community through the ongoing provision of quality medical services will far outweigh the costs. Finally, I ask the opposition parties in the Senate to pass the tort law reform legislation to close the loophole which allows people avoiding state law reforms to use parts of the Trade Practices Act to recover damages for personal injury—which was never the intent of the act. I commend the bills to the House.

talk.start.para: —It is with great pleasure that I join this debate on the Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill 2004 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Amendment Bill 2004 and express my support for the proposals involved. Nevertheless, I think it is worth putting on the record what the government have been forced to do—at a cost to the Australian taxpayer—because the nation and its legislatures have failed to properly address issues that are fundamental to public liability. We have had plenty of warning. The United States of America has to spend 12 per cent of its GDP on health matters, and there is significant evidence that the three per cent differential with Australia, at about nine per cent, has arisen as a result of the plaintiff lawyers and litigation which are endemic in that nation. As a consequence, in certain states of America where the state legislatures have addressed the problem of plaintiff lawyers and litigation there has been a massive reduction in the cost to the taxpayer, because capping and other legislative measures were implemented that made it less profitable for plaintiff lawyers to participate. In that nation, things got to the point where you could not get into outpatient care without being confronted by someone with a clipboard who would go through a checklist to see what services you had whilst you were in hospital, in the hope of finding something on which there would be grounds to sue.

speech.para: Australia took a terrible fright in that regard. The evidence is legion in many areas of local governments suffering huge costs—local pony clubs closing down et cetera—and nowhere has it been a bigger issue than it is with medical indemnity. In reading the minister's second reading speech, my attention was drawn to the fact that this legislation, plus the other packages that the government has improved, will cost $620 million over the next four years. A noted economist called Friedman shocked the world when he reminded us, `There is no such thing as a free lunch.' In other words, in the end, someone will pay. The person who lines up in response to an advertisement that says, `Your first legal interview is free. Come to me and I won't charge you if I fail to get you money,' thinks that they are going to gain by that process; but the fact is that their children, their relatives and their neighbours will pay for it—through increased insurance premiums, in this case.

The interesting thing about the free lunch is that the $620 million sandwich—which this government proposes, quite properly, because our political processes have failed to address the system—will come with no meat. It will just be two slices of bread for the person who suffered some sort of injury or difficulty arising from, say, a medical procedure. Why? Because the meat is to be extracted by the administrators of an insurance fund, which we quite properly are propping up, and by the plaintiff lawyers who say, `The first interview is free; but mate, it's going to cost you plenty in the long run.' I think I am correct in quoting Premier Carr from New South Wales, whom I would credit with taking a more positive approach to this issue than anybody else in Australia at the political level, when I say that his argument was that about 70 per cent of the claims that are processed under these principles go to the lawyers. In other words, it is not only the meat but also the butter that disappears from the free lunch. The person who has suffered—or who believes they have suffered—an injury gets precious little. What is the purpose of that?

We would be told by people on the opposition benches that New Zealand has a better system, and that is called a no-fault insurance system. I do not agree with that either, because it does not take away entirely the tendentious claim. It is my view that, if there is a genuine injury, it would be better to look at it on equity and economic grounds and say that the Australian welfare system in a generous fashion attends to the needs of people who suffer in the process of being born, being operated upon or tripping over in a public facility for which local government has a responsibility.

In my early years in this place—there is nobody here at the moment who was here at that time, and it was not in this building—I became part of the then Standing Committee on Road Safety. We conducted an inquiry into vehicle licensing. It was the Year of the Disabled, and we thought we should extend the inquiry to the licensing of disabled drivers. We visited a hospital where they had a training program for such people. It was interesting to me—and this is fundamental to this debate—that a number of paraplegics were being taught to drive cars which had all the amenities on the steering wheel. They were mostly workers compensation or road trauma beneficiaries who had got settlements from one of the many insurance operations that we run. But one individual got home from work one day, climbed up on the roof of his house to fix a cracked tile, slipped and fell down over the adjoining fence to his neighbour's place—and he was in the same condition. He did not have a new car. He did not have all the bells and whistles. He had a second-hand car and was struggling on a pension.

That is the inequity in the system. Make sure you get injured at work. Make sure there is something that you claim or a medical practitioner who can be taken to court and accused of negligence. I think that is unfair. I think that is wrong. I think the guy I am talking about who fell off his own roof is entitled to a better deal out of the welfare system, while many of those who are not paraplegics are getting benefits from the system that we nationally accept and, through the efforts of plaintiff lawyers and others, are getting a better deal than might be fair.

We in this House are well aware—we would be fools otherwise—that this system is corrupt. It is not always corrupt, but there is plenty of evidence of people who plague the system—people who, for example, get Aunty Jane to say she ran her car into nephew Smith and then claim for injuries they do not have. We know that within the workers compensation area and all the other areas there is abuse of the system. That would be less attractive if the dollars were not so big. That is another downside of a system that, in the first instance, provides a lump sum. We know that some of those quite legitimately receiving lump sums see them eroded by relatives or neighbours and end up back on the welfare system anyway. So, all in all, the system does not work.

Tonight we are dealing primarily with these sorts of issues as they relate to medical practitioners. I was most impressed when the current president of the AMA, Dr Glasson, pointed out to me where the system fails. The failure deals with the definition of negligence. To me, a medical practitioner who is negligent, for instance—and this is a pretty graphic example—is one who gets you in the hospital and cuts off the wrong leg. We read jokes about that. I think it is negligence when, for instance, you are injected with excessive quantities of morphine and you die. There is not much we can do for you thereafter. The fact of life is that that is negligence, and I believe the question thereafter should be: does that doctor have a right to practise? But we do not ask that. We say: `Ring up your insurance company, plead negligent and pay the money.' In other words, we have a system that backs up true failures in the system—although let me say that I think in Australia they do not occur very frequently.

So what are all these settlements about? A sum of $20 million was paid for a child born 20 years ago, because the doctor had one of two options and chose the wrong one. That is not negligence. In this very place we are confronted with taking one option or another from time to time and under significant pressure. Say a doctor, having treated a woman during her pregnancy, is of the view, because he has no reason to think otherwise, that a normal birth will be okay. At the death knock, halfway through that process, he comes to the conclusion that a caesarean is necessary—but it takes half an hour to get an operating theatre in place and in that time the child suffers brain damage. Is that negligence? I do not think it is. But there has been judgment after judgment in our courts that says it is.

This legislation certainly does not fix that. It just says the Australian taxpayer will pay whatever the courts decide if it exceeds certain amounts of money. I do not criticise that, because this depends on the support of state governments. I know—I got some information on this—that the Ipp committee raised this issue and came up with what they referred to as the modified Bolam principle. A number of states have responded; my state of Western Australia still has a draft bill. I have read their comments over there, and they are more inclined to look after the plaintiff lawyers than people in these circumstances. It is patently silly to think that a case can be prosecuted 20 years after the event and yet, whilst there have been efforts—my schedule tells me where people have cut those periods down—there are still opportunities of that nature.

But who pays? Do people believe there is some miracle angel out there that sends the money? The minister in his second reading speech has quite properly told us—and I congratulate him for his compassion and his assistance in keeping medical practitioners in business—that we are going to spend $620 million of taxpayers' money to keep a medical insurance process in place, because there will still be inappropriate and gigantic claims relative to events that I do not think were negligent.

I do not think a local government authority is negligent because it failed to put a sign up saying, `If you are an inexperienced driver, don't drive here.' You can imagine how much notice a driver would take of that sign. There was a case in Western Australia which, to the great credit of the judge, was chucked out of court. A person who, tragically, is a quadriplegic fronted up demanding compensation. A local authority did not tell her that she should not have been driving on a particular road because she lacked the experience to do so. On that occasion the court found properly, perhaps through the conservatism of the judicial system in Western Australia. That was not the case in New South Wales where a fellow, to show off to his girlfriend, jumped into shallow water and became a quadriplegic. The ratepayers of a particular council were up for $10 million because a bloke was an idiot.

I do not see that the community should have to pay those sorts of sums, but I am prepared to accept that once a person, maybe through their own fault, has become a quadriplegic the community must give them care, and sufficient income to survive. I think we as a community would be much better off if we accepted people as welfare propositions where there is genuine evidence that a person, at whatever level, needs our assistance, rather than going through the process of propping up insurance entities, which have administrative costs and are typically adversarial. If Premier Carr is correct, the larger proportion of the money that is supposed to help someone in need goes to legal firms. The legal firms were doing very nicely out of the process. Some of them have had to amalgamate, simply to achieve economies, because there has been some tort law reform.

If we cannot get the states to be sensible, it is time it became a requirement of the national-states medical agreement that state governments clearly define what is negligence in the medical area and, for that matter, in other areas. I do not think that would be too difficult. I have given examples in my speech.

I have one leg shorter than the other because I drove a car into some trees one night. The incident occurred at a point on a road where the seal dropped from 20 feet to 12 feet. I knew that, and I drove inappropriately. I did not sue the local government authority, although I probably could have. I was the driver and I knew I was at fault. I did not ask the community to back me up.

In Western Australia a woman, who was training a few people on a town oval, got a settlement of $70,000 or $80,000. She was the coach and turned her ankle whilst running around telling them what to do. Surely if there was a duty of care, it was for her to make sure that her pupils did not turn their ankles. There is no such thing as a free lunch and, when a person chooses litigation to establish their claim, there is no meat in the sandwich—the lawyers get that.

We are doing the right thing but it is a bandaid measure. I do not think this is an issue for adversarial politics. There is a better way. It is about time we approached each other, got together and worked it out to the benefit of the community. People who suffer injuries, whether at birth, through a hospital procedure, in a motor car or at work, must be reasonably cared for to the level of their injury or loss of income. I do not think that propping up medical insurance, and everything else, is the answer. We must change the law and make it clear.

You cannot blame an employer, who is working in an area remote from another workplace, because some idiot does not take reasonable precautions in their workplace. They should do that in their own interests. We should address all these issues in the law so that our judiciary have a fundamental understanding of them. It is pretty tough on the judges. A judge is there looking at the disadvantaged person and thinking, `How can I help?' They forget how many other people will go without to support that decision. This is something for government. We must look after those in need, but we should not have all these convoluted processes and the legal profession should not be the major winners.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr ABBOTT
talker.role: Minister for Health and Ageing

talk.start.para: —We are debating the Medical Indemnity Amendment Bill 2004 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Amendment Bill 2004 not because we want to spend $620 million and not because we want to help plaintiff lawyers to continue to live in the manner to which they are accustomed. We are debating this legislation because there has been an explosion of tort law litigation in this country which has particularly affected the medical profession and, as a result of that explosion, many doctors were considering withdrawing from practice. While the federal government cannot deal with tort law reform, it certainly can deal with insurance. That is effectively what we are doing now.

speech.para: I thank all who have contributed to this debate. I should single out my opposite number, the member for Lalor. Her speech, stripped of its ritual abuse of the government and of ministers past and present, was not a bad precis of developments in this area over the last decade. She did move a pious amendment but, as I understand it, the opposition do not oppose this legislation. I am grateful for small mercies. The opposition did not say what they would do to solve this problem. They said simply that, if they were in power, we would not be in the current position. It is easy to say that. The Tito report was delivered just a couple of weeks before the former government went out of office, so medical indemnity insurance must join the list of things the opposition would have fixed if only they had had another term.

What we are doing tonight is addressing legislation that implements most of the recommendations of the Medical Indemnity Policy Review Panel. That review panel sought affordable premiums for doctors, it sought to have the government take on the long-term care costs of catastrophically injured patients, it sought to restore medical indemnity insurance to a claims incurred basis and it sought to deal with the IBNR levy. The government has responded very fully to the recommendations of that review panel and, in so doing, has substantially addressed the desires of the medical profession, as expressed by the medical members of that review panel, to address those four key grievances.

The government is introducing premium support. If a doctor's actuarially calculated medical indemnity premium exceeds 7.5 per cent of private medical income, the government will pick up 80 per cent of the gap. We are extending the High Cost Claims Scheme to cover 50 per cent of all claims over $300,000, and this substantially addresses the long-term care issue. We are negotiating with the medical indemnity insurers to create a run-off reinsurance vehicle, and this will cover claims against former doctors who have been out of the profession for three years and doctors who have retired or are permanently incapacitated. We have replaced the IBNR levy with the UMP support scheme, under which doctors who are former members of UMP, or who were members of UMP at the relevant time, will pay two per cent of their Medicare income or $5,000 or their former levy amount—whichever is the least. Those UMP support payments will be paid in conjunction with the standard premium and will be capped for six years. Doctors who are over 65 and who are permanently retired or earn medical incomes under $5,000 will be exempt from UMP support payments.

This is a good package of legislation. It reflects the work of the Medical Indemnity Policy Review Panel. I want to thank all those who served on that panel. I particularly thank the medical members of the panel: Dr Bill Glasson, President of the AMA; Dr Andrew Pesce, the AMA's indemnity specialist; Professor Don Sheldon, Chairman of the Council of Procedural Specialists; and Dr Susan Page, President of the Rural Doctors Association of Australia. I also thank the lay members of the panel: John Phillips, a former Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank; Nancy Milne, the insurance partner at Clayton Utz; and my friend and colleague, Senator Helen Coonan, the Assistant Treasurer. The panel met frequently, it consulted widely, it cogitated deeply and, I think, came up with a very good slate of recommendations.

There are two recommendations which are not addressed by this legislation but which are worth mentioning in the course of this debate. There is a recommendation for further tort law reform. The New South Wales government has done well, and all credit to Bob Carr for what he has done in this area, but I do think it is necessary to consider further measures such as the interposition of medical assessment panels to determine whether there has been professional misconduct, or something which does not satisfy the ordinary professional standards of medicine, before it goes into the courts. Obviously, for its part, the medical profession does need to ensure that they have proper risk management strategies and programs in place. These are two recommendations of the panel which are not dealt with here but are certainly worth mentioning.

I should also mention that one of the recommendations of the panel was to have a further review in about 15 months. That is something the government certainly will do. One matter which the review at that time will consider is whether there is some merit in moving to a doctor-controlled monopoly medical indemnity insurer for this country. While we were part of the panel, we certainly received evidence that there would be significant administrative savings from a move in that direction.

In conclusion, it is important that the existing medical indemnity insurers lift their game. Over the last few years, these insurers have not always served their members well. Considerable evidence was found by the panel of a loss of faith between doctors and at least some of the medical indemnity insurers. They have to lift their game. There are some encouraging signs that they are starting to do so, and I am pleased about that. That is one of the matters which the government will reconsider in 15 months time. In the meantime, this is good legislation and I commend it to the House.

talk.start.para: —I have been sent down here to speak on the Customs Tariff Amendment (Paraquat Dichloride) Bill 2004 because I seem to be the only person on the opposition side who knows what paraquat dichloride is. In fact, I will have to declare a conflict of interest in that I actually on occasions use this product and therefore might benefit from this piece of legislation in some very small way. Paraquat is a contact herbicide to control broadleaved weeds and grasses and it is a very suitable herbicide for using around young vines. You cannot use glyphosate, because glyphosate herbicides, while they are much more effective, are too effective and will kill young vines. So I have on occasions used paraquat to control weeds in my vineyard.

speech.para: The issue at stake is the safety features that are attached to this product. When I was using this product I took advice from the research manager of the viticultural section of the CSIRO, Nigel Steele-Scott, who told me that this was a very effective contact herbicide; in fact so effective that some people may have used it on occasions to kill their grandmothers.

talk.start.para: —Did you?

—I did not have a grandmother who I wanted to treat in this way; I just had 10 acres of weeds in the vineyard. This bill corrects an anomaly whereby paraquat dichloride which has a number of safety features attached to it, either anti-dusting agents, colouring or staunching agents, is imported duty free but paraquat dichloride that is equipped with the safety feature of an emetic to make people who swallow it vomit is currently attracting a tariff of five per cent. This bill will remove the tariff of five per cent and people will find it thereafter more difficult to poison their grandmothers, because there will not be cheaper products around that do not have the emetic. I commend the bill to the House.

—The Customs Tariff Amendment (Paraquat Dichloride) Bill 2004 seems at first glance to be nothing more than a minor technical amendment to a bill, but once again the Howard government has missed the point entirely. This bill, in the words of the explanatory memorandum, will amend the Customs Tariff Act 1995 to insert a new additional note to chapter 29 of the tariff section. That amendment would allow the chemical paraquat dichloride, with an added emetic—or vomit inducer—to be removed from chapter 38 and instead classified under subheading 2933.39.00 in chapter 29. What that does is remove the five per cent import duty on paraquat dichloride imported in a form which contains the emetic. This move was foreshadowed by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration in this House on 27 March 2003. On that occasion the parliamentary secretary, who is in the House at the moment, said:

quote.para: This amendment corrects an anomaly in the tariff that sees paraquat dichloride with an added emetic, which is a safety agent that induces vomiting if swallowed, attract a duty rate of five per cent whereas paraquat dichloride without an emetic receives a duty rate of free. The purpose of the emetic is to achieve the same safety outcome as the addition of other allowable anti-dusting, colouring or stenching agents, which do not attract import duty.

speech.para: The 2003-04 budget papers tell us that the government will remove, with effect from 1 April 2003, the five per cent duty, and that this measure will result in a revenue reduction of $500,000 a year in perpetuity. That is, the importers of paraquat dichloride into Australia will receive a half million dollar windfall as a result of the passage of this legislation. The bill now before us seeks to remove that five per cent duty retrospectively—with effect from 24 March last year. But the Attorney-General gave no reason for the changed date of effect—from 1 April 2003 to 24 March 2003—in his second reading speech last month, preferring instead to engage in some light-hearted banter with the Speaker, saying:

quote.para: This chemical, and Mr Speaker I am sure you are familiar with it, is commonly used as a herbicide.

speech.para: Prompting the Speaker to acknowledge:

quote.para: I am in fact more familiar with it than with text messaging.

speech.para: But I wonder just how familiar. Familiar enough to know that paraquat dichloride is banned, or severely restricted, in no less than 11 countries? That it is banned in Sweden, Denmark, Finland and Austria, and has been since as far back as December 1983, because of its high acute toxicity, risks of irreversible health and environmental effects, and potential for accidents during handling? Familiar enough to know that the governments of six industrialised countries in Europe have notified bans and restrictions under the 1998 Rotterdam convention on prior informed consent? Familiar enough to know that the European Union considered totally banning its use as recently as March last year? Perhaps even familiar enough to know that the United States Environmental Protection Agency allows its purchase and use solely by certified applicators?

Paraquat dichloride—or simply paraquat—is a chemical which honourable members should know about, if for no other reason than the fact that the World Health Organisation has dubbed it `the only highly toxic herbicide of the post-war years'. Paraquat was first identified as a herbicide by ICI in 1955 and marketed in the 1960s. It has been surrounded by controversy ever since. The major manufacturer of paraquat is a company called Syngenta, which controls about 20 per cent of the global pesticide market. The company describes paraquat, sold mainly under the trade name Gramoxone in over 120 countries, as the world's second-largest-selling agrochemical.

When first marketed, the dark brown colour led to paraquat products being mistaken for drinks like coffee or cola, particularly when decanted to other containers—a common practice in developing countries. It was also used widely to commit suicide, as we heard mentioned by the previous speaker. Since the late 1980s, Syngenta has added various safety agents to formulations such as paraquat. These include a blue pigment, a stenching agent to give it a strong and deterring odour, and an emetic to induce vomiting if swallowed. In 1996, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation—the FAO—developed a specification for active ingredient concentrates, requiring an effective emetic and blue-green colorants and encouraging the addition of other safety measures, including stanching agents and thickeners. Now we have the government moving in this bill to abolish the duty on a chemical containing an emetic—something which should have been compulsory back in 1996. It makes you wonder, doesn't it? Why the delay? And why is there still no compulsion?

According to the European Union risk classification, paraquat dichloride is very toxic by inhalation, toxic in contact with skin and toxic if swallowed. It is irritating to the eyes, the respiratory system and skin, and there is danger of serious damage to a person's health by prolonged exposure. A 1997 study in Malaysia, for example, revealed the adverse effects of paraquat and other herbicides on workers in small plantations—fingernails dropping off, nosebleeds, rashes and irritations of the skin, eyes and reproductive organs. Yet in that country just last year chemical distributor ICI was running a publicity campaign proclaiming:

quote.para: Paraquat and nature working in perfect harmony ... It's a FACT. PARAQUAT is environmentally friendly.

speech.para: Companies were also giving away baseball caps, golf balls and drums of free product with large purchases, rather than offering free safety equipment, which would have been more appropriate. Of course, there was local outrage at such misrepresentation and promotion, especially in light of the fact that the WHO regards paraquat as one of the world's deadliest chemicals. This campaign nevertheless shows the level to which the chemical companies are prepared to go to sell their products, especially in developing and third world countries, where safety regimes are often not as stringent as in other countries—and I hope the member for Kingston, when he made use of paraquat on his local vines, followed the appropriate safety regimes. As a result of the WHO's concerns, the Malaysian government has legislated to completely ban the use of paraquat by 2005. If only the Australian government showed as much concern for its citizens and did the same.

Paraquat dichloride has been criticised for its adverse impacts on workers since it was first introduced back in the 1960s. Its high toxicity and lack of antidote lead to serious ill health, and even death, from exposure. A 1999 South African study found that the lung capacity of workers exposed to paraquat was consistently 10 to 15 per cent lower than a reference population. The greatest risk of serious or fatal accidents to workers is during mixing and loading, where contact with the concentrate occurs. But fatalities have also been reported due to prolonged contact with diluted paraquat spray during application. Drift from spraying paraquat has also caused health and environmental problems. A 1993 study by the California Environmental Protection Agency identified health problems—including an increase in coughs, eye problems, diarrhoea, irritation, headache, nausea, rhinitis, throat infections, breathing problems, unusual tiredness and wheezing—after spray drift passed over the town of Hollister. A 2001 study in Costa Rica, conducted by the Central American Institute for Studies on Toxic Substances, concluded:

quote.para: Regulatory agencies have not fully recognized either the inherent toxicity of paraquat for human beings...

speech.para: But there is more. Paraquat has been ranked as very persistent in soils by a Cornell University environmental risk index in the United States. In Germany, the product is restricted to use once every four years on field crops, based on its potential to accumulate in the soil. Syngenta claims that the product is safe and has many benefits. They say:

quote.para: The product acts quickly, is rapidly inactivated in soil and won't contaminate ground or surface water ... If you follow the instructions, you are safe. That's why we do not discuss a ban on the product.

speech.para: Yet paraquat is labelled a potential groundwater contaminant by the California Department of Pesticide Regulation because it has the potential to move into groundwater, based on its water solubility, ability to bind to soils and long half-life.

It is not as though this is new information for us here in Australia. The parliament has been made aware of the extreme dangers of paraquat on numerous occasions in the past. For example, the chemical was used in Vietnam, and in 1982 questions were asked in this place regarding its effect on the health of Australian service personnel. I think it is appropriate that we make mention of this today, with the announcement regarding TPI payments. In the 1994 agricultural and veterinary chemicals bill debate, Senator Bell of Tasmania pointed out:

quote.para: We have a situation where voluntary helpers, assisting in projects conducted by Landcare and Greening Australia, are being given containers of such fearful chemicals as paraquat. Having given of their time voluntarily, they are coming home with severe nosebleeds occasioned by the notorious anticoagulant paraquat.

speech.para: Why then has there been the echoing silence within this place since 1994 on the dangers of paraquat dichloride? There is no doubt that paraquat dichloride is hazardous to human health and to the environment. But rather than banning it as it should do, this government is hell bent on making one form cheaper by abolishing the five per cent duty on the version of paraquat containing an emetic. This once again begs the question: why the delay in the first place? As I have already outlined, an emetic has been voluntarily added by the major manufacturer since the 1980s, and the FAO introduced a specification requiring an effective emetic in 1996. So why has it taken until 2004 to remove the five per cent impost?

I take no pleasure in saying this, but I think we have caught the government in bed with its chemical mates again, just like we did with the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill last year. Last year it was Chemical Trish; this year we have Chemical Phil. Why else would it take as long as 20 years, or eight at the minimum, to recognise the need for an emetic safety factor? Also, why the change in date of effect from 1 April 2003 to 24 March 2003? What happened in that week to make the government change its mind? Why has this bill been presented in such an off-hand and cavalier manner? At a time when there is increasing public concern about multiple chemical sensitivity, why isn't paraquat dichloride being banned altogether?

It is not as though there are not other effective weed management techniques that do not involve deliberately introducing toxic chemicals into the environment. Multiple chemical sensitivity is an increasing problem within our community, costing Australia millions of dollars each year in related medical and welfare expenses.

Just last month I attended the Illawarra chronic fatigue syndrome support group in my electorate of Cunningham and saw first hand the results of multiple chemical sensitivity—or `chemical AIDS' as it is called—of which CFS has been cited as perhaps one manifestation. When toxic chemicals attack the immune system, they can have a devastating effect. I heard one story of a young girl who has been bed ridden for seven years as a result of chronic fatigue syndrome which may or may not have been brought on by chemical poisoning. We just do not know what the effect is of some of the toxic chemicals we are introducing into the food chain and into the air we breathe.

When we are told of the many adverse effects of a chemical such as paraquat dichloride and we fail to take action to ban it, and instead continue to promote it and allow it to be used as a herbicide throughout the country, then this is nothing less than criminal. The worst of it is that the introduction of GM crops is reported as being likely to result in the increased use of these so-called old fashioned, more toxic herbicides such as paraquat.

This parliament cannot continue to bury its head in the sand over this issue; it is one which we must address. The South Australian task force on multiple chemical sensitivity is holding a public protest in Adelaide in a fortnight's time, on 17 March, calling for a national multiple chemical sensitivity prevention, treatment and disability access strategy. The task force believes that the failures of governments and chemical regulators to address the problem of chemical injury have led to large numbers of people with MCS and related illnesses. I am one of nine members of this House who have been emailed by task force convenor Peter Evans asking what action we are taking to address the problem of MCS at a national and international level. How do I refute his suggestion that we are:

quote.para: ...deliberately maintaining a state of ignorance and denial that an extremely serious public health crisis even exists, with large numbers of people disabled from so-called `safe' chemical exposures.

speech.para: How indeed, when the government brings legislation like the Customs Tariff Amendment (Paraquat Dichloride) Bill before this House—a bill which is handing half a million dollars per annum back to the chemical companies; a bill which is making one of the world's most toxic chemicals cheaper; and a bill which is therefore likely to lead to the increasing use of paraquat in this country.

The government has once again missed the point. In the interest of all Australians I call on the Prime Minister to ban paraquat dichloride altogether. We should not forget the tragic death of a 54-year-old Maryborough man after exposure to paraquat in 2000 and the earlier death, in or around 1990, of a carpenter who ingested paraquat thinking that it was coca-cola. He died three days later of multiple organ failure, because there is no antidote to paraquat. We have had these tragedies in our country because of this chemical. As I have pointed out, there are alternatives. While I understand the government's desire to rectify an apparent tariff anomaly, I cannot in all conscience support a bill which perpetuates the use of a highly toxic chemical that has demonstrable adverse health and environmental impacts.

talk.start.para: —Unfortunately, and sadly, I have had a lot of experience with suicides, as probably most members of this House have. The young male suicide rate in Australia, if not the highest in the world, is amongst the highest and has been so for probably 10 or 15 years. There is something seriously wrong here.

speech.para: If you go to the library and ask for the reasons for suicide, they will probably give you a handout from the health department where they tracked deaths of 15- to 25-year-old males over a 30-year timeframe. If you placed the graph for the rise in suicides over the graph for the rise in unemployment, the lines were almost identical. We know the reason—it is because there is no hope out there; there is no work even though the government make it their duty to skite all the time. We are talking on the Customs Tariff Amendment (Paraquat Dichloride) Bill 2004 and sadly paraquat is one of the favoured methods of suicide in north Queensland. Like strychnine, it is readily available and can be used for that purpose. We are very pleased to be looking at any moves that that will overcome this problem and I would have thought that there were other ways of attacking this problem, as my esteemed colleague from Wollongong was saying, than giving the companies a free kick. I am not complaining about that because a lot of farmers buy it, but if you think those savings are going to be passed onto the farmer you would believe that the abominable snowman lives in Bedourie. I doubt whether farmers are going to receive any benefits from it, but undoubtedly there is a benefit initially for the companies that produce this stuff.

Let me return to the problem that has precipitated this, which is basically the suicide problem. This very evening, before coming down to this chamber, I spent 2½ hours on the telephone speaking with somebody who felt that there may be the possibility of a suicide. So it is very real. I get letters probably once a month. I spoke to Alf Messina, a trader in rural products, and he told me that over a recent period of time there were three cases of people committing suicide by taking gramoxone. He said it is a very serious issue indeed in Far North Queensland. In one two-week period recently there were three suicides in the sugar industry.

The sugar industry does not use gramoxone a lot these days because of the trash blanket approach to farming, where you do not have the necessity that we once had for weedicides. The trash blanket innovation, as you are well aware, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley—being very experienced and having many generations in the industry—and many other innovations that are of a superior standard than we have had before which have been introduced in the sugar industry have enabled us to avoid the use of weedicides to a very large degree. For those who are not familiar, the trash blanket is six, eight and, in some cases, 12 inches thick. Nothing can drive up through that huge trash blanket, except that very powerful—the most powerful of all plants—sugar plant. The sugar plant is able to come through but nothing else is. The trash blanket has very effectively replaced a lot of the weedicides that were once used in the industry.

The suicide issue is very personal to me. There were three young men who committed suicide in the town of Hughenden in the space of 18 months when I was a state member. I vividly recall three cases that took place. A cattleman who was going to shoot some calves in a drought situation—he had a meeting with the bank that week—turned the gun on himself instead of the calves. A few months later, the brother of a very close friend of mine—we played football together for many years—who also had problems with the bank took strychnine. That is a terrible way to die—as is taking gramoxone.

Gramoxone is irreversible, in the sense that, once you take it, you die a really terrible agonising death over three days. We had a case in Far North Queensland. I did not know the family but I knew their neighbours very well. The neighbour said it was a terrible way to die. The person was a young man with everything before him and he had three young children. He was in the sugar industry and he saw no hope—but of all the ways that one would choose to die!

The effect of gramoxone is irreversible, so the idea of putting an emetic in with it is an excellent thing to do. But, like my worthy colleague here from the Wollongong area, I would have thought that the way to attack this would be to ensure that there was no gramoxone available anywhere without the emetic in it. I do not know why we are so taken with this economic fundamentalism that we have to provide a carrot instead of what is a big stick—an emetic. People are dying. Why would you fool around with providing a very low-level incentive when in fact you could pass legislation and put in the emetic in the first place? It is quite extraordinary to me.

Third World countries throw this stuff around like confetti. There is no necessity, nor any pressure upon them, to do the right thing via a trash blanket because they have such super cheap labour in those countries and they do not really have to be internationally competitive. This government has to live with the eternal shame of allowing bananas into Australia. Those bananas are coming in from the Philippines, where paraquat is put on the ground like the rest of us put fertilizer on the ground or like we would put a lawnmower over the ground. And who is using it? Mr Dole, Mr Del Monte and Mr Chiquita—the United Fruit Packaging Company of America.

If the United Fruit Packaging Company does not sound like a Spanish name or Del Monte or Dole do not sound like Spanish names—or Philippine names—it is because they are all American companies. The companies that produce bananas are not Philippine companies; they are American companies. So the American companies will sprinkle this stuff like confetti at a wedding all over the ground, we will bring those bananas in, we will be told that none of those bananas will have paraquat on them, and some people will suffer as a result of that irresponsibility.

I am not here tonight to talk about the 23 diseases they have that we do not have which will be sold on the shelves of our supermarkets. We appreciate what Coles and Woolworths have done. They have acted in a far more responsible manner than the government has on this issue. They might also be conscious of the fact that their customers may not like bananas coming in from the Philippines with paraquat all over them. Maybe they have some respect for their customers. Not only will the bananas have paraquat on them, they will also have many diseases and many spores that we do not have in this country. Those banana peels will be thrown onto rubbish heaps and those spores, bacteria and diseases will proliferate in this country—a country which, at the present moment, has a clean green image. Obviously if you bring things into this country from countries that throw paraquat around like we sprinkle salt on our chips you are going to deal with people who are very irresponsible indeed.

We are treating a symptom here in a most peculiar manner. We are attempting to suppress the symptom, and we are doing it with a most peculiar free-market, fundamentalist approach by dangling some sort of a carrot because we are not game to actually tell a big chemical company what to do. We are not game to tell oil or chemical companies what to do. In fact, it is very hard to find any way in which this government—or, I might add, the previous government—has stood up at all to the big corporations on what they want. We believe what they tell us and we do what they tell us to do. We act in accordance with their wishes at all times. In the end, the effect is suicide.

In North Queensland, we have seen the previous government and the current government do untold damage to the prawn and fish farming industry; the grape industry; the peanut industry; the tobacco industry, which they have closed down completely; the timber industry, which they have almost closed down completely; the durian industry, which is in a very serious situation; the fishing industry, which they have almost closed down completely; and the rice industry. Now we have terminal inaction with the sugar industry being left out of the free trade agreement and the decision last week to allow bananas into this country, in spite of the government's own body rejecting it totally last year.

There are some 13 mainland Aboriginal communities in Queensland in which some 20,000 or 30,000 Australians live. In those areas they are not allowed to own land, to own businesses, to own cattle or to own anything. When the possibility of earning a living is taken away, people lose hope. When they have no hope, people—as they do on the American Indian reserves—simply drink themselves to death or destroy themselves in some other way. It is an ugly truth, but it needs to be told. A lot of suicides happen in those areas and those communities. When you take away a person's right to make a living—whether it is in the prawn, fish farming, grape, peanut, tobacco, timber, dairying, fishing, rice, durian, sugar, or banana industries—it is not surprising that they take gramoxone and kill themselves.

By suppressing the symptoms—as we are attempting to do here tonight—instead of attacking the causes, our conduct is reprehensible in the extreme and will be remembered in the history books as the years pass by. And so it should be remembered. If we unleashed all of those sentiments which were once abroad in this country and which are in our national anthem when we sing, `Golden soil and wealth for toil,' that would be a joke. Where is the golden soil and wealth for toil? It is a classic case of the very well-worn joke: child cruelty is giving your kids the farm.

Turning back the clock, in 1985 we expected to make $2,000 million from the prawn and fish farming industry. Many of our young people go to university and study marine science in the hope of having a job in this new and wonderful industry. Greenies—and I am not one, but my worthy colleague from Wollongong is—say that they do not like people trawling on the Great Barrier Reef or wherever. I acquiesce in that view, but the government has said, `All right, you can have prawn and fish farms.' When we started in 1985 we expected to catch up with Thailand and make $2,000 million a year in North Queensland by 2000. We have a longer and much more suitable coastline than Thailand. We did not get to $2,000 million, we did not get to $1,000 million and we did not get to $100 million; we only got to $55 million. Thailand was making $2,000 million way back in the year of Our Lord 1985.

We import into this country $233 million worth of prawn product every year. In Thailand, there is hope, excitement and very rapid economic growth. If you check up on where our growth is in the GDP area, you will see that it is in wholesaling, retailing, banking and financing. That is where the growth in GDP has occurred in this country. Going back to Thailand, it was making $2,000 million in the year of Our Lord 1985. It now makes over $8,000 million a year, and this country is still importing $233 million worth of prawns.

On many occasions in this place we have pleaded for the ethanol industry, which would return hope and growth to our sugar industry, clean up our environment, dramatically improve the health of people in the cities and give hope to our young people instead of the hopelessness that they confront now which makes them take this most deadly chemical. The young man in the electorate that I represent, to whom I referred earlier, had three young children and everything to look forward to. It took him, I think, three days to die a most terrible and painful death. Presumably he took that chemical knowing that its effect was irreversible. What sort of hopelessness and pain must these people be experiencing to cause them to take this step? There is a sort of free-market fundamentalist approach to this act. Are we going to dangle an economic carrot rather than quite rightly apply the stick to the chemical companies for not having put in the emetic in the first place?

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —Given the lateness of the hour I will be particularly brief in summing up the debate on the Customs Tariff Amendment (Paraquat Dichloride) Bill 2004. I have listened with great care to the comments made by my friend the member for Cunningham and the members for Kennedy and Kingston. The Customs Tariff Amendment (Paraquat Dichloride) Bill 2004 contains some very minimal amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1995. The bill provides for the classification of the chemical paraquat dichloride with an emetic added for safety reasons in section 29 of the Customs Tariff Act. This bill will ensure that the same duty rate of free will apply to paraquat dichloride with an added emetic as currently applies to paraquat dichloride with other permitted safety agents. It is a non-controversial bill. The member for Kingston already outlined the benefit of this particular chemical, and I commend the bill to the House.

—I should indicate to the House that it is after 9 p.m. but, given the fact that the debate is almost concluded, I do not intend to restrict opposition opportunities for participation in the adjournment debate and will proceed to put the question if there is no dissent.
