talk.start.para: —Tonight I would like to share with the House a good news story. It is a story about an area in the electorate of Shortland—a suburb called Windale, which in 1999 was identified as possibly the most disadvantaged area within the whole of Australia in a study that was conducted by Tony Vinson called `Unequal in life'. It looked at all the factors of social disadvantage—things such as long-term unemployment, low income, early school leaving, unskilled workers, low birth rates, child abuse, psychiatric hospital admissions, criminal convictions and so on. When those factors were weighed up Windale was found to be a very disadvantaged community.

speech.para: Four years ago the New South Wales government initiated a community renewal scheme in Windale. This scheme is now being managed by the Windale community. The management committee is responsible for supporting unemployed people, aged people, youth and sporting groups. Representatives from all these sectors of the community are involved in the management committee. They utilise the skills of members of the community and they are very much involved in mentoring and supporting each other through the community. The mentoring is conducted one-on-one, in groups or informally and is designed to meet the needs of the community.

I would like to pay particular attention to a program called Alcazar that is being run through the Windale Public School at the school community centre. This initiative involves a mentor program, which is an early intervention program for children who might experience challenges in kindergarten. The program began two years ago and is still running. The children in this program have had challenging behaviours where they may act out, including exhibiting violence, shyness and many other types of behaviour. The program trained people from the local community to mentor specific children and their families. The mentoring was initiated through a support playgroup and other activities.

In the first year, 10 children and their families anticipated. The children represented a variety of backgrounds and had a variety of challenging behaviours. Alcazar was able to initiate the program to build relationships with children and their families, and the outcomes were phenomenal. Of the 10 children that went to the preschool program, eight went into kindergarten and all but one were promoted to year 1. The one not promoted remained in kindergarten and successfully completed it last year. This program was implemented again in 2003 and it will be conducted again in the future. Another program that is being run through Alcazar is the home start program, which operates with local residents trained to mentor and support young parents and their families. There is another program called `engaging fathers'. This has had some amazing outcomes, where many fathers participating in programs at Alcazar are playing a very important part within the Windale school. They participate in the breakfast club and in various community groups and committees that operate within the school.

This shows how important it is to build the capacity of communities to give support to families in need. It also shows how important mentoring is and what an asset it is to the community. Without these mentoring projects there are a number of families within this area that would not have achieved the outcomes and would not have the hope for the future that they now have. This mentoring program has been phenomenal. The cooperation and the fine work of everyone involved with Alcazar should be recognised. I would particularly like to recognise the work of Wendy Lawrence, who is a very dedicated and committed worker at Alcazar and the driving force behind the success of the program. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This evening I rise to speak about a very important matter concerning residents in parts of Mitcham, Ringwood and Vermont North of my electorate. In the last couple of months it has come to my attention that there is a proposal for a waste transfer station to operate from a site on Heatherdale Road, Ringwood. The operators of the site, Eastern Recycling, have relocated their business from a nearby industrial estate. The new Heatherdale Road location is within an industrial estate; however, unlike the former location the new site is located, according to some sources, 300 metres from existing residential properties. As you can imagine, many of those residents have health fears, apart from concerns about the traffic congestion and noise that go with such a site.

speech.para: I would like to bring to the House's attention the contempt the state ALP members of parliament have shown the people of this area. In late 2003, the Victorian government made a $450,000 grant to Eastern Recycling for its proposed relocation. However, when faced with a backlash from concerned residents, the state ALP members for Bayswater and Silvan Province went to ground and quickly distanced themselves from the decision. The state member for Mitcham was asleep on the job and not even aware of the issue or the resulting backlash by residents until it was uncovered by my office through a public meeting.

Of great concern to the residents is how the operator of the facility was allowed to continue to function despite a rejection by the Maroondah City Council of a planning permit application. The operator claimed it was not required and proceeded to open the new facility. This dispute was listed for hearing before the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal and is still taking place. Strangely, the Victorian government's grant was forthcoming during local council objections and the VCAT deliberations.

I was first informed of this issue by the state manager of the neighbouring Wridgways removalists on Heatherdale Road. He had received little interest from local state Labor MPs when he had raised the issue. It was clear to me that a majority of residents had been kept in the dark by their representatives, including their local government, the Whitehorse City Council. In an attempt to facilitate an open discussion between all parties, I convened a public meeting on 22 January for residents and businesses within the immediate area. Although it was at the height of the Christmas holiday period, approximately 200 people overwhelmingly vented their frustration at the lack of information received on this issue. It caught everyone by surprise, not least of course the representatives in that area. All were appreciative of the meeting having been organised and of the attempt by my office to out the issue.

At the public meeting two resolutions were unanimously passed—first, that the public meeting endorse ward councillors, nominated residents' representatives and other concerned parties to seek a community deputation from the Victorian Minister for the Environment, the Hon. John Thwaites MP, and the Victorian Minister for Local Government, the Hon. Candy Broad MLC, as soon as practicable, and, second, that the meeting endorse the establishment of a residents action group. Whilst the action group has been established, the deputations are still being sought, and I trust that Minister Thwaites at least has the courtesy to meet the Heatherdale Road Residents Action Group.

I congratulate local residents Mr Gary Cooper and Mr Dennis Burley on marshalling the local residents into a vocal and concerned residents action group. The residents action group has been vigilant in documenting transgressions by the operator, including noise levels at one, two and three o'clock in the morning, the constant noise of waste bins and dumpmasters coming into the place and the dust and traffic congestion that go with them. The residents are of course concerned for health reasons, particularly about the acceptance by the operators, contrary to their claims, of `putrefaction' material—I think that is the word that is often used.

Emerging from this issue are the clouded requirements and statutory obligations of waste transfer operators. The design and location of the Eastern Recycling Heatherdale Road site is of concern, as evidently there is a lack of clear and binding planning legislation. Of particular concern is Victorian state government agency EcoRecycle Victoria's detailed Guide to Best Practice at Waste Transfer Stations. These loosely worded and non-statutory guidelines offer room for potential conflict, which was demonstrated at the Heatherdale Road site. EcoRecycle Victoria is not effectively powered to enforce its own guidelines; rather, it offers general advice and information. I recommend the establishment of a national set of clear and binding guidelines for the management of waste transfer facilities. It is certainly worth considering this issue at future COAG forums. Clearly, modern state-of-the-art waste transfer and recycling facilities are inherently positive for the community. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On this the eighth anniversary of the election of the Howard government it is timely to assess the government's record on matters of truth. The verdict of any reasonable person is that the government is constitutionally incapable of telling the truth. All Australians recall the Prime Minister's pledge that he would never, ever introduce a GST and they know his famous pre-election distinction between core and non-core promises. Certainly they remember his claim of 9 October 2001, just before the last election, that asylum seekers threw their children overboard. But do they recall the Prime Minister's 14 October 1999 assurance:

quote.para: There will be no $100,000 university fees under this government.

speech.para: Do they recall his false statement in parliament that he did not meet his friend Dick Honan to discuss ethanol? The litany of Liberal lies is seemingly endless. Challenging the Prime Minister for a record number of false statements is the Treasurer. In referring to the legislated tax cuts of the early 1990s the Treasurer told this parliament on no less than 13 occasions that the Keating government:

quote.para: ... did not pay $1 to one person for one day.

speech.para: The Treasurer made this false claim in parliament on 14 May 2003, 11 May 2000, 6 March 2000, 8 December 1999, 13 May 1999, 23 March 1999, 15 February 1999, 9 February 1999, 8 December 1998, 30 November 1995, 28 November 1995, 23 October 1995 and 10 May 1995. The truth is that the first instalment of tax cuts was brought forward—paid early—at a full-year cost of $2.9 billion in 1994-95 dollars. In present day dollars that equates to more than $3.5 billion. Compare that $3.5 billion with the Treasurer's tax cuts announced in the last budget costing $2.4 billion. Not only did Labor pay tax cuts early but they were more than $1 billion greater than the Treasurer's tax cuts announced in last year's budget. But the Treasurer claims no tax cuts were ever paid by Labor. He told the National Press Club on 10 May 2000:

quote.para: ... there is a very large proportion of the Australian public which has no experience of income tax cuts. If you've been in the workforce for 10 years, you've not known what an income tax cut is. ... And I was thinking back through my own experience of taxation policy, of my own experience and I can vouch for someone who has been in the workforce for about 20 years. Was that whenever we seemed to get to the barrier on income tax cuts, for some reason or another they were never paid.

speech.para: That is what the Treasurer claimed. Now for the truth. Labor cut personal income tax rates seven times: in November 1984, December 1986, July 1987, July 1989, January 1990, January 1991 and November 1993. In those seven tax cuts Labor gave back all of bracket creep and more, something this government has never come close to doing. The second instalment of those tax cuts was converted to superannuation co-contributions worth $4 billion which this government, after promising to keep, cancelled in its 1996 budget.
The Treasurer's incapacity to tell the truth extends to his claims about budget surpluses. He told parliament on 10 May 2000:

quote.para: First of all, we put the budget into surplus on a headline basis, which the Labor Party never did. Then we say, `We ought to put the budget into a surplus on an underlying basis', which the Labor Party never did.

speech.para: The truth is that Labor produced headline surpluses in 1987-88, 1988-89, 1989-90 and 1990-91. Labor produced underlying surpluses in 1972-73, 1973-74, 1974-75, 1987-88, 1988-89, 1989-90 and 1990-91. The fact is that this government is constitutionally incapable of telling the truth. In the time that I have there is no capacity to go through all of these statements by the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and other ministers. Maybe I should leave the last words for the Prime Minister. He said on 25 August 1995:

quote.para: ... truth is absolute, truth is supreme, truth is never disposable in national political life.

speech.para: Hypocrisy, thy name is Liberal.

talk.start.para: —This makes an interesting backdrop for issues of imputation.

—Last Friday, 27 February, I visited a great many small businesses in the town of Somerville. Somerville is a town built around young families, people involved in trades and in their own businesses, people who commute to the city and people who work on the Mornington Peninsula. There were two overriding messages from the discussions I had with people in these small businesses. First, they had a deep concern about opportunities for youth and the problems of youth unemployment and youth activities within the town of Somerville and, second—this was a related issue—they had a real concern that the much promised Somerville Secondary College, for which so many people fought and for which I was proud to be one of the advocates, may not be delivered on time. The school was promised by the state government 18 months ago after a heavy campaign which involved overturning the education department's own figures once we had gathered together the figures, through the Parliamentary Library, for the town of Somerville.

speech.para: Since that time the ground has never been broken. Yet the pledge is that the Somerville Secondary College will open for business to take year 7 and 8 students from Somerville in 2005. We know that there are only a few short weeks before we lose the opportunity to allow students in at the beginning of next year. This has created a genuine and real uncertainty for parents within Somerville, Baxter, Pearcedale, Tyabb and the surrounding area who have enrolled their children and who are relying on the availability of the college.

The college will serve two purposes. Firstly, it will serve as an educational centre for children and youths throughout Somerville and, secondly, it will play a key role in providing a community resource—a community centre—to deal with some of those after-hours questions of youth aimlessness. It will provide social outlets and opportunities for drama, sports and communal activities.

Against that background, what concerns all of the people who I spoke to is that the school which was promised may not be delivered on time. If that is the case, there will be two consequences: it will be a blow to not only the parents and the students but also the community. The community fought hard for this school, fought hard to preserve the land and then fought hard to win the commitment that this school would be brought into being.

On behalf of the community, I make this request of and this statement to the state government of Victoria: please start construction of the Somerville Secondary College now. We have only a matter of weeks for this school to begin if it is going to be open in time for students in February 2005. It is a critical window of opportunity. After 18 months, there are all sorts of excuses. But fortunately, and as a surprise, the state government has not been able to blame the federal government because funding has been provided—$1.8 million of federal funding has been pledged to that school. Only this week we received a pledge from the federal education minister, Dr Brendan Nelson, for an additional $1.2 million, taking the total federal pledge to $1.8 million.

The state has said that it will put in $5 million. Yet when the federal government provided this $1.8 million it decreased its own amount to $3.2 million. So the students can get as much federal money as they want but the town will not be any better off because for every dollar that the Commonwealth puts in the state reduces its own amount by that amount. So we have fought and achieved a commitment of $1.8 million only to see that very amount deducted from the state's pledged contribution of $5 million.

Two key things have to happen. Firstly, the state must commence construction immediately. No matter what excuse they raise, they have had 18 months to reach the point of constructing a school for the students, the community and the parents of Somerville, Baxter and Tyabb. Secondly, they should provide the full $5 million which they pledged, in addition to the $1.8 million from the Commonwealth. The $1.8 million which they have deducted is the difference between the school having an arts centre, an oval and full facilities and not having them. Build the school and build it now. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It would be useful if the member for Flinders were to spend more time representing the interests of his constituency on the Point Nepean matter. Having holidayed in his electorate and having stayed in the town of Flinders, I have found that the level of representation on those matters was somewhat lacking.

speech.para: For the past five years, I have hosted the Griffith Australia Day Awards on Brisbane's Southside. The Griffith Australia Day Awards were established in 1999 because there was a need to recognise the contribution of local residents who work tirelessly for the Southside community without reward or recognition. Too many Australians spend their whole lives putting back into the community without any appropriate form of recognition. That is why, this year, we held the fifth annual Griffith Australia Day Awards at Carina. I would like to congratulate the award recipients and briefly mention, in the parliament here in Canberra today, their service to the Southside community.

Beulah Anderson's 10 years of volunteering at Bulimba State School culminated in two `highly commended' Queensland road safety awards for establishing and monitoring the two `stop, drop and go' zones outside Bulimba State School. Ron Baker, as an architect, has dedicated himself to preserving Brisbane's heritage—restoring everything from Brisbane's older buildings to the Kookaburra Queen—to safeguard the character of our city. In her 25 years as secretary of the Balmoral Uniting Community Centre, Patricia Beattie has seen the centre evolve from a volunteer organisation into a successful registered community care program.

Lynette Boyd has been secretary of the Yeronga Australian Football Club for 16 years continuously. Allan Carr has given 10 years voluntary service to the East Brisbane Men's Bowls Club and the Carina Meals on Wheels program. Allan has humbly declined efforts to formally recognise his contribution. As president of the Adoption Privacy Protection Group Inc., Rita Carroll has made a significant difference to those whose lives have been adversely affected by the adoption process. As head of the Bulimba State School Grounds Committee, Fred Collishaw ensured Bulimba State School's recent win in the regional and state finals of the Comalco Greenest and Healthiest Schools competition.

Eileen Colliss's 23 years of service to the Carina Meals on Wheels program have been invaluable. Through her service, the program and the Southside community have gained enormous benefit, and her contribution has been unwavering. During his seven years as area co-ordinator for Annerley Neighbourhood Watch 10, Ivan Costello doorknocked to raise $1,500 for breast cancer research. He also initiated a skate park at O'Grady Park, Fairfield. Betty Craghill has been a volunteer for 17 years for the Carina Meals on Wheels program, in addition to the nine years she has served on the committee.

Cherie Crane contributes enormously to the community, beyond her professional duty with the Morningside Police Division, by improving relations between the police and the community. Rosamond Dalgleish established the Burnet Swamp Creek Freecs, an environmental group striving to protect and restore the waterway corridor adjacent to the Stones Corner Kindergarten. Barbara Edwards has donated 16 years to the Carina Meals on Wheels program and also serves the Carina and Districts Committee on the Ageing.

Gillian Greenhill has contributed widely to various community groups, culminating in the compilation of the publication The Naming of Streets in Wynnum Manly and Districts. Joan Hackles has given over 33 years to the community, providing services through bowling, including establishing the first disability league in Queensland in 1980. Diane Hill has become an institution in the Girl Guides since 1982, serving as District Commissioner and other positions within the Girl Guides. Holly James's efforts beyond her role in the police force have created a more effective link between local police and students.

Daphne Johnson has donated 50 years to the local community through the Country Women's Association at Morningside, serving as president and treasurer. Sotirios Koutsoukos has maintained 40 years of service to the cultural, religious and philanthropic needs of both Greek and non-Greek communities in Brisbane. Gordon Nicholson's love of soccer, community and support for Christian attitudes in youth culminated with his being awarded life membership of the Queensland Churches Soccer Referees Association.

Peter Stafford contributed to the establishment and maintenance of the `stop, drop and go' zone at Bulimba State School, earning him two Queensland road safety awards. As part of the St Mary's Church community, Karyn Walsh has dedicated her life to helping the homeless. Brian Walton's cancer diagnosis saw him establish the Quality of Life Cancer Support Group, offering non-judgmental, compassionate care for cancer sufferers.

As a founding member of the Morningside Development Association, Alastair Ward's commitment has ensured the ongoing strength of our local community. For 50 years, Evan Wegner has donated his time to teach religious education, to chair the Balmoral State High School Chaplaincy Support Group and to pioneer Bulimba State School's current religious education cooperative program. Florence Yapp has raised over $15,000 for cancer research through the years that she nursed her husband through the disease, and she has raised further funds for St Luke's Nursing Service. Shirley Zech is a great all-rounder, donating time to numerous organisations including Lifeline, Brisbane State High School, the Brisbane City Mission, the Red Cross and Meals on Wheels. All these Australians should be commended on their service to the community.

talk.start.para: —Every member of this House would be conscious of the older Australians in their communities. In my own community of Wentworth, the percentage of older people is one of the highest in the country. Tonight I will talk about increasing tax benefits for older Australians, particularly those of pensionable age and above. In light of the demographic changes that have occurred in Australia, to which the Treasurer has drawn attention in recent times, the proportion of the population aged 65 and over has increased relatively slowly over the last 40 years. But we are projecting that over the next 40 years this will nearly double, and in 2042 almost one in every four Australians will be aged 65 or over.

speech.para: I want to propose a measure to the House tonight, and I would encourage those who are looking at budgetary outcomes in the forthcoming round of discussions to consider it. In short, I want to propose that the tax threshold for people of pensionable age and over be doubled and that those benefits accrue as part of the tax cuts which I hope will be introduced at the next budget for all Australians. Of course, a tax cut for all Australians as the dividend of efficient government is, of itself, a priority that all Liberals would agree with, but I would like to see those tax cuts for older Australians given particular priority in the manner that I have mentioned.

It has been suggested that there are already provisions in the fiscal arrangements of this country which benefit older Australians in a way that does not assist others. It is true that the SATO scheme—the Senior Australians tax offset—permits an offset of tax liability up to $20,500 for a full dispensation and, thereafter, a sliding scale up to $38,340 for singles and $29,622 for each member of a couple. Those are valuable benefits for older Australians, but the measure that I am proposing is a supplement to that particular measure. What the Treasurer has recently sought to do—and I highly commend what he has done and his recent announcements about these matters—is to encourage older Australians to stay in work and allow them the choice to make a decision for themselves, in their own best interests, to make their lifestyles in their older age more comfortable and more desirable.

talk.start.para: —It is 9.30 p.m., but I will allow the member for Wentworth to make some concluding remarks.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. What I am proposing is simply this: if the tax threshold were doubled, at a cost estimated by my research at $400 million, that would give older Australians the incentive to continue to work. In other words, if we want to get serious about getting older Australians to work—if wewant to encourage them and give them that option—that is a measure which I believe would be in the public interest.

talk.start.para: to move:

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Lindsay) took the chair at 4.05 p.m.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 1 March, on motion by Mr Slipper:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: upon which Mr McMullan moved by way of amendment:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the government for its budget waste and mismanagement, and wrong priorities which have resulted in:
(1) a costly Medicare `safety net' which does not protect families from increasing health costs and declining levels of bulk billing;
(2) inadequate funding and higher fees for students seeking access to higher education;
(3) a growing number of families who are financially squeezed and trying to balance work and family; and

talk.start.para: (Mr Lindsay)—Before I call the member for Braddon, I advise the Main Committee that it was agreed in the House that a general cognate debate be allowed with the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 covering the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004.

—I rise to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 and the cognate bills. On Tuesday, 20 January the Prime Minister carried out a diversionary tactic, not surprisingly, which became not just a diversionary tactic but a divisive tactic by attacking public schools, teachers in those schools and, by implication, students and their families in those schools with his disgraceful attack on the so-called valueless systems in our state schools and the provision of antiseptic values. He charged that our schools are filled with politically correct teachers and that our curriculum is charged with political correctness. On 26 January on a Current Affair, Ray Martin asked the Prime Minister:

quote.para: Why did you begin this year with such divisive comments about public education?

speech.para: John Howard replied:

quote.para: Nothing divisive. I was just asked a question as to why I thought an increasing number of people were wanting to send their children to independent schools and I gave some of the reasons. I didn't make a generalised attack on government schools.

speech.para: Ray Martin went on:

quote.para: What did you mean though ... in terms of `antiseptic' and what are the values missing from government schools?

speech.para: The Prime Minister said:

quote.para: Well, you know, people come to me and say all sorts of things. And I mentioned some of them. I don't have time on this programme to go through all of them and I'll develop some of the things during the week.

speech.para: Ray Martin asked:

quote.para: It looks like you've thrown a bit of a cracker and then stepped away.

speech.para: The Prime Minister replied:

quote.para: No, no. I never throw crackers and step away. I mean ... what I said I meant. Don't think for a minute that I'm stepping away from what I said.

speech.para: Ray Martin then asked:

quote.para: What's antiseptic mean?

speech.para: The Prime Minister said, `Well, you know' and on it went. Ray Martin finally said:

quote.para: But don't you seriously think that government schools don't have values?

speech.para: The Prime Minister replied that he did not have time to go through it. So I spent some of my own time to find out what the Prime Minister meant by valueless schools, by political correctness in the curriculum and by the provision of an antiseptic atmosphere in our schools. I looked for proof. One of the values that I think is very important is that you provide evidence in a reasoned debate for your argument. Has the Prime Minister said anything since? Not a single word. There has not been a single word to substantiate the disgraceful charges that he levels: `Some people talk to me and I have to report what they say.' We can all bet what happened. He called the reporters in and said, `Listen, cop this. It might divert attention away from the fact university places are not available to students.' So it is about diverting attention, making education divisive and using it as a diversionary tactic from the higher education agenda.

Of course, on cue, came the Prime Minister's willing acolytes, who are on the Right on anything dealing with so-called values in public education. Of course, the member for Gippsland popped in with some really edifying comments that education in public schools is value-free, hostile or, at best, apathetic to Australian heritage and values—whatever that meant. At this stage, the member for Gippsland was the acting federal education minister. Then there was the member for Warringah—the boxing monk—but you would expect that. I am sad to say that the member for Herbert rushed in with his unsubstantiated comments and Senator Lightfoot rushed in, as he does, to protect the Prime Minister from anyone who might possibly be harassing his presence or his views.

But it did cause division, not just in the community but also in his own party. That is not something the Prime Minister is used to, but we have seen examples of it more recently. It caused division because enlightened persons such as the members for Adelaide, Hindmarsh, Pearce and Macquarie came out and basically said, `This is arrant nonsense.' To claim that public schools are valueless is the same as saying that private schools are valueless—arrant nonsense. They at least were prepared to stand up publicly and say so.

So it was not just the superannuation meeting or the Clarke report on veteran entitlements that saw divisions in the Liberal Party caucus room coming to the fore; the same applied to this comment on public education by the Prime Minister. I acknowledge the comments by those members of the coalition who were prepared to stand up to the statements of arrant nonsense by the Prime Minister and those other members I mentioned.

I thought it was best reflected by the cartoonists—as is their wont. In the Australian on 20 January 2004 there was a cartoon which I know I cannot show at the moment but I will try to describe it. It showed our Prime Minister with a sign behind him saying, `Howard's way—a federal government nation-building project.' In front of him is an earthquake fault line, and there is a little sign on the other side of the highway heading off in the distance saying, `Divided country'. That is exactly what those comments did. They were needlessly hurtful, silly comments not substantiated by evidence.

It was not just me who was disgusted by those comments. Many people throughout Australia—even principals of private schools—thought what a worthless debate the Prime Minister had brought about. I attended a number of school excellence ceremonies and of course the Prime Minister's comments featured at those ceremonies. People were disgusted and hurt by the comments. I would like to quote from an address at an evening of excellence at one of the schools in my electorate of Braddon—and a very good school at that. The principal said:

quote.para: I felt that tonight, of all nights, I couldn't let their comments go unanswered or our students and parents think that the schools that have produced the wonderful young people we will see tonight are in any way sub-standard or without values.

speech.para: Fancy having to have this discussion in the first place. The principal went on to analyse why they believed the Prime Minister made those comments and said:

quote.para: If that is the case—

speech.para: that is, to bring about division and diversion—

quote.para: I thought I would take the time tonight to explain the values that I think underlie the academic and personal relationships we have at (our school) and ask the question `if not these values, then which?'

speech.para: The Prime Minister was asked several times: `What values are you talking about? What values don't exist in our public schools that you believe should exist?' Of course he did not answer. The principal went on:

quote.para: Our primary concerns ... are, I think, fivefold and they relate closely to Howard Gardner's view of schools. We are concerned with the truth. Not the truth that gave us `children overboard', `weapons of mass destruction' and now `valueless schools'—but how we determine what is false or misleading and, importantly, what we do with that knowledge. Secondly, we are concerned with beauty and it is from this concern we model not just our arts curriculum but our deep concern and empathy for the environment and the planet, surely the most beautiful and fragile of things that we have in our care. Thirdly, we are concerned with morality—what is good and what is right. This is not the morality of politics but the morality of how people should be treated and treat others.

speech.para: He goes on to say, fourthly:

quote.para: We are concerned with educational excellence, not only of the academic elite but of all students. This comes from our deeply held views that teachers make a difference and all students can learn. Finally, we are concerned, in State schools with equality. We take everyone into our state school system.

speech.para: He says that at their school:

quote.para: ... alongside the students you will meet tonight—

speech.para: and it was a night of excellence, I would remind you—

quote.para: with TE scores as good as any in the country, you will find blind students, Downs Syndrome students, homeless students, students with mental illness and physical impairment. You will find students who are poor, students who are rich, students who are black and students who are white. In this melting pot, whose cultural values are the ones we must follow and explore and support? You and I know that we cannot favour one set of cultural values over another but what we can do is support the universal values that make up a decent, just and humane society. We will not play the politicians values game where we somehow favour a set of values held by a small political sub-set. We are concerned with weightier things ... with truth, beauty, morality, excellence and equality, and these threads have run through the education that every student here tonight has received. They own these values because they are also the values of their parents, their relatives, their churches, their friends and their employers. They are also the values of each and every one of their teachers.

speech.para: That was in part the address that was given that night in response to the Prime Minister's arrant nonsense on 20 January 2004. But, when I think about the charge levelled by the Prime Minister and then by the member for Gippsland and his minions, I say to myself, `I have had the privilege of being involved in public education for 25 years of my working life.' Were the institutions that I was involved in, the students, the curriculum and my colleagues valueless? Were we politically correct? Did we not teach what we believed was right and wrong and at least teach people to make their own decisions about what was right and wrong? Were we apathetic to the Australian heritage and values? The answer is no, definitely not.

I did a bit of research, as you do on these matters, particularly when you are made anxious by them. Where better to go than to the government, because it preaches values and principles and traditions—on and on? Of course, our current education minister is very good at that. He just parted with $300,000-odd for values and principles and civics in education—good; so be it. There was a values education study published in November 2003. It had a top 10 hit parade of values. Tolerance and understanding, respect, responsibility, social justice, excellence, care, inclusion and trust, honesty, freedom and being ethical were the top 10 values. The night of excellence report by the principal of my local school, it was replete with that. In that school they do not need to read the values education study of November 2003 to find out what these values might be.

I looked at the education website in my own state. I said to myself: `I have been out of the system for a while. What exactly is underpinning the curriculum? What is underpinning the important social values in our schools today? What does it mean to be publicly educated in Tasmania today?' What I found on their web site is a really interesting program called Essential Learnings which was kicked off in December 2000—not November 2003 but December 2000—by our then state education minister, the Hon. Paula Wriedt. I looked to that to see what the purposes of the essential learnings were and what the values were that underpinned these essential learnings. And I said to myself, `Will I find values there? Will I find principles that I can subscribe to and that I believe reflect the so-called Australian tradition and values?' So what did I find? It says:

quote.para: We are guided by this core set of values.

speech.para: This core set of values that underline our essential learnings includes:

quote.para: Connectedness, which includes developing a sense of community through friendship, care, compassion, cooperation, acceptance, belonging and sharing.

speech.para: I have ticked it for pretty good values—Aussie values too. Another core value is:

quote.para: Resilience, which includes recognising strengths and maximising potential; developing self-management, self-confidence and self-respect; and nurturing optimism, perseverance and wellbeing.

speech.para: Tick! Another is:

quote.para: Achievement, which includes attaining personal success in a range of human endeavours, pursuing individual excellence and displaying pride and satisfaction in personal achievement.

speech.para: Tick! Another is:

quote.para: Creativity, which includes valuing original ideas, demonstrating enterprise and innovation, and engaging with and responding to the aesthetic qualities of the natural and constructed world.

speech.para: There is no economic bottom line there, but aesthetic values—tick! Another is integrity. Now, what does this mean?

quote.para: ... which includes acting honestly, ethically, and consistently.

speech.para: Tick! Another is:

quote.para: Responsibility, which includes accepting both individual and collective responsibility and contributing to sustainable community development.

speech.para: So values regarding others as well as values regarding the self. And the final value is:

quote.para: Equity, which includes developing tolerance and a commitment to social justice—

speech.para: Is this the problem area?—

quote.para: acknowledging diversity, respecting difference and encouraging distinctiveness.

speech.para: Now, that is under threat. It is almost politically correct now not to be tolerant of others. But I gave that a tick, because I think equity is pretty fundamental in our character. So what were the purposes of all these essential learnings? I thought I found some values there, long before the values education study of November 2003. The purposes behind the essential learnings are:

quote.para: Learning to relate, participate and care ...
Learning to live full, healthy lives—

speech.para: in every sense of the word. They continue:

quote.para: Learning to create purposeful futures—

speech.para: being part of the future, not just for yourself but with others and for others. They continue:

quote.para: Learning to act ethically—

speech.para: not simply knowing what is right and wrong, but being able to justify it and able to justify moral practices. That is a skill. They continue:

quote.para: Learning to learn.

speech.para: That is absolutely essential to being a participating citizen. The final purpose is:

quote.para: Learning to think, know and understand.

speech.para: These are the purposes underpinning the curriculum of essential learnings in Tasmania, based on the values of connectedness, resilience, achievement, creativity, integrity, responsibility and equity. Is this the valueless, politically correct world in public education that the Prime Minister spoke of? Well, if this is valueless, then I am proud to be part of it, and I am proud for both of my sons to have gone through this system of public education. The arrant nonsense that was peddled by the Prime Minister is a disgrace and an embarrassment as is that of all those minions that joined him.

We had in the House yesterday from the member for Sturt the feigned indignation which the government are renowned for—the wringing of hands and beating of breasts on anything that is pursued by this side. And at this stage, the member for Sturt was attacking the member for Jagajaga. Listen to this hypocrisy! The member for Sturt said:

quote.para: The member for Jagajaga should come into this House and apologise for the fear campaign that she, hand in hand with the AEU, has waged, a campaign that has upset parents and children and created division in the community—and all for what? Grubby short-term political gain.

speech.para: And on it went. Fancy, they:

quote.para: ... upset parents and children and created division in the community—and all for what? Grubby short-term political gain.

speech.para: The Prime Minister should come into the House and apologise to the people of Australia—to the students, parents, teachers and educators involved in public education and, indeed, in private education—because the implication was that private schools are value-full and public schools are not. He is a disgrace and he should apologise to the people of Australia.

talk.start.para: —Here we are again, with more appropriation bills. But Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 are, I think, the last will and testament of the Howard government. What a dreary little set of documents they are! As I have observed previously while speaking about appropriation legislation, this government takes the prize for the dullest legislation program I think I have ever experienced in my time in this House. Since the government was re-elected in 2001, we have seen a combination of re-runs of legislation that various ministers failed to have passed in previous parliaments and some lacklustre minor legislation that really does not serve to achieve very much. If ever Australia needed a change of government and an injection of vitality and enthusiasm, it is certainly now.

speech.para: I have looked at what has been proposed in these bills to see if there was anything to grab the imagination—anything that would be worth debating and that was not just pandering to the dreariness of the government. Amazingly, I found an issue which did strike a chord with me. It is to do with the Australian Federal Police. The Australian Federal Police, as I am sure most of us are aware, comes under the Attorney-General's portfolio. It has an important international role. While the $47 million equity projection proposed in Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 is in relation to the deployment of the AFP in Papua New Guinea and operations in the Solomon Islands and people-trafficking issues, there is another role that the AFP is currently performing, and that is on the island of Cyprus.

Since 1964 Australia has deployed police to Cyprus as part of a United Nations peacekeeping mission. Originally, it was a joint Commonwealth-state arrangement, but now it is just the AFP. Fifteen AFP personnel are currently in Cyprus contributing to the maintenance of law and order in the buffer zone between the Greek and Turkish Cypriot communities. To give a bit more background: UNFICYP was established in March 1964 to prevent communal violence between the Greek and Turkish Cypriots after there had been a breakdown of law on the island resulting from an attempted coup by members of the national guard and a lot of fighting between the Turkish and Greek communities.

The role of the organisation was later expanded to include supervision of a ceasefire between the Turkish army and the Greek Cypriot national guard. UNFICYP also includes a civil police component which is called UNCIVPOL. Australia's commitment began in 1964 with 40 policemen of the Commonwealth Police. Police from all states were seconded to the Commonwealth Police, which became the Australian Federal Police in 1979 and had its own personnel. The number of Australian police serving in Cyprus increased to 50 in 1967 before decreasing to 16 in 1975. In May 1988 the first policewoman began service in Cyprus, with many policewomen serving since then.

As I mentioned earlier, Australia's commitment is currently 15 AFP officers serving for a period of six months. Three Australians—Sergeant Ian Donald Ward, Sergeant Lew Thomas and Inspector Paul Hackett—have died on duty with the Australian Federal Police in Cyprus. I am sure that all members will join with me in paying tribute to these officers. There are always risks involved with this type of mission. I believe that Australia's reputation as a peacekeeper is generally good. While three losses are three too many, I firmly believe that one could realistically have expected there to be a lot more loss of life over the almost 40 years that there has been an Australian police presence on the green line in Cyprus. That it has been contained to three is remarkable in the circumstances. These are dangerous jobs that are fulfilled by our police officers. They are not just overseas jaunts. I have had first-hand knowledge of their work, as I have visited the AFP contingent on the green line in Cyprus up at the airport and along the green line itself on three separate occasions. As I said earlier, their job is not an easy one.

There have been persistent rumours in recent times that the government is considering withdrawing Australia's AFP contingent from the United Nations peacekeeping force in Cyprus. So strong were these rumours last year that the Cypriot community in Sydney, many of whom live in my electorate of Watson, asked me to try and discover if there was any truth behind the rumours. I wrote to the Minister for Justice and Customs in October last year seeking his advice. I pointed out how much our presence in Cyprus since 1964 has been appreciated by the people of Cyprus on both sides of the green line—which it certainly has been. I also pointed out that the overall cost to the Australian economy has been well worth it in terms of the goodwill created and the excellent reputation earned by our national peacekeepers in Cyprus. Furthermore, I told the minister that I share the concern of the Cypriot community about the future of the Australian Federal Police contingent in Cyprus and I sought his advice about the government's intentions in that regard.

For some time in the 1990s I was a member of an IPU committee looking at the Cyprus issue. As indicated earlier in my speech, I visited there a number of times, the two most recent occasions being in September 1996 as a member of a parliamentary delegation with my colleagues the member for Grayndler and the member for Adelaide and also in July 2001. While I was there then, I met the Chief of Mission of United Nations operations in Cyprus, the acting special representative of the Secretary-General, Kofi Annan. So for many years I have taken an active interest in Cyprus and in its future. Thus I was more than happy to take up the concerns of my constituents with the minister last year. The reply that I received from the minister in November 2003 confirmed the view that a review would be taking place but gave no indication of a likely time. However, the minister did say that the review would be of all options concerning the Australian contribution to UNIFCYP as well as East Timor, the Solomon Islands and Papua New Guinea.

I do not want to read too much into the fact that additional funding is now being sought in these appropriation bills currently before us for the AFP deployment in Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands, but obviously a decision has been taken to commit additional AFP resources in those two areas. I hope this does not mean a diminution of our commitment in Cyprus, particularly at the moment when for the first time after many years it seems there will soon be a resolution of the unsatisfactory situation of the divided island. A breakthrough in the United Nations in New York was reported in the Australian on 17 February this year. The article said that this breakthrough has:

quote.para: ... created a real chance of reuniting the island before it joins the European Union on May 1.
For the first time, the two sides in Cyprus, divided since 1974, have agreed to a procedure that cannot collapse or grind to a halt.

speech.para: The article continued:

quote.para: Decisive negotiations begin this week in the capital, Nicosia, on a UN blueprint that would reunite the island in a loose federation of two largely autonomous areas with a central government. A deal would involve territory handovers and large population shifts.

speech.para: As members would be aware, when the island was divided in 1974 the Cypriot community of Greek descent moved to the south of the island and the people of Turkish descent moved to the north of the island into the Turkish zone that was invaded by the Turkish army. The article continued:

quote.para: The breakthrough came when the Greek Cypriot President Tassos Papadopoulos and his Turkish Cypriot counterpart, Rauf Denktash, agreed that UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan can rule on any disputes they cannot settle before a final deal goes to separate referendums in April.

Mr Annan said that there was now a real chance that before the first of May Cyprus will be reunited. US mediator Thomas Weston was even more emphatic: “It is almost certain now that there will be a settlement on the island of Cyprus.”

speech.para: I could not be more delighted at this news, and I certainly hope that the reports in the newspapers were not overly optimistic. There has been a long history of disputes on the island. There has been a long history of hopeful breakthroughs that do not result in anything. So I hope that now people of goodwill on both sides—the Greek and the Turkish Cypriots—will show an equal generosity of spirit in having the matter settled, because the real hope of any solution lies with the people who live there. The ordinary people in Cyprus want a solution. The Turkish government have to come to the party and insist that they want a solution this time.

If the Turkish community in the north have their way, they will reunite with their brothers and sisters in the south. We have seen very significant demonstrations in the Turkish ruled zone of Cyprus where Turkish Cypriots have said that they want to reunite the island. We have also seen a lot of Turkish Cypriots voting with their feet by leaving the island. That is not a good thing, and we need a solution. There will be a lot to forgive and a lot to try and forget, but there does need to be reconciliation. While the details might take some time to sort out, it now seems that 30 years after Turkey invaded the northern part of Cyprus there may be a resolution to the situation. It would be a tragedy for Cyprus if, on 1 May when Cyprus becomes part of the EU, only the southern part of the island, which is administered by the government of Cyprus at present, entered the union. The EU have made it quite clear that only the sovereign part of the island, governed by the Cypriot government, will become part of the EU.

The people in the north of the island deserve the economic benefits that European Union membership will bring them. They have a lower standard of living than people in the southern part of the island and they have a greater need for the economic benefits which will come from Cyprus being part of the EU. The Greek Cypriot part of Cyprus—the southern part of the island—has very few natural resources. Its only major natural resource is its people and their industry and they have shown that, even with the island divided, they have been able to develop a very strong economy in the south built on tourism, banking and services. They are able to hold their heads high, go into the EU and provide the economic stability and advancement that the north of the island requires.

It will need a lot of pressure by the Turkish government to get the old Turkish Cypriot regime in northern Cyprus to agree to the amalgamation, but if the people who run the Turkish Cypriot regime in the north of Cyprus genuinely have the ideals and the best interests of the Cypriot people at heart, particularly the Turkish Cypriot people, they will ensure that we achieve a solution to this problem now. It would be absolutely stupid if the Australian government chose this time to withdraw Australia's AFP contingent or even think of diminishing it. As previous experience has shown in other difficult international situations, once a solution has been found there is still a lot of work to be done to bed down the new arrangements. A harmonious and successful reunification will take time, patience and goodwill on both sides. The Australian AFP, with its well-earned reputation in Cyprus with both sides of the island over the years, will be in an excellent position to assist for however long it takes to bring peace and harmony to the island.

While I am pleased to see that AFP personnel are continuing to be deployed overseas and that the government recognises our international responsibility to help preserve stability and security among our near neighbours, I hope that it is not at the expense of our longstanding commitment in Cyprus. When the beginnings of a resolution to the problem in Cyprus seem to be so close—the closest it has been in memory—it would be premature of the Australian government to withdraw our police at this sensitive time. As I have said before, it would certainly not be a popular move from the Cypriot community's point of view, and I know from personal experience that the people of Cyprus appreciate the presence of the AFP.

We should hope that the minister will see sense, that the government will ensure that the AFP stay in Cyprus and that the AFP can celebrate the reunification of the island in a way which the Cypriot community here in Australia will be proud of and which the Cyprus government will be appreciative of. The people of Cyprus, who have come to know the Australian police there over that long period, would want them to be there to celebrate the reunification of the island. I hope that the minister will continue to maintain Australia's presence in Cyprus.

In the rest of this appropriation bill, as I said at the beginning, there is very little that the government is proposing that it has not proposed before. There is a lot of dross and very little gold. I was going to speak about some of the decisions that the aviation portfolio have taken, particularly in moving the terminal control units that control along the east cost of Australia to Melbourne, but if I got on to the airport issue I would probably need an extension of time, so I might—

talk.start.para: —I'll move it for you!

—My colleague here has heard my airport speeches before, and he loves and enjoys them. He has only an Air Force airport in his electorate, but he might worry a little because, when Brisbane gets bigger, the best place for it to expand will be out to Amberley.

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 4.42 p.m. to 4.53 p.m.

talk.start.para: —Today I would like to address a number of family and community service issues which are very important to many people in my electorate of Oxley and, of course, to a whole range of Australians throughout our country. More specifically I want to outline a number of failures by the Howard government to address these real issues affecting real Australians. I remind people to cast their minds back to 1996 when that famous phrase `the Howard battlers' was coined. Sadly, they have been forgotten by this government. I believe the Howard government has failed to provide adequate assistance for many Australians and their families, and I know that a Latham Labor government would redress these failings as a matter of urgency. Labor has a proven track record, particularly on the issues of health, education and housing, whereas the government has an ever-growing track record of being strong on the weak, weak on the strong, loose with the truth and—their greatest record of all—the highest taxing government in Australian history.

speech.para: In general terms, the Howard government is not committed to delivering real assistance for Australian families. Instead, the government's approach is to avoid its mutual responsibilities—and we often hear that terminology used in this place by the government. It is a term that in fact does not belong to this government. It should be a term of respect—mutual responsibility is about what we can all do for each other for the betterment of this place. But the term has been hijacked by the government, and I am offended by that because it is a term that Labor has used, but used in a responsible manner. That is what mutual responsibility should be about. But the government has taken that and put it in the too-hard basket. It is no more evident than in what has been revealed recently by a leaked 130-page cabinet document which was presented to the federal government nearly 14 months ago. This document, which the government has sat on for far too long, presented a range of work and family policy options open to the government to redress some of its own failings. What did the government do with this document? It shelved it—it put it to one side and into the too-hard basket.

When I asked in question time recently why no action was taken when the government was presented with these policy options, in his response the Prime Minister said that there were more pressing issues to deal with than an options paper about families. I cannot think of any more pressing issue or any issue that should be more prioritised than the wellbeing of families in this country. At the end of the day, no matter what we do as a parliament and no matter what any party does in government, we should first and foremost look after families. If you look after families, you look after all Australians. But the government failed in this area and put it into the too-hard basket.

I also want to briefly outline a few key issues that presently face all Australians, particularly families. Many families struggle to balance the pressures of work and family life. There is no question about that—that is a known fact. Life has become more complicated and much more of a struggle. Families today are finding it increasingly difficult to obtain child-care places. With the requirement for people to go out to work for that double income to match the lifestyles that families are seeking and the expectations that families have, there is a need for more child-care places. Many of them particularly struggle to find after-school care places. Young families need assistance when it comes to that new addition to their family. We should be encouraging new families and more children, and we should be doing that through policy. Parental leave is an important issue, particularly for people re-entering the work force. I also want to take note of the structurally flawed family tax benefits scheme. All of these issues are interlinked—you cannot separate them. You cannot have a government that decides it is going to deal with one of these issues but not all of them. At the end of the day these issues affect everybody—not only the people in my electorate of Oxley, in Ipswich and western Brisbane, but also the millions of families right across Australia.

What the government should be doing is presenting the policies by which they seek to address many of these issues and providing real assistance and real solutions. Government do have the power to make a difference—they can effect change. Where there is a will, there is a way. Where there is another incentive and when it is about saving their political hides, the government find no will to take care of family issues and family matters, but they certainly find the will in other areas—and I will come to that in a moment.

So the Prime Minister was right about these issues—about how families balance the pressures of work and family life—when he said, some 19 months ago, that they were very important, but unfortunately he has just done nothing about them. In fact, the Prime Minister has called these things `barbecue stoppers'. He is right—they are barbecue stoppers, because they are very important issues. We have heard all the talk but we have seen no action. We have had all sizzle but no sausage; we have had all ham but no burger. Interestingly, when it comes to these very important issues about the government saving its own political hide it will sit on a report for a long time, but when it comes to other matters that affect the Prime Minister's election hopes then we find a different Prime Minister. The Prime Minister and the government can fix the political problem of parliamentary superannuation—they can fix that in 48 hours—but when it comes to helping Australian families then 14 months go by and nothing happens. How does the government justify that? How does the government go out into the community and explain that? I am going to be asking that question in the lead-up to the election on every opportunity.

For 30 years, throughout his career, the Prime Minister has come into this place and defended the parliamentary superannuation scheme, but he backflips on that in 48 hours when he knows that his political hide is on the line. That is the type of person I am talking about. People will and do ask questions about that. But when it comes to helping families and there is a report sitting in the party room, it takes 14 months. And if the report is not leaked and not discovered, nothing happens. This is the tragedy; this is the explanation; this is the definition of this government. This is what this government represents, and that makes me sick. It makes me sick to the bone knowing what this government is truly about. It is not about helping people and families; it is about saving its own political hide.

I also want to speak about some specifics and highlight just how the government is failing Australian families. I mentioned before half-a-dozen or more of the issues that are prominent in the lives of many Australians. There are some figures and facts that I think are really important to this debate, particularly in relation to the government's failed family tax benefit scheme. There have been 2.9 million incorrect payments—56 per cent of all payments, worth $2½ billion—made in error to families. The percentage of family payment debts remains extremely high. It is unacceptable. Families have an average debt of around $900. I find this unacceptable. It is totally unacceptable that the government does not act to fix up this problem. It will find ways to fix up its own problems but not the problems of the families that it should be helping.

It has underpaid families an average of $32.50 a fortnight. It underpays them and then thinks it is okay to say, `At the end of the year we'll give you a top-up.' Meanwhile families are suffering. That is why we have those large personal debts and credit card debts—because this government forces people into that position by not dealing with their family tax benefits in a proper way. It is a flawed system that this government should address as a matter of urgency but finds not important enough. It can find the time within 48 hours to do the greatest backflip of all time when it comes to superannuation entitlements for parliamentarians—when it affects them personally—but when it comes to families it cannot find the time. I find this very offensive.

In relation to the debts it actually gets worse. The total number of family tax benefit overpayments from July 2000 to September 2003—a relatively short period of time—was 1,639,378. That is right—over 1.6 million mistakes. The dollar value of these overpayments in that period was over $1.4 billion. A growing number of families are being underpaid, and I find that totally unacceptable. The total number of family tax benefit underpayments in that same period of time was nearly 1.3 million, with a total value of over $1 billion. And you ask why families are suffering! Why are families hurting? They are hurting because the government is not dealing with their family tax benefits in the proper way. It is a flawed system. It is a system that hurts ordinary families.

Some government members might giggle a bit and think that this may only affect a small percentage of unfortunate people who might not have a job. That is not the case. We are talking about ordinary middle-class Australian families in which one parent or both parents work. They are finding the system so complex, so difficult, that they come to my office to seek assistance not with the actual benefits but in comprehending the forms. These are people who are in middle management or management jobs and are very literate. I have looked at the forms and I find them very confusing. I do not know how ordinary people can fill out those forms. We see the result of that complication and bureaucracy in the millions of underpayments. We see the result in the hundreds of thousands of families that miss out on an entitlement—miss out on something they are due. It is not fair and it should be corrected.

But, again, the government cannot find the time. It is not on their list of priorities. On their list of priorities are their political hides. That is the one and only issue on their list of priorities. We find that only 44 per cent of payments are correct, so we are talking about nearly 60 per cent that are not correct. Again, this is just not acceptable. The total dollar value of incorrect payments is $2½ billion. The reason why I highlight these figures is to draw some attention to the quantum—the size, to the actual dollar value, of just how bad this is.

An on-point example of a real person in my electorate is that of a young woman who came to my office about a system flaw in her payments. She had identified the flaw and notified Centrelink, but the system would not allow the change because it is not built into the computer system. It is not built into the method by which it can be changed. It has to lie there—the documents are not right; this and that are not right. Every electorate office around this country has gone through this. Every Liberal member, every National Party member and every Labor member knows this is right, because we fix the problems. It is the members who end up sitting down, going through the details and fixing the problems in the bureaucracy—the bits that the public servants who are looking after Centrelink cannot fix because they do not have the authority to fix them.

This is part of the problem with the system. The minister wants all power over what goes on in their own system but accepts no responsibility, so people suffer in a flawed system. We did finally fix this woman's problem. It was a minor problem but it was a policy problem. We fixed it, but she had to put weeks of stress, pain and time into fixing this problem. That is completely inadequate and wrong. This government should go and fix its system first and let people get on with their lives. It should let people go out there and work for a living and look after their families and not have the stress and burden of this government which cannot do its job. It should not let that burden fall on to our electorate offices and on us, as members of parliament, or directly on to the families in our community.

I cannot understand how the government continues to allow this to happen year after year and does not prioritise it. I cannot understand why it does not make it a top-level priority in its own party room to say. `This is an important issue we need to fix.' I think that might change. I have got to tell you here and now, Mr Deputy Speaker Lindsay, that this might change. It is going to change because the government is going to start to suffer in the electorates. That is the only thing that this government understands—electoral pain. If they feel enough electoral pain they will react. We saw that this week. They have ignored veterans; they have not come up with the sorts of packages and things that we need to provide to veterans as the proper entitlement that they are due for their service to this country.

We saw Minister Vale come into the parliament—I have to say she has very little respect, if any, left from the veteran community—with the gall to come in under false pretences and not offer the sort of benefits these people are entitled to. I was ashamed that day for this government and the way it treats veterans. But what did it do this week? It suddenly realised: `Hang on, we've got a fair bit of money stashed away for a rainy electoral day: a $7½ billion surplus. We might have to spend some of that on the people we are hurting the most.' It has twigged to that little problem it has in terms of the veteran community—the veterans just might do something about it if problems are not fixed.

I am glad to see now that there is an almost $300 million package that will actually go to veterans. But, mind you, the government, as always, has been dragged kicking and screaming all the way to the table and the options—all the way to the payments. It does not want to do this. The veteran community should make a note of this: `The government does not want to give you that $300 million; it is forced to give it to you.' It has been dragged there kicking and screaming because we, as the opposition, go into the parliament day after day and take the government to task. We want the government to be accountable for every single cent that it puts away like a miser in a little stash fund called an electoral fund—that $7½ billion surplus—so that it can have a get out of jail free card come the election. That is what is happening. This year may or may not be an election year, but you will see the changes. I think the community is smart enough to know that this year that is where that surplus will be spent. There is a lot of work to be done and a lot of things that need to be redressed, and this government has had way too much time to do it and has not acted on any of it.

There were also some interesting statistics that came back to us through the Weekend Australian newspaper, acquired through freedom of information requests, which confirmed the damaging 1.3 million mistakes that affected 700,000 Centrelink customers over a four-month period—700,000 Centrelink customers were affected over four months by Centrelink's mistakes. I want to make it very clear at this stage that I do not blame the workers of Centrelink. I do not blame the people that work there at all, because I know the stresses, regulation and bureaucracy they have to deal with and the pressures that come to them directly from the top—from government in Canberra—about the way they have to apply the rules they have been given. It has become such a complex business now, and we see the government making it more and more difficult for public servants to do their job.

And then what does the government do? I was absolutely shocked a couple of weeks ago when we had ministers come into this place and say that public servants cannot do the job well enough and we need to outsource and privatise it. Of course they cannot do the job well enough if you do not give them the tools and the resources. You can always make life difficult for someone if you want to and if you do not resource them properly. The government should make the system better. It should fix the flaws in the system and properly resource Centrelink. It should do all these things to make life for families easier. At the end of the day that is the goal. The priority of government should be to make life for families easier to the point where they do not have to worry about their Centrelink payments or that extra layer of bureaucracy, so that they can get on with their lives and their barbecue stoppers, as the Prime Minister is so keen to point out.

The Leader of the Opposition, Mark Latham, has talked about a ladder of opportunity. He has talked about the first rung on that ladder being opportunity for all our infant children. The Leader of the Opposition knows, like all of us, that our children are precious and the foundations of our future and that their development is not an issue to be avoided. Their development should be right up there—the No. 1 priority. It should be on the government's list but it is not. As I have explained before, we know why it is not on that list—that list is crowded by one issue only: the government's re-election.

Throughout my electorate and many like it across the country, people are trying very hard to balance the pressures of family life and work and, more specifically, people are struggling to find adequate child-care places. People often tell me they struggle not only to find adequate before- and after-school child-care places but also funded places so their kids can be looked after properly in a qualified child-care centre. People also tell me that child care is becoming one of those central issues that make it very difficult for them to continue in their employment. I think that is an issue the government should really pay more attention to. It ends up meaning that those families have to put more pressure on their friends, more pressure on their family and more pressure on the community in order to do the government's job. The community, friends and family end up doing the government's job, because the government refuses to accept its mutual responsibility to families in Australia. There is a crisis in child care that this government refuses to fix. The issue of affordability is certainly high on that agenda.

In the couple of minutes that I have remaining, I want to mention a specific example of the government's failure—that is, the Job Network system. The Job Network system is now well and truly stuffed. I do not know if I can find any other way to explain it. This system has failed glaringly. It is a revolving door of unemployment for those who remain unemployed. While I acknowledge that unemployment rates are low, not much has changed for those who are in long-term unemployment.

This system that the government has put in place seems to me to be nothing more than a system which it took away from public servants—it took away its own responsibility as a government to provide a Commonwealth employment service—and gave it to private enterprise. Private enterprise quickly worked out that, to make a profit—something that this government claims to understand very well—they needed customers. Their customers are the unemployed. Of course, as unemployment tends to fall or as there is no renewal of customers, the Job Network agencies fail. And as they fail, the government finds that it has to top them up. What is it doing? It is topping them up to the tune and $670 million per year. It is finding that, if it does not throw in $1 billion extra to keep them afloat, they and the system will collapse and it will be revealed just how flawed this system really is.

In the few words that I have put on the record today, I have highlighted just a few of the many problems that families and communities face in Australia today. But I really want to draw people's attention to the fact that this government does absolutely nothing about it. It does not prioritise. Labor will do that when it is elected. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004,Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004 constitute the additional estimates bills for 2004. They provide additional funding requirements since the 2003-04 budget and include total appropriations for the three bills of $14,307 million. This is a net increase of $957 million from the 2003-04 budget, which is two per cent of total annual appropriations. These bills also include savings due to changes in policy or parameter variations totalling $473.4 million. These are outlined in the finance document statement of savings expected in annual appropriations. The Appropriations Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 deals primarily with measures since the last budget and, in addition to supply, two new clauses have also been added to this bill which will provide a mechanism for the finance minister upon request from portfolio minister to lapse amounts of departmental expense appropriations which are not required.

speech.para: While we have said that we will support these appropriation bills as we have done every year since 1975, we have moved a second reading amendment that the House condemns the government for its budget waste, mismanagement and wrong priorities which have resulted in a costly Medicare safety net that does not protect families from increasing health costs and declining levels of bulk-billing; inadequate funding and higher fees for students seeking access to higher education; a growing number of families who are financially squeezed in trying to balance work and family and half a million Australians who have been waiting for up to five years to get their teeth fixed.

We need to restore doctors' services in the Newcastle and Lake Macquarie area. Labor has a plan to save Medicare with a $1.9 billion package to reverse the collapse in bulk-billing and by lifting the patient rebate for bulk-billing for all Australians, no matter where they live or how much they earn.
