A Latham Labor government will immediately lift the Medicare patient rebate for all bulk-billed consultations to 95 per cent of the scheduled fee—an average increase of $3.35 per visit. Subsequently, it will lift the Medicare patient rebate for all bulk-billed consultations to 100 per cent of the scheduled fee—an average increase of $5 per visit. Doctors will be offered financial incentives to keep treating their patients, without additional cost, and to extend bulk-billing, especially in places like Lake Macquarie and Newcastle where the collapse in bulk-billing is really hurting families. Lifting the patient rebate and introducing financial incentives for bulk-billing will help to stem the dramatic decline in bulk-billing and act to make more bulk-billing available to more Australian families.

Labor will encourage doctors to bulk-bill. We will make access to health care much easier for families, particularly those families who are under financial pressure. Labor stands in stark contrast to the government's proposals to destroy Medicare, to restrict bulk-billing to pensioners and concession card holders, and to see Australian families pay more every time they visit the doctor. Bit by bit, visit by visit, the cost for Australian families under John Howard will go up. Under Labor's proposals, there are substantial financial incentives for GPs to continue bulk-billing or to improve their bulk-billing performances. We are very confident that our package, when implemented, will firstly stem the serious decline in bulk-billing and then see bulk-billing go back up towards our national objective of an 80 per cent bulk-billing rate.

The Prime Minister knows his package will create conditions in which it will be easier for doctors to charge gap payments for patients and increase their fees for patients who are already paying private fees. There is the ability for doctors to claim the Medicare rebate directly and to charge a gap payment, and it is being held out as an incentive only for those doctors who agree to do John Howard's bidding for pensioners and concession card holders. As the former President of the AMA, Kerryn Phelps, pointed out:

quote.para: What will need to happen is that for doctors to continue to bulk-bill their concession card holders they're going to have to charge their non concession card holders more ...

speech.para: The government's package will drive bulk-billing even lower because, while doctors will be given financial incentives to bulk-bill pensioners and concession card holders, they will be given the green light to charge higher fees for everybody else. Australian families who earn more than $32,300 a year are not eligible for a concession card. For them, bulk-billing will effectively end. When they visit their GP, bit by bit, visit by visit, they will be asked to pay more.

We all know that being able to see a doctor when somebody in the family is sick can be pretty tough. Finding a doctor who is prepared to bulk-bill is almost impossible these days. Part of my job as a federal member of parliament is to help our community gain better access to services, including doctors and Medicare. Labor is the party that built Medicare. Labor believes in Medicare. Under Labor, Medicare was not in crisis; it worked. In 1996 more than 80 per cent of visits to doctors cost patients nothing because the doctor bulk-billed. John Howard, in contrast, has never believed in Medicare and his policies have put Medicare on the critical list. John Howard's policies mean that there are now 21 per cent less bulk-billing consultations each year in West Lake Macquarie and South Newcastle than there were in 2000. This means that greater pressure is being placed on John Hunter Hospital, Belmont Hospital and Wyong Hospital emergency rooms.

We all know that there are times when a family needs a doctor and that it is now harder to find one. I will relate a personal experience that happened to me during January. We woke up one morning at home and Reg, my husband, found that he could not swallow. We rang his local medical service and they said, `No, the doctor is on holidays. We couldn't get a locum in and won't be able to see you for about three or four days.' I rang another medical service in the area, but the doctor had to go on leave as she had been working hard all year. They could not get a locum in to assist the practice, so the practice in the town had to close down over the break. The advice given to us was to wait at the emergency rooms at the John Hunter Hospital. I would like to think that we are a fairly intelligent family, but on this occasion we decided that we would self-medicate. We looked in the herbal books on the bookshelves, looking for ways to try to alleviate the symptoms Reg had, without having to wait at the emergency room at the John Hunter Hospital. If we as a family have to make choices like that, I can just imagine what other people in the community do.

In relation to shortages of doctors and bulk-billing, in July last year I expressed my disappointment in this place at the sudden closure of the Wyee Medical Practice in my electorate. I was extremely saddened that the last of the bulk-billing surgeries in the Morisset and Wyee area had closed its doors to the public. The doctors at the surgery were well respected and were the last to regularly bulk-bill patients in the Southlakes area. There are few doctors in the Morisset region who will take on new patients because their books are full. Costs of around $35.50 for a pensioner to visit the doctor are causing many people in our community to turn to our public hospitals for medical attention or they just miss out completely.

The community of Wyee and Wyee Point have been left without their bulk-billing doctors. This means that many families will just not seek medical attention because the $35 or $44 to visit the doctor is just not there. There is a clear shortage of doctors in the Southlakes area and, with a significant growing population, the pressure placed on our hardworking doctors is mounting. People living in the Southlakes area have been disadvantaged by the closure of the Wyee surgery, which will only add pressure to the existing doctors in Morisset, Cooranbong and Bonnells Bay. We need more doctors in our regions; we cannot afford to see them leave. And we need these doctors to bulk-bill us so all families can access medical attention when they need it. We need a solution to the bulk-billing crisis, and only Labor will deliver a better deal on Medicare for families in the Southlakes area.

Following the closure of that doctor's surgery in Wyee towards the end of last year, the Wyee community faced the possible closure of the Wyee pharmacy owing to the loss of the doctor. I am deeply concerned that because we are still yet to secure the services of a new doctor the pharmacy may have to close. I have been working closely with the community, including Ibraham and Lobna Gahzi, the local pharmacists to bring a doctor back to Wyee. Whilst our efforts continue, there is increasing pressure on the pharmacy to close. Much of the pharmacists' work is generated by dispensing prescriptions and, without a doctor in town, fewer people are using the pharmacy. Ibraham and Lobna have been great supporters of the Wyee community and it is a tragedy that their business has suffered as a result of the closure of the Wyee Medical Practice. I again call on the government to bring about a solution that will encourage a doctor to come to Wyee. We were advised by the minister that Wyee is a location where an overseas trained doctor is able to access a Medicare provider number. This needs to happen soon before another vital service, the local pharmacy, is lost to the community of Wyee.

Moving on to dental care, I have received many letters, emails and phone calls on this issue. As I have responded to them, I emphasise that Labor will invest $300 million over four years in a national dental care program to help those half a million Australians currently waiting up to five years to get treatment. Australian dental care will provide well over a million extra dental procedures for Australians—enough to clear the existing backlog and substantially reduce waiting lists. When the Howard government abolished the Commonwealth dental program in 1996, there were 380,000 Australians waiting an average of six months for public dental care. Now there are more than half a million people waiting as long as five years to get their teeth fixed, and many of the people on these lists are elderly.

Under Labor's plan, concession card holders, such as pensioners, and health care card holders and their dependants will now get free check-ups when they need them and subsidised dental treatments, restorations and dentures. Labor will also provide dental health assessments and ongoing care for everyone admitted to nursing homes and will help Indigenous communities with special dental problems, including lack of water fluoridation and diabetes. Under Labor, the federal and state governments will join together in a great national effort because we know that affordable dental care is as essential as any other medical treatment. State and territory governments will spend $384 million on dental services this financial year for health care card holders and school children. Labor believes that dental care is a national responsibility and, unlike the Prime Minister who simply tries to fob it off to the states, a Latham Labor government will work with the states to fix the crisis in dental care.

Towards the end of last year, we saw a change in leadership of the federal parliamentary Labor Party. Mark Latham was elected leader and the policies that I have outlined in relation to Medicare, bulk-billing and doctor shortages were released prior to that. So we have shown already that we are a party of positive policy announcements, of policy announcements which have been fully costed and which we know will work to address the ongoing crisis in parts of our community in relation to medical care.

Throughout January in the lead-up to the Labor Party's national conference which was held in Sydney at the end of January a lot of the media and political commentators and many of those in the coalition government were saying that the national conference was going to be a test of Mark Latham's leadership of the Labor Party. I think a lot of those people would have been sitting back and waiting for Mark Latham to fall at the national conference of the Labor Party. But that did not happen. If that was a test of Mark Latham's leadership of the Labor Party then he well and truly passed it. Following on from that, we had the media commentators as well as the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and leading government ministers and government backbenchers saying: `This is a honeymoon for Mark Latham. This is a honeymoon period for the new leader of the Labor Party.' After three months of that leadership—three months today—that balloon, that honeymoon period, is nowhere near dissipating. I think the government members would be pleased to have a crisis which would maybe put a hole in that balloon. That is not going to happen. If you have seen the energy, the commitment and the dedication from the new Leader of the Opposition, you will know that that is not going to happen.

In the last month or so, the government have gone into panic mode and we have seen their knee-jerk reactions. We saw that with the response from the Prime Minister in relation to parliamentarians' superannuation. We saw it today in response to the veteran community and the policy announcements to try and shore up their support. I remind the government members and the Prime Minister that the community has a long memory and the community will remember the trail of deceit, the trail of non-core promises and they will ask: `Where are the weapons of mass destruction and the reasons we went to war?' They will remember Tampa. They will remember the children overboard. They will remember Peter Hollingworth. They will remember the never, ever GST. They will remember the no $100,000 university fees. They will remember the reason we went to war was because of the so-called weapons of mass destruction, but now the Prime Minister tells us it was good to get the regime change. The electorate will remember these things. No amount of back-pedalling or spending the budget surplus is going to make them feel any other way.

The opposition's amendment to this legislation also goes to the issue of government waste. It was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald by Alan Ramsey on 18 February following budget estimates in which our two experts—Labor Party Senators John Faulkner and Robert Ray—raised some questions about expenditure on the Lodge. The total expenditure came in at about $140,000 which included 10 armchairs at $23,000-odd, carpeting, painting and new timberwork, design fees, timber removal, curtains, two bathrooms and lighting. The article reports Senator Faulkner saying:

quote.para: Is that the full horror?

speech.para: And the official replied:

quote.para: There is still some carpeting.

speech.para: They then moved on to the `retirement lifestyle' of Peter Hollingworth. You would remember that Peter Hollingworth was, as Ramsey reports:

quote.para: ...[the] former archbishop and tainted governor-general who resigned, under pressure, a year ago after just 23 turbulent months and walked away with an annual pension of $184,000, a car and driver and first-class air travel for life, and an office and secretary—

speech.para: thank you very much! Senator Ray, in budget estimates, as Ramsey reports:

quote.para: ... wanted to know about Hollingworth's 21st-floor office in Melbourne that taxpayers maintain. How big was it? Official: “145 square metres for him and his staff.” How many staff? “One.” Faulkner: “145 square metres for two people? That is bigger than a lot of houses in this country, isn't it?” Official: “I do not know.” Faulkner: “Well, I do.”

speech.para: And we all do, too. Ramsey's article said Senator Ray then asked:

quote.para: “Were any renovations required?” Official: “There was a fit-out, yes.” Ray: “How much?” Official: “The total cost?” Ray: “Yes.”

speech.para: The official said that the total cost of the fit out of this 21st floor office of 145 square metres for two people was $234,000. Those are just a couple of examples of government wastage in this area.

I referred to the national conference and the various policy announcements which were made there. We also announced the policy of Read Aloud Australia, where parents are supported in reading aloud to their children from day one—because we know that learning begins at day one—and the BookStart program, where every new parent will be offered three new books to read to their children. We also had the announcement that Lindsay Tanner, the member for Melbourne, had been appointed the shadow minister for community relationships. We all know that people out there in the community do not sit around the pub talking about the state of the economy; they sit around the pub talking about the state of their families, the state of their community, their community security, how their kids are going and what is happening in their everyday lives. So I applaud the Leader of the Opposition for making those announcements at our national conference. They were great announcements and there are many more where they came from.

In conclusion, and because I have referred to the new Leader of the Opposition, I would just like to take this opportunity to salute Simon Crean, the member for Hotham. Simon always had my support. Simon is a good man; he was a good leader. Unfortunately, events conspired against him. I wish him and Carole all the best, all the time. I consider them good friends. We did a lot under the leadership of Simon Crean and I applaud him for that.

talk.start.para: —I was appalled and disgusted when I saw in the Weekend Australian Magazine of 21 and 22 February a reference—to a part of my electorate—which I consider to be full of judgment and prejudice. A number of people in this chamber might have read the article that I am talking about. It was an otherwise excellent piece of writing by a journalist named Stuart Rintoul. It was an article about a very well-known and prominent defence barrister named Colin Lovitt. I thought it was a good piece of writing about Colin Lovitt and it was interesting reading, but I must take issue with a reference that Stuart Rintoul made in his article to what he described as the `rural slum of Moe'.

speech.para: I am very proud to represent the town of Moe in my electoral district. It is a beautiful town and an absolutely fantastic place to live. It is surrounded by rolling hills to the south and an absolutely gorgeous mountain range to the north. It is a large and vibrant township of about 18,000 people, and it has a magnificent sense of community. I have been proud to have the support of so many people in Moe in my political life for quite a few years, and very proud to count so many people in Moe as my trusted and closest friends.

I want to say this in the parliament: I think Stuart Rintoul did the wrong thing by making that reference to Moe. It is an uninformed comment and a comment that is full of prejudice and judgment. I say to Stuart Rintoul through this parliament that we really count on people like him in the media to be responsible in the comments they make about towns and districts, because what they say has a big effect on how people perceive the towns, districts and regions in which we live. I think it would be appropriate for Stuart Rintoul and the Weekend Australian to apologise to the people of Moe for that reference. It might have been an inadvertent reference, but the damage has still been done. People in Moe are hurt by that reference. It is a reference which is unfair. It is a comment on the people of Moe which is not deserved.

We all know that when you refer to a slum in an Australian context the general usage of that word is associated with a place like Calcutta where there is desperate poverty and there are awful physical circumstances and people living in horrendous personal situations. We all know that that is what the word `slum' refers to. We know that that reference is unsuitable when talking about a beautiful town and a vibrant community full of good people, all working hard to get ahead, which is what we have in the township of Moe.

I want to use the time that I have available today to draw attention to the response that we have had from the public schools right across my electorate to the awful comments made by the Prime Minister in relation to the public school system. It might be worth while my reminding the House exactly what those comments were. The Prime Minister said:

quote.para: ... they—

speech.para: talking about the parents—

quote.para: feel that government schools have become too politically correct and too values-neutral.

speech.para: And the acting education minister, Peter McGauran, said:

quote.para: ... there is a worrying trend within state schools, that there is a jettison of traditional values and heritage of Australia.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: ... there is a growing trend that is discernable to parents that too many government schools are either value free or are hostile to, apathetic to, Australia's heritage and values ...

speech.para: Those comments are appalling and very uninformed. They are an insult to all those hardworking teachers and support staff who commit themselves so fully and energetically to providing quality education to our students in public schools. Quite a response has been created in my electorate not only from people in the public school system but also from people in the Catholic and independent school systems who were appalled at the Prime Minister's comments and who think that these types of generalisations and stereotypes of schools or teachers are highly inappropriate.

I have some letters here from schools across my electorate in response to what the Prime Minister has said. I want to read part of what they have said in their letters to me into the Hansard for the record. One letter is from a rural primary school in the beautiful Latrobe Valley. It says:

quote.para: Christian, you must have noticed even in your visits to our school how seriously we emphasise the values of respect and civility to visitors. This is even more so when we are out of the school. The students know very clearly what is expected.

speech.para: The principal goes on to say:

quote.para: This year at our school, we are launching the You Can Do It program. This actually teaches the indicators research has shown make a successful student and citizen. These indicators are: organisation, academic confidence, persistence and getting along with others. Underpinning these success indicators are a whole range of values: respect for others, respect for property, independence, giving of your best, expectations that tasks will be completed, putting in an effort, planning time, listening to others, tolerance, playing by the rules, thinking first—the list goes on. These aspects of successful citizenship are actually taught. There are specific lessons on these values.

speech.para: The principal concludes by saying:

quote.para: Christian, can you imagine what schools would be like if tolerance, respect and a conscientious approach to study were not inherent in the values of a school? It would be chaos, and my school is not that.

speech.para: I have been to that principal's school on several occasions, and I can guarantee that his school, like so many other public schools in my electoral district, is an excellent school. It provides a fantastic education to all of its students.

Another letter I have received in relation to this issue is from the principal of one of the large state primary schools in the west Gippsland area. He has written a letter to the Prime Minister which he has copied to me. As principal of his school, he writes to the Prime Minister:

quote.para: I am deeply offended by your comments regarding state government schools and their values. As the elected political leader of this country your effort should be constructive and inclusive, not divisive and politically point scoring.

speech.para: He goes on to say:

quote.para: ... it is a large primary school with a strong culture of producing high-quality, well educated students. We operate in a very competitive environment. The whole community sees our school as offering outstanding quality education. The values and heritage enunciated at this school truly reflect the parent community and are clearly stated. Your recent statements not only damage years of hard work and effort but also the image of my staff and their profession.

speech.para: This was typical of the response I had from schools right across my electorate in relation to the Prime Minister's comments about public education. I would like to read from another letter I have got, which is from a large public primary school in one of the towns in the Latrobe Valley. The principal wrote to me and said:

quote.para: Like you, I was appalled at the indiscriminate demeaning of schools.

speech.para: He goes on to say:

quote.para: It is unfortunate that the Prime Minister's comments and those of many of his colleagues have in one broad, generalised sweep undermined the work and integrity of teachers and parents who are contributing so much to the growth and development of this nation. I am personally embarrassed because it has taken the focus away from the real issues facing schools today.

speech.para: I support that view and I think he has hit the nail on the head. The real issue facing the federal parliament in relation to schools is not some type of false debate that the Prime Minister might want to try and start which relates to his idea of values; it is about where the funding goes that the Commonwealth provides to schools. We have a situation now where the more money schools have the more money they get, which means that poorer districts—mostly in rural areas—miss out. All of the big increases go to the King's School, Geelong Grammar, Wesley College and Trinity College—schools that charge $15,000 or $16,000 per year for just one student to study. Not one single person in my electorate can afford that. The real debate, which was alluded to in that letter I just read out, is about why it is that the Howard government sees fit to give those schools the most money and not adequately fund the public school system and low-fee Catholic and independent schools and recognise the needs of their students and the communities they serve.

I had many other responses, from principals, school councils and students right across my electorate. I want to read out a response from a principal who leads one of the public secondary colleges in the south Gippsland region. He says that at his school:

quote.para: Our core values and expectations are: valuing people, valuing diversity, mutual respect, honesty, trust, resolving conflict positively, recognising and encouraging people's strengths, respecting individuality, fostering a sense of community where we care about everyone. People are encouraged to make positive choices, taking responsibility for actions and achievements.

speech.para: His letter goes on:

quote.para: We teach these core values and expectations in the curriculum, with a subject known as people skills. This has commenced this year at years 7, 8 and 9. We are a project school for social competencies, which we have called people skills.

speech.para: He includes some three pages in his letter that set out in more detail all of the values and skills which his school is teaching its students as it prepares those young people for life.

There are so many other responses that I have received, from some excellent schools right across my electoral district. I hope that the Prime Minister is listening to my contribution today and hearing first-hand what educators, people who are in the field servicing communities in country areas, actually think of the comments that he made about their schools and the school system, which he has, in one broad statement, demeaned in such a disgraceful way.

I had the good fortune the other day to get a briefing from the Trafalgar district community association. The Trafalgar district community association are good people who have been working very hard on behalf of the residents and the citizens of Trafalgar and have really been a very powerful force within that community in setting a positive agenda for the town and making sure that things happen when they are planned. I received a briefing from the Trafalgar district community association, from the people from the youth resource centre in the town, from the Trafalgar Chamber of Commerce and from a number of people who are involved directly with the Trafalgar district community association in terms of organising the strategic direction for the town.

The group have steered the development of the Trafalgar strategic plan and its sister publication, the Trafalgar action plan. They are two excellent publications, which are the result of extensive work and public consultation that has been done by the people involved in the Trafalgar Community Development Association. I just want to use this public opportunity in the parliament to congratulate the people involved in the Trafalgar Community Development Association for the work which they have done. In particular, I want to congratulate Mick Bourke, who has been their president for quite some time, for the work which he has done and the leadership he has provided to that organisation.

It is a wonderful town, Trafalgar, and I am absolutely convinced that it has a very positive future. It will continue to have a positive future so long as there are people in the community like Mick Bourke and all the other people involved in the Trafalgar Community Development Association who give so willingly of their time and effort and creativity to ensure that a future for Trafalgar is not something that people take for granted but something that people work towards and plan towards. Well done to Mick and his team and to all of the people who are involved in the Trafalgar Community Development Association.

I had the opportunity last week to meet with the people involved with the Coal Creek Heritage Village, which is one of Victoria's premier tourist attractions and is located in the southern part of my electorate, in Korumburra. It is an excellent place. I have been there several times and I am sure many other people in the House have been there before as well. You will be pleased to know, Mr Deputy Speaker Wilkie, that it is celebrating its 30th birthday this month.

The story of Coal Creek is quite amazing and an excellent example of the determination, resourcefulness and cooperation of rural Australian communities. Coal Creek was planned, developed and built by the Korumburra community. The village has benefited from ongoing financial assistance initially from the old Korumburra Shire Council and, more recently, from the South Gippsland Shire Council. However, the vast majority of the original construction was undertaken by volunteer labour, and most of the relics, artefacts and antiques that make up the collection were donated by local residents and families. The day-to-day operation of the village has across its 30-year history relied heavily on volunteers in staffing roles as tour guides and in maintaining the village. Korumburra is a relatively small town, as you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, yet the local community supplies around 30 volunteers per week to keep Coal Creek functioning. It really is a great achievement that the people of Korumburra have been able to keep Coal Creek functioning for so long and have made it such a success.

Today I want to briefly give some special recognition to a number of volunteers. One standout volunteer amongst a bigger group is Anne Hopwood, who recently retired as a volunteer at Coal Creek after 25 years of continuous services. Anne and her husband run a dairy farm in the Korumburra area and have raised a family of three children. However, she still found time to donate at least a day's voluntary labour to Coal Creek almost every week across the past 25 years. Keith Dunstan is a relative newcomer compared to Anne. He first became involved with Coal Creek around 15 years ago. Since then, he has adopted the village. He is often there seven days per week, feeding the farm animals and tackling all manner of maintenance projects. Keith is also an active member of many of the groups and subcommittees that form the basis of operation and support at Coal Creek.

When Coal Creek was first suggested, Hugh Henry was a local councillor. He was a member of the original investigative committee and a prime mover in developing and progressing the project. He then took on the role of manager of the village, once it opened, and remained in that position for its first 15 years of operation. Since then, he has been a regular visitor, returning to offer his services across a broad range of areas, including building maintenance and general repairs. Hugh has a wealth of knowledge on the history and original development plans, and he remains only too happy to share that with the current management. There are many other examples of local people who have given so much to the Coal Creek Heritage Village over its 30 years of operation.

Well done to Ken Joiner, the current manager of the Coal Creek Heritage Village, in making sure that we properly celebrate this 30th anniversary. I would like to place on record the great regard that I have for the many volunteers who have worked so hard over so many years to make sure that Coal Creek is the excellent tourist facility that it is and that the important history of coalmining in and around the south Gippsland district is preserved for future generations.

talk.start.para: —In rising today to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 and cognate bills, I want to raise some particular issues with respect to two reports of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Financial Services, of which I am a member. One report is entitled Money matters in the bush and the other report is entitled ATM fee structure. These two related reports went into a range of issues regarding access to, and availability and serviceability of, banking services in rural and regional Australia in particular—although the report on the ATM fee structure had a slightly wider remit with respect to that issue. The reports, on balance, are broadly endorsed by all members of the committee. However, Labor members disagreed with coalition members on a number of issues, and I would like to focus on those particular areas and recommendations. In the first report—Money matters in the bush—there was some difference of opinion on a number of recommendations. These recommendations covered issues such as notifications for closure of banks, older person and disability access, accounts, balances provided at EFTPOS, Indigenous communities and banking, and community obligations.

speech.para: I will just go through some of those recommendations and highlight some of the differences of opinion in order to make the Main Committee more aware of the concerns that were held. Recommendation 3 in that report related to the question of improved consultation and, in particular, a notice period of some six months to be provided if a branch was the only branch in a town that was left and that branch was to close. Labor certainly support that recommendation. It is actually in line with what our policy has generally been with respect to the issue of branch closures. Our belief, though, is that you should not just look at it from a rural and regional point of view in that respect. It is a very significant issue in those areas, but there are also metropolitan suburbs and communities where branch closures and their circumstances are also quite traumatic for local businesses and communities. Therefore, although we fully support this recommendation for rural and remote areas, we also believe it ought to be the case for the community in general and should cover branch closures, full stop.

Recommendation 4 related to the question of the gathering of data by APRA and concerns about the question of how that was operating. I am going to quote extensively from the committee report in various ways, shapes and forms but, in respect to that matter, Labor members shared the community's concern that there does need to be improved analysis and commentary on the information provided through the points of presence database. While the committee has requested that another government agency and not APRA be requested to do this, Labor members believe that APRA should have a role in analysing and commenting on the data but that this should be done by APRA in conjunction with the ACCC. Given the ACCC's role in assessing levels of competition in the banking services industry, they would bring a good deal of expertise to any assessment of access to banking services. We think that more can and should be done there.

Recommendation 12 relates to the question of older Australians. Labor supports the priority placed on introducing industry standards to support older Australians and those with disabilities to achieve full and equal access to services such as ATMs and EFTPOS. With respect to recommendation 22 on the issue of expansion of displays of account balances, Labor supports the expansion of EFTPOS facilities to allow for access to account balances. However, there should not be an additional fee for this service and the balance information request should not be considered as a transaction where consumers can only access a limited number of fee-free transactions. It gets back to the issue that we are now at a stage with banking services where, even if you blink at your ATM, you need to respond by paying some sort of fee. The nature of fee payments with respect to this industry has just grown like Topsy over the last few years. It is something that the banks have seen as an ever-growing area for increasing their revenue streams. It is certainly the way that they have been dealing with the benefits of competition that occurred around the Labor government's reforms in that area regarding things like mortgage providers and interest rates.

Another area where concerns were held related to some of the recommendations not going far enough, particularly with respect to the issue of Indigenous communities. Much evidence was taken by the committee on the difficulties confronting Indigenous Australians regarding access to banking services and financial literacy generally. It is apparent that many remote and regional Indigenous communities lack sufficient basic banking services. In some cases it is not an issue of services previously enjoyed being withdrawn but, rather, of services never having been provided at all.

As important, the lack of such services is compounded by factors such as remoteness; socioeconomic disadvantage, which in some instances is extreme; poor levels of numeracy and literacy; and, accordingly, low levels of financial literacy, cultural difference and language barriers. Labor members consider that access to basic banking services and minimum levels of financial literacy are preconditions to addressing the disadvantage experienced by many Indigenous communities in remote and regional Australia. There is little point in governments encouraging Indigenous Australians to achieve greater economic independence if the basic building blocks of economic development are not in place.

Accordingly, while Labor members were generally supportive of the committee's recommendations with regard to Indigenous Australians, we also made the following additional points. In relation to recommendations 24 and 26, Labor members see a need for a multifaceted strategy to improve the financial literacy of Indigenous Australians which is coordinated by the government and which involves Indigenous organisations, state and territory governments and financial institutions. Whilst we support recommendation 24, which calls for financial literacy to be included in core school curricula, we consider this to be only one of a number of strategies that are required. We also believe the involvement of Indigenous organisations, particularly those with demonstrated success in the area of financial literacy education, to be critical.

Further, we consider that recommendation 26 fails to go far enough. It is insufficient to call on the ABA to simply examine the successful practices utilised in Canada in relation to Indigenous financial literacy. In our view, the ABA should develop, in partnership with relevant Indigenous organisations, a comprehensive strategy for improving the financial literacy of Indigenous users of banking services, drawing on the Canadian experience. Labor members are encouraged by some of the initiatives taken by some banks and also by the ABA's indicated willingness to work with Reconciliation Australia on this issue. However, it is our view that, in the event these voluntary initiatives prove to be insufficient, these issues would properly be considered in the context of compulsory community service obligations.

Recommendation 29 related to the issue of the Banking and Financial Services Ombudsman. In particular, Labor members believe that the jurisdiction of the BFSO should be widened further to encompass consumer complaints about the cost of banking services. This is part of that wider discussion. I think the Banking and Financial Services Ombudsman does a pretty good job in many respects; however, the fact of the matter is that he is dramatically limited by the extent of his charter. There are a range of issues which get raised with the BFSO on a regular basis that are not able to be investigated. Those are genuine complaints about the operation of the banking sector but they are complaints which the BFSO is unable to deal with. That is a fault in the system. It means that a range of issues that ought to be investigated are not able to be investigated by an appropriate body such as the BFSO. That is something that I think is incredibly unfortunate. In this particular case, the committee may not have realised the extent of the need but certainly the Labor members do realise that those issues need to be looked at.

Going on from that, there is recommendation 30, which from Labor's point of view related to the issue of supporting the introduction of community service obligations on ADIs. It is a point that we have made repeatedly in the past. We have said that once again we are prepared to look at reregulating the banks if they do not agree to meet appropriate voluntary community service obligations. Our view is that, until we get the banks to the table in a situation where they understand that the regulators and the government of the day are serious, we will not be able to get real movement on a range of issues. The experience with the sector in the past has been that, when they think things are about to happen, you tend to find that they are then prepared to look at what they might do. We believe more can be done in that area. We stress that as something that should be done in the future.

I will go on now to the issue of ATM foreign fee structures, which was the subject of a follow-up report that effectively came out of the main report that I have just spoken about. ATMs are a very important part of what is now the banking sector in this country. Many of us here—and no doubt Deputy Speaker Causley would be amongst us—certainly found that initial period of moving across to using an ATM to be of some difficulty. I know that I did. I do not think that is something to be worried about. In my early years it was a matter of going into a bank branch rather than dealing with the infamous hole in the wall. However, most of us have conquered this to a large degree in the last 20 years or so and now it is something that we have taken for granted as being a bread-and-butter part of the banking sector.

However, there are many things that a hole in the wall cannot do. The experience right across Australia, particularly in rural and regional areas, is that bank branches are the sorts of services that go. We lose the bricks and mortar and the services which relate to that. We are seeing in a range of ways more innovative solutions now being used to deal with some of these issues. That is a good thing, but the bottom line—and this is something that the committee found in its inspections—is that there is still a general and genuine view pervading the community in many rural and regional areas that, although in many respects the new services were good and occasionally in some respects they were better, overall service delivery had dropped and that that was detrimental to the operation of the local community. When you take away those banking services, you end up in a situation where they are simply the first things to go. Then the stores start to leave. The next thing you know—and we saw them—some towns effectively almost turn into ghost towns, not quite overnight but certainly in the passing of merely several years.

With ATMs the question is: what is happening with respect to the fee structures in those areas? A review is going on at the moment, looking at the question of ATM fees, and there is a working party of the industry, which has come forth with some recommendations about how to deal with those fees. In a nutshell, it involves the abolition of certain fees and a recommendation for more transparency in charges so that when you look at an ATM you would be able to see what you would be charged for undertaking a particular transaction. In the scope of that, there would effectively be a deregulation of what we call foreign ATM fees—that is, when you use an ATM of another institution. In my case, as a Commonwealth Bank customer, if I were using a Westpac, an ANZ Bank or a National Australia Bank ATM, it would be a question of what fee would be charged in those circumstances. By deregulating this area, the concern is that we would potentially find absolutely exorbitant fees being charged, particularly in rural and regional areas but also in some metropolitan areas, depending on the particular circumstances.

The situation with respect to rural and regional Australia is that it is potentially very damaging. Certainly some of the evidence that was taken at the hearing into this matter highlighted that. The representative from the Country Women's Association, Chris Connolly from the University of New South Wales and representatives from the Australian Consumers Association stressed the fact that many things could happen in this area and that the international experience suggested very clearly that rural and regional communities should be very concerned about what might happen.

We are talking about a situation where, over the last decade or so, some 750 branches have closed, and those communities have been put into a situation where they need to use electronic banking. Forty per cent of Australian transactions were at foreign ATMs, and this proportion is likely to be higher in the bush where there is often only one bank in a town and therefore not the same level of choice that you would have in metropolitan areas. In my case now, because of these sorts of fees, I look for Commonwealth Bank ATMs rather than using another institution's ATM, because I know that I will be dealing with some additional cost.

talk.start.para: —For once you are an informed consumer!
—As the member for Scullin said, for once I am an informed consumer. It is a new experience—
—Out of character!

—and out of character, as he says, but there you go. It just goes to show that you can teach an old dog new tricks in some cases—but not always. The transaction rate even now, with respect to these fees, can range between $1.35 and $2. When you look at the movement in these foreign ATM fees as they currently stand, before we go to deregulation, you see that they have increased by something like 250 per cent since 1995.

speech.para: What we are saying is that there are several bottom lines which ought to be the basis of the implementation of these reforms and which we worry about, given the report as it currently stands and where the working party is up to with respect to recommendations. Firstly, we believe that any change should reduce the overall cost of banking to customers. This should be a logical conclusion of these changes, because the fact is that, when you do an examination of the actual cost to the institution for undertaking this service compared to the fees that are charged for electronic transactions, those fees are almost invariably at a significantly higher level of profit than is reasonable for the provision of the service. There should be—and, in our view, there must be—a reduction in the overall cost of banking to customers in this area. We also need to ensure that customers in regional areas are not slugged with higher fees than those charged in the major cities. I will come back to that in a minute. We need to prevent institutions with large ATM networks from using their market power to impose higher charges on customers of smaller institutions.

One of the recommendations in the report which Labor has strong concerns about is recommendation 1. I will read out that recommendation. It mentions the creation of `safeguards that would ensure that people living in country towns and remote communities do not incur significantly higher fees or charges for using a foreign ATM and that an unreasonable or unwarranted differential in fees and charges between those in rural and remote areas and those in metropolitan areas does not develop'. The key point there is `an unreasonable or unwarranted differential in fees and charges'. Although the majority of the committee said that we should not be in a situation where there is an increase in charges for certain areas, that is actually conceding that there is scope for—and, in fact, it is effectively endorsing—differential fee charging. While it is saying that it should not be unreasonable or unwarranted, it is still saying there is not a problem with it actually occurring.

The member for Wannon is present today and I am sure he would be concerned about what the results might be there. Going by this recommendation, the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Financial Services has basically said that it is okay to have a differential rate for foreign ATM transactions between the city and the country. That is what it has basically said. It has said that the differential should not be unreasonable or unwarranted, but it is still saying it can be there. The fact of the matter—and the member for Wannon has some expertise in these matters, given that he is the chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration—is that, over time, we have seen a lot of evidence on the way that banking institutions have operated with respect to the provision of services. I think that, if we asked many members of the public and certainly many members of parliament who deal with regional and rural areas in particular whether the actions of the banks with respect to branch closures over the years have been reasonable or warranted, we would find that, in many cases, there would be significant concerns.

The fact is that being reasonable and not introducing unwarranted changes is not something that we have come to expect from banking in this country. We can be sure that, with this sort of change, when you open the door they will use every capacity to try to make sure they keep that door open and use it to great effect. That has been the experience in this area where you have had changes and scope for fee increases. Look at the increase we have seen in fees just in this case under the current system—some 250 per cent since 1995, just with this type of fee. When you look at the situation with fees overall, right across the board with banking, you know that they have a very different view of what is unreasonable or unwarranted.

I am not convinced by the guarantees from the banks. I am not convinced from the wording of that particular recommendation from the committee that what we are going to see is a situation where rural and regional communities get a fair go. I think we are in real danger now of seeing a divide developing—a divide that will mean that it is more expensive than it should be for people in those sorts of communities. I want to make it very clear: the Labor Party will not stand by and let this occur. Other parties have to look at their positions on this, but they can be very clear that we will not stand by and let this happen. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In rising to speak in this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004, I indicate my support for the second reading amendment moved by our spokesperson which talks about the government and its budget, the waste and mismanagement of the budget and the wrong priorities that have resulted in a Medicare safety net that does not protect families from increasing health costs and declining levels of bulk-billing. I have had the opportunity to talk about this phenomenon in my local area, where we see a decline in the levels of bulk-billing and an increase in the number of people who are attending the accident and emergency centre of the Northern Hospital. Something in excess of 60 per cent of attendances there are categories 4 and 5, which could be dealt with by general practitioners if they were available. Part of the reason that people attend the hospital is the lack of after-hours services by GPs, the low level of GPs in the outer suburban area that I represent and the fact that there is a decline in the levels of bulk-billing.

speech.para: The second point in the second reading amendment was on inadequate funding and higher fees for students seeking access to higher education. This debate occurs at a time when one of the local universities servicing the northern suburbs of Melbourne, La Trobe University, has indicated that it will increase its HECS fees by 25 per cent. This is making it harder for people, at a crucial time in their lives, to make the decision to go forward and take the opportunity that tertiary education gives them. It is no use saying that because of the way the HECS system works they are able to defer the payment. These people know that at the end of their course they are going to have an increased level of indebtedness that they are going to have to work off during their lifetime, which is an impediment to their decision to go forward to tertiary education.

The third item is the growing number of families who are financially squeezed in trying to balance work and family. In the outer suburbs of Melbourne this is clearly identified by the way in which people are feeling the squeeze of trying to establish their family home, juggle their responsibilities with family and, at the same time, stay in employment—often where they have to travel long distances, because a lack of local infrastructure to support them is getting to a crucial stage.

The last item in the second reading amendment is the 500,000 Australians waiting up to five years to get their teeth fixed. I have had the opportunity to talk about the need for the Commonwealth's involvement in a dental health scheme on a number of occasions. As each day goes by it is clear that there could be great advantage brought about if the Commonwealth were to decide to enter into a partnership with the state and territory governments and community organisations that are working in this field to ensure that we can get back to a negligible waiting list, as we saw when the Commonwealth Dental Health Scheme was in existence.

Today, I want to use the opportunity provided by this wide-ranging debate on these appropriation bills to talk about the way we discuss public issues in the Australian parliament. I want to illustrate this by using four examples of current issues being discussed to indicate not only the ways in which the parliament could display its strengths but also the weaknesses in the way we deal with things. I want to try to suggest ways we can improve parliamentary discussion of important issues. The first item I want to mention is the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD: Intelligence on Iraq's weapons of mass destruction. As an aside, I am pleased that the committee's secretary is in the chamber at the moment and I congratulate her on her involvement in this report. This is an important example of the way in which this parliament can work at its finest.

Subsequent to the report being released, I am yet to be convinced that it is being handled in a proper way. I was a little disappointed that only half an hour was available for discussion of this during Monday's private members' business. That is no reflection on those who allocate the time, but it illustrates my point. Especially in this case, when there are four members of the House of Representatives who are members of the committee, they should have been given a longer time than five or ten minutes to talk about it in the chamber. I hope that we get an opportunity as a parliament to discuss the contents of the report, because the items that this report covers are very important. They are not only important for the historical basis of the government's decision to involve Australian troops in Iraq but also, as I have had the opportunity to say before, as an example of public policy decision making and the way in which a government portrays the information it has and uses as the basis for a decision, which then leads—if it is not done carefully—to a distrust of the way in which those decisions are made.

It is really about the political scenario that the government used to, in a way, pick the items which were available to it that it wished to latch onto. The other elements go to more rigorous investigation and examination of the information available. But most importantly it goes to the way in which that information was used in justifying to the community decisions that the government made. If on this occasion, as I believe, this information was used to the extent that decisions were brought forward long before they really had to be made, there is a large part of the public that then, on that basis, asks, `Why would we in future believe any of the decisions that a government makes to commit troops overseas?' I hope that as a parliament we get an opportunity to more fully discuss this report.

The second item I wish to reflect upon is the US free trade agreement. It will not surprise members that I approach this with a great deal of caution, right down to the fact that I would be much happier if we were actually talking about a fair trade agreement with the United States. That perhaps gives a hint about the angle that I come from. That is perhaps not the majority view of the Australian parliament. I am not sure that it is the majority view of the Australian Labor Party. But I will simply keep up the fight. I think it is an angle from which we have to approach these problems and from which we can improve our best interest in dealing with our trading partners and opponents.

My beef about the United States free trade agreement is that, in the two to three weeks since the late Australian time that this was settled upon, (a) we have not seen the detail of the document and (b) there has not been a proper discussion by the parliament about the free trade agreement. Critics will say that I am being unfair because when this appears magically after being legally scrubbed—or whatever the technical terms are for the state that it is in at the moment—it will be going to the committee systems of the parliament, and that should suffice. But I believe this is a situation in which there should have been a ministerial statement and in which there should have been a debate.

Since this agreement has been cobbled together into its final state there have been 17 questions without notice, including three today from the opposition. But before today there were 14, four of which came from the opposition and 10 from government members. At the end of the day, those 10 are dorothy dixers. Within the limitations of the standing orders—and again I do not wish to reflect upon decisions made by people about the legitimacy of questions under the standing orders—they are used to elicit an angle, to allow the Minister for Trade to get up and give the government's spin and angle.

Instead of that government spin and angle about this free trade agreement there should have been an announcement by way of a ministerial statement in the parliament about the government's view on the agreement. That would have led to a response by the opposition and perhaps somewhere down the track a fuller discussion by members of both houses about the intent of the agreement. I am surprised that this has not occurred if we are to believe the government when they say that this is an important agreement. If it is so important, it should have been subject to a discussion and a debate.

As I have said, the fact that these matters are not sufficiently discussed is a flaw in the way in which we deal with them. This is something that perhaps should have had fuller discussion during the negotiations. There were a lot of views about. I do not think it is an unhealthy prospect that in a parliamentary democracy like ours there should be a divergence of views. I note that the government seems to want to fit the opposition in its view about the free trade agreement by indicating that it is motivated by pure anti-Americanism and things like that.

It has been clear from the outset that the Leader of the Opposition has said that he wants to look at this agreement with Australia's best interests in view. It is pretty hard to do that when you do not have the detail of the agreement. Having said that, I think we have been fairly consistent in the view that we have about this agreement—that it should be viewed in that way. One of the shortcomings—because of the things that have been in and out, the things that are at the edges and the timetables that are used in some sectors—is whether it is a comprehensive trade agreement, which is a necessity if we are going to have a bilateral agreement.

The third issue that I wish to raise—and I wish to express a great disappointment about the way in which the parliament has been treated in this case—is the Treasurer's statement of last week about Australia's demographic challenges. I honestly do not know where he delivered his address—that is only because I have not done the proper research—but what I know is that it was not done in the parliament. And if this is such an important issue, as perhaps quite rightly the Treasurer has flagged, then this place is the venue where this should have been discussed.

Whilst I note that a couple of the papers that were released at the address allow for public discussion, this address clearly could have been a ministerial statement. Again, there has been a missed opportunity to use the venue that the parliament provides for the proper discussion. If it was good enough for the Treasurer to release his Intergenerational Report at the time of the 2002-03 budget and if this is a work in progress that arises from that, it should have come in to the parliament. As I understand it, none of these documents that were released last week have become parliamentary papers. They actually have no status within the parliamentary procedures, and this is a great disappointment. I would love to have the opportunity directly, not through asides during this debate, to give my comments about the lack of direction that I think these documents show about Australia's demographic challenges and to properly debate the meagre propositions that the Treasurer has put forward as solutions: the notion that we should work till we drop and things like that. This is an issue that should be debated. It should have been presented as a ministerial statement; the papers should be parliamentary papers that are open to discussion.

Finally, the fourth thing I want to raise to illustrate my disappointment about the way in which the parliament is not being used properly is to touch upon Indigenous health. The week before last, the Australians for Native Title and Reconciliation held a conference about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health. The Indigenous health rights campaign launch I think was on 18 February. Directly, my interest in this arises from my membership of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs when it produced its report, Health is life:a report on the inquiry into Indigenous health. At the time, we wanted to make sure that this was the last time that there was a need for such a report and that we set out the basis for the way in which Australia could go forward with its Indigenous people to improve the health of those Indigenous people.

When this committee inquiry was launched there was some suspicion that it was an attempt in some way to be negative about what was going on with a clear inference that perhaps there had been excessive expenditure which had drawn little results in the improvement of Indigenous people's health. Clearly, our inquiry showed that the additional amount of money that is spent on the health of Indigenous Australians is actually meagre when compared to non-Indigenous Australians. At the ANTaR launch two weeks ago, the AMA's 2003 report card says that the level of health spending for Indigenous people is 22 per cent higher than for non-Indigenous people, but the need is 200 per cent greater. Really it is not surprising given the state of Indigenous Australian's health that there would be an additional amount being placed at the disposal of those charged with improving the health of Indigenous people. But it is minor; that amount is minor compared to the need. We really have to face up to that.

After the committee's report Health is life in May 2000, it disappointed me to read the speeches and papers delivered at the Indigenous health launch on 18 February. There was a speech, for instance, by the AMA President Dr Bill Glasson that says things like, `We should ask ourselves why Indigenous Australians are admitted to hospital at twice the rate of non-Indigenous people?' He said in his speech:

quote.para: I believe all Australians should ask the question why one group of people in our community faces a health reality worse than people in many third world countries.

speech.para: In their report card, there is a graph, and it shows the relationship between the percentage of the Australian population as a whole expected to live to age 65 and the percentage of Aboriginal Australian males and Aboriginal Australian females expected to live to age 65. The figures for Aboriginal people are below the figures for people in countries such as Nigeria, Nepal, Bangladesh, India, Thailand and Vietnam. I seek leave to incorporate the graph in Hansard.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Wannon. In these brief remarks about Indigenous health today—I owe it to a lot of people that helped the committee's inquiry three or four years ago to return to these items—I make the point that my disappointment is that we do not discuss this issue enough in these venues, whether it be the Main Committee, the main chamber or the Senate. This is something which should always be in the eyes of the Australian parliament. The report of the committee in 2000 suggested that there be annual reporting to the parliament. The reason for this was deliberate: it was so that these facts would be in our faces as legislators so that we could not ignore them.

speech.para: When you look at the facts on the AMA report card, you see that diabetes is eight times higher, respiratory conditions are four times higher and circulatory conditions are three times higher for Aboriginal Australians than they are for the rest of the population. The life expectancy of Indigenous Australians is still 20 years less than it is for non-Indigenous Australians. When we compare that figure to the figure for comparable countries, such as the United States and New Zealand, we see that the gap is only five to seven years. And they believe that they have a problem. They understand that that is not good enough. But why is there such a disparity? Why is there a disparity of something like 15 years in the outcomes?

We need to make sure we have discussions about how we can best improve the way in which Indigenous communities can best deal with these problems. This has to be a partnership. We cannot let the events of a couple of weeks back in Redfern cloud our judgment about the ability of Indigenous communities to deal with these issues. When they put forward their view about what is required, we need to listen to them and we need to act upon those suggestions. When people come forward, like at the launch of ANTaR, we should listen to them and work with people who are working in the area to make sure that we improve the things that deal directly not only with health but also proper housing, access to employment and, most importantly, their sense of belonging and their sense of grievance for past acts. That is one of the conditions that needs to be addressed. In other countries it has been addressed and there are indications that it has led to improved health outcomes. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is with a heavy heart that I rise today to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004 and associated legislation and to outline the past eight years of this government's charter, which has included much wastage which has been covered up by even more fibbing.

speech.para: There are significant opportunities now to build a community that provides greater prospects for all its members. But the reality is that this government continues to augment the growing divide between the priorities on this side of the House and those on the other. In my electorate of Bass the constituents that I have are concerned about the issues that affect their daily lives—the issues that this government continues to sweep under the mat through its refusal to treat them as significant. These issues are appropriate access to health care, access to education, access to appropriate employment, access to a high standard of aged care, as well as looking after the environment, safety in the home and community and being able to properly care and provide for their own families.

At the beginning of this year a Roy Morgan research poll of Australians showed that the divide between Australia's richest and poorest was continuing to grow—a trend the Australian Council of Social Services believes is related to rising levels of crime and disparities in literacy and other basic life skills. When these results were published, ACOSS President Andrew McCallum said:

quote.para: The rich-poor divide should not be made worse by the major political parties using the budget surplus and a federal election to offer some voters a tax cut. This would mean the poorest people in this country—those who don't have a job—will get no benefit from a cut. At the same time the capacity of our national government to address urgent problems in health, education and welfare would be reduced.

speech.para: He suggested that it would be of much greater benefit to turn around this divide in more practical ways, such as using the budget surplus to help low- and middle-income families by improving the family tax benefit system, to get help to those people who need it most; use it to improve the value of rent assistance for jobless people and reduce the impact of housing related poverty; to increase the opportunities for job training, whether through increased TAFE and university places or through greater real work opportunities; to enhance universal health care services such as bulk-billing for a doctor; or for equal access to education.

These types of solutions are sensible solutions to problems that are significant to the people of Bass and the people of Australia. These are, in fact, the types of solutions that the government itself had identified previously in its work and family policy documents, which have recently been discovered in leaked cabinet documents—documents that the government is now seeking to cover up. They are solutions that were discarded by a government more interested in spending much-needed money for social services on increased defence capability and security measures—a decision that has only served to destroy the government's credibility and highlight its disregard for the Australian people.

However, these solutions included things like more flexible working arrangements for women returning to the work force from parental leave, and addressing the hardship created by inconsistencies in the family benefits system. But instead the government chose to allow families to continue to fend for themselves, while the Prime Minister played cowboys and Indians in the United States. While the Prime Minister has been off playing deputy sheriff, he has left his ministers home alone—and oh, dear, what a mess they have made while they have been left alone.

The government's ministers have succeeded in utter mismanagement and waste of funds in all essential services. They have succeeded in reprioritising what should be the government's agenda—that is, the insurance of the wellbeing of all Australians. The Minister for Health and Ageing, when he speaks about health, has gone one step further towards completely destroying access to health care services, while the Minister for Education, Science and Training has managed to further alienate Australian students who have worked hard for a place in a university—not to mention the Minister for Ageing, who it appears has great difficulty finding anybody who will play nice with her.

The latest bulk-billing figures were released recently and again show a drop in the percentage of people who are able to access a bulk-billing doctor. The national average has now dropped a further 3.1 per cent to 66.5 per cent, and in Bass it is sitting now at 43.6 per cent—the lowest in Tasmania. If the government really believes that its MedicarePlus policy will have any benefit for providing appropriate health care services then it is even more out of touch than anyone could have previously thought. The MedicarePlus policy will do nothing to solve falling bulk-billing rates. Bulk-billing rates have been failing consistently under this government, and everything it does completely undermines getting access to a doctor. This policy further takes away the universality of the Medicare system and discriminates against those not in the lowest socioeconomic group. It will advance a two-tiered arrangement, where people will fall through the cracks, unable to access any type of health service.

It is not good enough that the government continues on its path to create two-tiered systems in all our basic services—systems that only lead to further increases in the divisions between the richest and the poorest in our communities. Another developing two-tiered system is the education system, a system where wealthier families are able to buy places in universities while the number of HECS places for the not so wealthy families, whose children have worked hard through their secondary school years to earn a place on merit but miss out because of decreases in funded places, has declined.

However, the government has assured us all that there was a definite increase in the number of places, and in fact says it increased the number of places at the University of Tasmania by 1,003. It appears that it is a little confused here. If the government funded an extra 1,003 places at the University of Tasmania, how does that explain the fact that the number of students who missed out on a place this year was 1,606, compared to the 1,416 students who missed out on a place last year? By most calculations, this is actually an increase of 190 students—or 13.4 per cent—who missed out. It seems that the government has been tricking us and has not really created an extra 1,003 new places but has reallocated existing places that were previously funded on the cheap. The government has a dismal record in education policy. It has no commitment to ensuring talented students have access to affordable education. Its only education commitment is towards a user pays system—a system that destroys the opportunity unless you can pay for it.

Of course access to a university education, while important, is not a priority for everyone, and in Bass there are many more people who are concerned because they cannot get access to TAFE courses and appropriate job training courses. Even in an environment where there are significant identified skill shortages, many younger people cannot get into skills based training because the government simply refuses to fund the appropriate training facilities.

The government also continues to prop up the Job Network system despite it being a significantly flawed financial model that the minister and the government continue to throw even more money at in an attempt to bail it out. The Job Network continues to fail the long-term unemployed, and data collected through the Department of Family and Community Services shows that the number of people who have been unemployed for more than a year is up by almost 6,000 since November last year. In Bass the unemployment figures are currently sitting at nine per cent. How does the government expect to help people back into the work force when it continues to slash labour market programs by $1 billion a year? How can we be expected to trust the government to assist unemployed people if it continues to do a slash and burn program on all the programs that are in place to help them?

The other area causing major concern in my electorate is that of aged care. We look forward to the elusive Hogan report into aged care services—the report commissioned by the government, the report that has so far cost $7.2 million, but the report that the minister refuses to release. Interestingly, today, Professor Hogan, the author of the report has started to talk about it himself, probably getting fed up with the government not doing it. In Bass, aged care services are in trouble. There are currently 11 aged care services in the north-east and the providers hold grave fears that if the government funding is not increased then many of these services will simply not be able to remain operational.

These services are telling me that there is a real danger that many Tasmanian services will have to close their doors because they are not able to remain financial under the current subsidies. It is not just closing businesses; it is closing people's homes. In Tasmania, service providers have identified issues like funding equalisation as significant because it essentially means that the funding for Tasmanian aged care services will continue to decrease in order to bring the national funding level into line. It is not a bad idea to have a national funding adjustment but it should be done so that states are not disadvantaged. It is not a viable option when the subsidy rates in one state are decreased leading to a significant difficulty in maintaining the current standards.

These reductions are really hurting aged care services in Tasmania. They are impacting on the ability of services to not only maintain the level of care they are renowned for but also to simply survive. This is a point that has been further compounded by the decisions by the Salvation Army to sell off 15 of its 19 aged care services across Australia and the Seventh Day Adventist Church to sell its two services in Tasmania. These are decisions that have caused great distress to organisations that have done excellent jobs in the provision of a high standard of aged care over the years but which now say that they can no longer viably and with good conscience provide such services. The Seventh Day Adventist Church has already sold its services to the Presbyterian Church, which continues to provide services to its residents. The Salvation Army is now in negotiations with prospective buyers for Tyler Village, which provides a home for 75 residents and employment for 85 staff in Launceston.

With such organisations saying that the system is unmanageable, what hope is there for a robust future for the aged care industry under this government? The government also has to stop treating older people like second-class citizens. The services that the government is refusing to fund appropriately are people's homes; they are part of their lives. The government must stop its dehumanisation of older people and release the report into aged care services so that it can start engaging in the debate about the best way to appropriately fund and manage aged care services, not about the best way to get out of it.

Let us be frank: why stop at older the people? This government really has to stop its complete disinterest in anyone who cannot directly contribute to its election coffers.
