Take the treatment of essential services in regional Australia as a point in case. The government recently saw it as necessary to close the Launceston Bureau of Meteorology because it was apparently not cost-effective. However, an unexpected community outcry saw it making policy on the run again and it decided at the same time to suddenly open a shopfront experiment in order to pacify the locals and stop the community backlash about the loss of more regional services and more regional jobs. What is really interesting is that in estimates, only three days before, the bureau made no mention of any future plan to set up a shopfront. Yet, after severely underestimating the reaction that such a closure would have in Launceston, they have suddenly announced plans that were apparently on the agenda for a very long time.

This decision has been made in order to satisfy the reported 15 per cent funding cut across the board, at least in Tasmania, that the government has enforced—cuts that are part of an ongoing budgetary squeeze by the government, which includes refusals to fund staff pay rises or even supplement pay rises cuts that have seen the bureau's budget dwindling ever lower since they were forced to take action, in this case, to downsize services or, as Dr Love called it in estimates, `de-man.' Based on this, the government must be asked how it can justify or clarify its $27 million fit-out for the bureau's Melbourne head office as a cost-effective measure, while the salaries for three positions in a regional weather office are not.

I am told that the bureau had no consultation with the Launceston office about its decision to centralise services in Hobart. It was a decision made at a management level for an economic reason and a decision that in turn significantly increases the workload in the Hobart office. Staff down there have not been consulted, so they do not know how they will provide the service either.

How will the government ensure that the local weather information accessed by the Launceston community, such as farmers or the local winemaker who calls the office each year to discuss the forward forecast at length, remains? The winemaker plans his grape picking schedule by this forecast. What about the marine industry, the professional fishers, the builders and the myriad outdoor occupations that rely on the quality daily contact they have with the Launceston office? How will these professionals have access to the same standard of service from an overworked, overloaded and unconsulted team based in Hobart with very limited local knowledge? Professional meteorologists are telling me that replacing people with automatic instruments is not the answer. Instruments cannot report visibility or the extent of mist or fog and they cannot identify cloud types or distinguish between sea state and swell height.

This decision should not be based purely on economics; it should also be assessed as a significant safety issue, as well as an industrial issue. And while the government has said it will create two new positions at the shopfront service, it has said that the current staff who hold their jobs and have held them for some time will have to reapply for those jobs, because it refuses to transfer them over. It is unfortunate that, as an economic issue, the government is assessing the future of the Bureau of Meteorology, particularly because of the impact on regional areas. The Launceston office was first, but I understand that there are in fact plans to possibly shed up to another 140 jobs across all the regional weather bureaus. This type of action would be a terrible blight on regional areas not only in terms of the loss of employment in regions but also because of the loss of essential regional services—services that should not be centralised to the nearest capital city.

Another example of how this government carries out its consultative processes is the National Airspace System. This is a system that has been one calamity after another, and I am sure members are aware that I have followed this quite closely. It is a completely inappropriate system for Australia's airspace. It was introduced with no consideration of industry concerns. It is missing vital safety information and there has been no appropriate training or assessment for pilots. The National Airspace System has essentially turned Australia's airspace into what has been described as an unprecedented unsafe operating environment culminating in what was a serious near miss in the airspace above Launceston on Christmas Eve last year.

This incident lead to a review of the system by the government's own Transport Safety Bureau, which found that the National Airspace System posed a safety risk and recommended a review. It has also led to the announcement yesterday that AirServices Australia is planning on moving a transportable radar unit to Launceston to assist Melbourne based air traffic controllers and to increase aircraft surveillance over Tasmania. This system is normally stored in Melbourne, but is to be kept operational in Launceston because under the current airspace system with the type and volume of commercial and general aviation traffic, the airspace in Tasmania has become unsafe. However, if someone else's machine breaks down, the Launceston machine will be moved to go and fix up someone else's airspace, which means we return the Launceston air space to being very dangerous once again.

It is frightening that the minister and the government are prepared to put public safety ahead of their stubborn determination to implement such a system. It is a determination which saw the minister convene industry advisory groups consisting only of those people prepared to share his point of view. The Howard government's cost-cutting agenda is dangerous and raises the question of how we can more effectively leverage regional development through the deployment of more government agencies to regional Australia. It also raises the issue of how the government can use its capital assets spend of some $60 billion a year to benefit regional Australia.

As a major purchaser of goods and services, the government currently promotes national competitive advantage and Australian and New Zealand industry development. I believe it is time for government procurement policies to be broadened to encompass regional Australia. The government notes that there is a `critical strategic role that government procurement plays within the Australian community.' The rhetoric is not supported by specific procurement policies to assist regional communities. As we know, regional centres are well known for offering cost-effective accommodation options, innovative small business, stability in the work force—and I must say that $27 million will get you an awful lot of office accommodation in Launceston.

The government publishes contracts and standing offers with a value of $2,000 or more—and I note that the Department of Finance and Administration publish some extremely high-level statistics which are drawn from this data. I would like to suggest that the Department of Finance and Administration publish statistics on the amount of government purchasing which is actually sourced from suppliers based in regional Australia.

Procurement is being seen as a strategic business tool within the private sector, but not by the Howard government. A more strategic focus on government procurement can result in significant benefits to the Australian community. In fact, every one per cent saving that can be made results in a $600 million benefit. Let us not forget the inefficiencies that exist and the benefits that can accrue from improved procurement practices. While industry is struggling with the cost of tendering in large procurement projects, we are still focused on simplistic initiatives such as putting tenders on the Internet. It seems the Howard government is still struggling with that.

After multiple false starts, the National Office of the Information Economy is struggling to get agency support with the latest AusTender initiative. How can we deal with the big-ticket issues when the basics are so hard for this government? Surely we have to move towards establishing an office of strategic procurement to streamline processes and to look for opportunities to maximise the benefit being derived from government procurement.

There is a general failing when it comes to the government spending taxpayers' money. How many examples do we need? Here is another one. How about the Customs Integrated Cargo System, a $100 million blow-out? Even with grant funds, the Howard government just cannot get it right. The government plundered a significant amount of funds through its Networking the Nation program. Many projects are not sustainable and not delivering long-term benefits, through sheer poor management by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Let us be absolutely clear on the poor management of these programs. ANAO audit report No. 12 2003-04 stated that the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts failed to `translate the government's program objectives into operational objectives that would have helped to establish an appropriate performance management framework to monitor the efficiency and effectiveness of program delivery'. ANAO found that the extent of the increase in telecommunications infrastructure development in regional areas would be difficult to demonstrate because no baseline data was collected at the start of the program and so no targets were set.

Let us highlight the failed Intelligent Island Program that the Howard government trotted out to ensure the passage of the Telstra first tranche. The Tasmanian ICT industry has been conned, jilted and spat out by this government. I have had a constant stream of constituents presenting case after case where the Intelligent Island management has led them up the proverbial garden path, wasting their time and money and with no intention of ever assisting them—just stringing them along. The $40 million allocated to this program would have been better augmented by Commonwealth investment in the Tasmanian Electronic Commerce Centre. We may then have had a sustainable program, a program which could have expanded nationally to provide assistance to other regions right around Australia. But of course the Howard government did not have the foresight, despite the efforts of many to convince them that the Intelligent Island Program was, frankly, not that intelligent. So we are now faced with an Intelligent Island basket case, which people are running around trying to salvage. At least the meagre amounts of funds provided to the Intellinc initiative appear to have been placed in competent hands.

This government has had eight years of fibbing and eight years of wasting. Where there is waste, there is a nice little web of intrigue wrapped around it to cover it up. But it is the Australian people who have been the victims of this charade being masked as governance. The Australian people have been the victims of this government's malady of a reverse Robin Hood syndrome, a syndrome that sees it uncontrollably take from the poor and give to the rich. It is time this government sought assistance for its condition and started to address the myriad problems it has created and the projects it has impaired rather than continue with its agenda of more wastage and more fibs.

talk.start.para: —I take this opportunity in the wide-ranging debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004 to firstly raise an issue of great concern to my electorate of Lalor. It is an issue that members of the House would have heard me raise on a number of occasions—some might suggest on so many that they are perhaps a bit bored with it. But it is an important issue. That issue is of course the future of the Point Cook RAAF base, which is within my electorate. A very important announcement was made on Sunday about the Point Cook RAAF base by the Parliamentary Secretary for Defence, the member for McEwen, Ms Fran Bailey. After years of community campaigning, the Howard government has agreed that Point Cook will remain in Commonwealth ownership and that its day-to-day management will be put in the hands of a trust composed of aviation and heritage groups—including the Point Cook Action Group, Point Cook Operations Ltd, a not-for-profit company which was formed specifically with the intention of becoming a manager of the site, and the National Trust—so that this very special place can be managed in the long term, in keeping with its heritage values and its very great history.

speech.para: The announcement on Sunday has delighted the local community and those who have fought long and hard to see this sort of outcome for Point Cook. I think it is important to remind ourselves that Point Cook is a truly historic site, a site of national significance. As you may be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, Point Cook is the oldest airstrip in the world that is still functioning as an airstrip. It has many of its original features, including hangars and heritage listed buildings. It was established in 1913 as the Central Flying School, and the airstrip has been in continuous use ever since. It is therefore the birthplace of the RAAF and a place of international significance, as the oldest airstrip in the world still being used as an airstrip. When we talk about the Central Flying School being started at Point Cook in 1913, it is important that we get some perspective about that, because we need to remember that in terms of aviation history the first ever flight with a person on board took place on 17 December 1903. So a mere 10 years after man's first venture with flight, Point Cook was operating a flying school, and planes have been flying from there ever since.

Apart from having history around the length of aviation service, it is the birthplace, as I have said, of the Australian Flying Corps and the Royal Australian Air Force. It was the departure point for the first north-south and east-west crossings of the continent by air and for the first aerial circumnavigation of the continent. Recognising its historic nature, Point Cook is home to both the RAAF museum and the RAAF chapel. With a site of this significance, which has continuously been in Commonwealth ownership, one would have thought that its future, that preserving its history, would always have been at the forefront of the Commonwealth's mind, but unfortunately that has not been the case. It was determined in 1997, as part of the Defence Efficiency Review and the Defence Force Reform Program that Point Cook was to be sold, that it was to move from Commonwealth ownership.

When I was elected to this parliament in 1998, being aware of the importance of the Point Cook site to the local community, I immediately sought a briefing from representatives of the then Defence Estates Organisation on what was proposed for the future of Point Cook. As we hunched over maps of the site, I was told that, from the point of view of the Defence Estates Organisation, whilst the RAAF museum would continue to operate from the site and whilst they would carve out a heritage precinct that had to be respected, as far as they were concerned, a freehold purchaser of the site would be able to do whatever they wanted to do with the remainder of the site. When I specifically asked them whether that would include closing the site so that it could no longer be used for aviation, they said that that would be all right. When I specifically asked them whether it would be possible for the site to be used for housing development, they said that that would be all right. When I specifically asked them whether it would be possible for the site to be used for industrial development, they said that that would be all right. So, from the point of view of the Howard government at that stage, they were contemplating a future where the oldest operational airstrip in the world would no longer be an airstrip, where the RAAF museum could end up marooned in a sea of housing or incompatible industrial development, and where thereafter the RAAF museum would have been limited to static displays of planes because it would not have been able to engage in heritage aviation and it would no longer have been situated at an operating airfield.

Having received that brief, I was rightly appalled. I found that in my local community, in the heritage community across Australia and in the aviation community across Australia, people were as appalled as me and I found that there was already in train a community campaign to try to ensure that Point Cook stayed in the ownership of the Commonwealth, that it was managed in a way which was always compatible with its heritage values and that it operated as an airstrip.

The depth of that community campaign can be shown by the fact that quite quickly more than 10,000 signatures were assembled on a petition which I was able to table in the House. In my capacity as local member I brought together the groups that were interested in the future of Point Cook and they were quite quickly able to agree on a vision whereby Point Cook was managed by a not-for-profit company formed by aviation enthusiasts and former members of the RAAF. The vision of that not-for-profit company—Point Cook Operations Ltd—was to have Point Cook managed in the long term as an aviation heritage, tourist and educational precinct. This would build on its strengths, its heritage value, its aviation value, the fact that the RAAF Museum is located there and the fact that flight training was occurring from Point Cook then, and continues to occur there now through RMIT. That was the vision that people were prepared to very actively campaign for.

I should note the following individuals as people who have put in huge service to this community campaign: Mark Pilkington, who has led the Point Cook Action Group, the preservation society that has always had at the forefront of its activities ensuring that Australia did not lose this historic asset for all time; Peter Scully; Gary Westley; and Brad Owens. Each of them contributed to Point Cook Operations Ltd and to bringing its vision of the site together. Each of them, particularly Peter Scully, contributed to very active lobbying of members of parliament to ensure that people understood the true significance of Point Cook.

If members are ever passing through or are in the vicinity of my electorate of Lalor—they are welcome, as long as I know they are there and what they are doing!—one of the things they should do is visit the RAAF Museum. They should meet there my friend Dave Gardner, who is the director of the museum, and they should take the opportunity to experience the history that lives and breathes all around you when you are at Point Cook. I say congratulations to each of the people who has been in a leadership role in this community campaign. Their work saw fruit on Sunday when the Parliamentary Secretary for Defence agreed that this community campaign had had the right idea all along and that Point Cook should be kept in Commonwealth ownership and should be leased for the longer term to a trust. Active in that trust will be the stalwarts of this campaign: people from the Point Cook Action Group and people from Point Cook Operations Ltd, who will be able to manage the site over the longer term in a way that is compatible with its heritage and aviation values and builds on its strength as a tourist and educational precinct. That is a very important issue from the point of view of my electorate.

I now turn from a local good news story to something that is in no way a good news story, but I think it would be remiss of me in my capacity as shadow minister for health not to take this opportunity to make some comments on the Medicare issue. I want to talk particularly on the sham safety net, which is at the forefront of the health policy debate, particularly in these two sitting weeks. I think we are all aware that our colleagues in another place are presented with making decisions about the sham safety net in the coming sitting days.

I want to take members through what I think it is important to acknowledge in the debate about the sham safety net. From Labor's point of view, we think our challenge in the coming few weeks is to save Medicare from opposition. Of course Labor will save Medicare from government. We are used to getting into government and saving universal health systems that have been destroyed by conservative governments, but in the next few weeks we have set ourselves the task of saving Medicare from opposition. If we are to save Medicare, it is vital that the Senate rejects the health minister's political fix—the so-called safety net that is up for debate at the moment. The failure of the Howard government to attend to bulk-billing rates and ensure that specialist fees are fair and reasonable has meant that out-of-pocket costs are rising.

For the Howard government the sham safety net is the solution of choice. Why is that? Despite the fact that `safety net' are pleasant sounding words, this is yet another policy from the Howard government which is infected with its values and is another policy stepping stone on the path to the dismantling of Medicare. I want to take people through the absurd policy that this sham safety net is if you look at it in detail. First, we need to debunk the Howard government's spin about the benefits of the sham safety net. The truth is that, on the Howard government's own figures, only 220,000 families or individuals will benefit from the sham safety net in a year. I note that the Minister for Health and Ageing is actually even revising those figures downwards. Professor John Deeble, one of the architects of Medicare, has said, `A generous estimate of the percentage of Australians who will benefit is three per cent and it could well be closer to two per cent.' Professor Deeble also says that of those who could benefit half would be better off under current arrangements than under the sham safety net. Specifically, Professor Deeble has calculated that the safety net benefits under the Howard Government's proposal would exceed those under the current system only for services billed at more than 25 per cent over the scheduled fee. On the basis of current GP, specialist and diagnostic fees, this means that well over half of the 220,000 people who reach the threshold would be better off under the current arrangements rather than under the proposed new sham safety net. Professor Deeble says that the proposal to cover 80 per cent of actual fees without limit is effectively uncapped gap insurance, and he is right. This is an admission that the Howard government is both unwilling to increase benefits and unwilling to do anything to ensure specialist fees are fair and reasonable.

Who wins and who loses in this situation? We have 97 per cent of Australians getting nowhere near the sham safety net. Of the three per cent who notionally benefit, Professor Deeble says that 1.5 per cent are actually better off under current arrangements. An important point to note is that for the 97 per cent of Australians who do not get on the sham safety net, the situation does not remain neutral because it is those very Australians who will bear the impact of increased fees that occur because of the inflationary cycle started by the expectations of the sham safety net. All of the data from all around the world says that with these sham safety net arrangements there is a price inflation effect on doctors' fees and specialists' fees. The 97 per cent of Australians who do not get anywhere near the sham safety net are actually worse off because they end up being slugged for higher doctors' fees and higher specialists' fees. We have a sham safety net where 97 per cent of Australians lose and of the three per cent who are notionally better off, half are actually better off under current arrangements according to Professor Deeble, and it costs $266 million: A $266 million plan to make 97 per cent of Australians worse off and, at best, 1.5 per cent of Australians will benefit. Even talking about 1.5 per cent of Australians benefiting is misleading. You have to be $500 or $1,000 out of pocket before you can begin to benefit and who benefits is subject to all sorts of perverse and unfair outcomes.

Use of medical services is skewed. While most people have five or fewer consultations a year, a small number of people account for the vast majority of services. Of 220 million Medicare services in 2001-02, 81 per cent were for people who had 10 or more services in that year. A quarter was for people with 40 or more services. These people are much more likely to be poorer than those who saw the doctor only five times a year. The two categories chosen to receive the lower threshold—concession card status or receipt of family tax benefit A—are a poor measure of health need. After all, the family tax benefit system was set up to address another set of problems and issues entirely and there is considerable evidence that even health care cards are not an accurate measure of need.

The selection of these two categories particularly discriminates against those without dependent children and low-income individuals, while providing significant benefits to many higher income families. For example, a self-funded retiree couple of pension age earning up to $80,000 per annum is eligible for a health care card and hence for the $500 safety net, but a working couple without children earning the same amount will only be eligible for the $1,000 threshold. An individual working full-time earning $35,000 per annum who has a chronic medical condition will enter the safety net only after spending $1,000 out of their pocket, but a self-funded retiree of pension age earning up to $50,000 will qualify for the lower threshold.

The Howard government have managed to cook up a $266 million plan to at best benefit 1.5 per cent of Australians, and the tests that they have set up will not even pick the most disadvantaged 1.5 per cent. Then of course $72 million of the $266 million is wasted in administration costs. It is such a poor use of precious health dollars: $72 million gone in administration costs; 97 per cent of Australians lose out; 1.5 per cent who notionally gain would be better off under current arrangements; and 1.5 per cent notionally benefit—and they have picked the wrong 1.5 per cent.

All of these practical objections should be enough to stop this latest political patch-up job going through the Senate. But there is also a bedrock principle objection to this sham safety net. This sham safety net is all about distorting from a universal health system to a welfare system. It is all about enabling the Howard government to justify henceforth its failure to invest in Medicare, its unwinding of the Medicare system and its allowing of Medicare to wither and die. And it will do all of that under the cover of saying, `Don't worry. We have a sham safety net arrangement.' Ultimately, as the universal health system dies, we will end up with a health system like America's with private provision at the centre and sham safety net arrangements for people who are thought to be poor. And we know how badly those arrangements work in America. Anyone, including any senator, who professes a belief in Medicare cannot endorse this sham safety net arrangement. All it will do is assist the Howard government in destroying Medicare. In and of itself it benefits very few, has unfair outcomes and is a bureaucratic monster.

talk.start.para: —It is good to see that the shadow minister for health is here. If I had otherwise been able to do it, I would have had a word to her about the budget appropriations here of $14.3 million in relation to changes in the hearing services model, because I can trust that I would be able to get some sense out of the shadow minister for health where I cannot get anything out of the minister or the government. They have treated me and other parliamentarians and the people of Australia with utter contempt in terms of the bills that are before us now.

speech.para: I have constituents who can no longer get adequate hearing services directly in Bankstown. I can only guess that this $14.3 million may or may not do anything to affect their situation—it may or may not improve it. We are given virtually no indication whatsoever. It is mentioned in passing in one line by the parliamentary secretary. If you go to the bill itself and its papers, there is no more information to elucidate what this is about. Since the government in particular brought in accrual accounting you can look at the bills and the background papers and weep at the prospect of finding any real or substantial information that you would be able to hand on to any constituent not only in my electorate but Australia wide. It is extremely difficult to get the information.

The government is asking for additional appropriations. There is the normal budget process. These extra appropriations are adjustments to those original expectations of the budget. We in this House are expected to blindly accept the few scraps of information that the government has given us and say, `They are budget measures; therefore they should simply be passed.' The government has not taken the time or made the effort—it has not demonstrated enough concern to inform me or the community at large about the nuts and bolts of what it is doing, which has a deliberate effect and impact on constituents in my electorate.

I will go in particular into the question of health services in Bankstown with regard to Australian Hearing and the experience of two of my constituents. I may then go to some other matters. There is an item of $21.4 million in assistance for the victims of the Bali terrorist attacks and their families and for meeting the costs of the investigations. We know what a wicked and cruel act it was for people to have their lives stripped away from them and for people who survived but had horrific injuries. All of us had the opportunity to be with their families at the anniversary commemorations in the Great Hall. This simple line says enough about why this sum of money is being set aside and provided. But in relation to most of the other measures there is very small and partial indication.

Let us go to the $14.3 million for hearing services and to the practical problems that are being faced in Bankstown by not just two of my constituents but also many more. Australian Hearing took the time to write politely to Mr Charles Garwood, the constituent concerned. He and his wife had this experience recently. Australian Hearing wrote on 5 December informing him:

quote.para: ... Australian Hearing's Centre in Chapel Road Bankstown suffered severe damage when a hot water service burst. As the damage was extensive we had to relocate to new premises.

speech.para: They said specifically:

quote.para: You may have received other correspondence suggesting that Australian Hearing was no longer able to offer services to you at Bankstown. That is not the case. Australian Hearing is able to provide hearing services to you in your local area at any of our three new locations listed below including Bankstown.

speech.para: They indicated that these were at Chester Hill, Revesby and a new site, the Town Square Medical Centre in Bankstown Square, opposite Medicare. They apologised for the inconvenience and confusion.

What they did not tell my constituent in December 2003 but he found out, to his cost, in January 2004 is that the permanent facility that was damaged was replaced with a temporary facility. In 2003 the Bankstown centre was a permanent site for Australian Hearing, as was the Liverpool centre. When Mr Garwood had problems with his hearing aid he sought help from the Bankstown service. He had been told that those services would still be available but now he was told: `Things have changed. Now this is not a permanent centre; it is only here three days a week and we cannot fix the hearing aid on site. We can take the hearing aid from you and in eight to 10 days time, after it has been sent to Liverpool and back'—only seven kilometres or so away—`we will be able to give you the hearing aid back; or you can choose to go to Liverpool yourself to get it fixed.'

Mr Garwood, who I know extremely well, is a war veteran. That is the reason why he is eligible for this help. I will read to the House the experiences he and his wife had in trying to get the hearing aid fixed at Liverpool that day. His wife, Hilda, wrote:

quote.para: My husband aged 83 a War Veteran with a Hearing disability due to being blown up in a War Zone has their services—

speech.para: that is, those of Australian Hearing in Bankstown—

quote.para: He received a letter dated 5th Dec.03 which I enclose herewith. However the statement of hearing service in the local area is a MISNOMER. My Husband's hearing aid stopped functioning so we went on Friday the 23rd Jan.04 to Bankstown where we were told there is no such service here we are only a Medical Centre, however if you write your name and address and medical card Number and what is wrong with the hearing aid we will forward it to Liverpool and it will take 8-10 days, but if we were to go to Liverpool they would repair it straight away.

speech.para: That is completely different from the experience that they had. She further states:

quote.para: We decided to do that. It was a very hot day we went by train to Liverpool it was a long up hill walk to the Centre. They repaired his hearing aid in one and a half hours walk back to the station arriving in Bankstown it took from 10am to 4pm before we reached home totally exhausted am sure there are many more people in our age group needing this service in Bankstown. Surely it could be possible to have a repair service at least one day a week.

speech.para: I repeat that last sentence: `Surely it could be possible to have a repair service at least one day a week.' That is a reasonable thing to expect for Mr Charles Garwood, an 83-year-old veteran, and a reasonable thing to expect for his wife, Mrs Hilda Garwood, who went with him in order to get this fixed. Hilda Garwood has visited Liverpool before. She has been to Liverpool hospital. Charlie Garwood, her husband, went to Liverpool hospital time and time again when Hilda was there with a significant heart problem. I visited her there some time last year when she was there for a long period. She had a very significant condition which took her a long time to recover from. To have people in their 80s put out in that way is just not good enough.

When the permanent facility had been there for years, it is right and proper that not only the Garwoods but my other constituents could say, `If the old centre was destroyed, there should be a permanent centre for Bankstown.' It is not Woop Woop; it is the centre of Sydney. There are 180,000 people in the City of Bankstown—my electorate has 82,000, Daryl Melham's electorate has another 82,000, and there are more people as well. Bankstown is a central place in Sydney. It is easier for a lot of people to get to Bankstown than it is to get to Liverpool. They have had a situation where the permanent facility has been replaced with an inferior, temporary one. We have a high aged population in the electorate of Blaxland. Those people who have not had the experience of the Garwoods will no doubt find the same situation applies.
I made representations to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs with regard to this matter, attaching the letter from Mrs Garwood. I said, in part:

quote.para: To replace the Chapel Road Centre, the Australian Hearing Service three days a week occupies a small, claustrophobic room within the Bankstown Square Medical Centre. They provide a limited service, but have to send hearing aids elsewhere for repairs, taking up to ten days.

speech.para: If the $14.3 million here for changes to the hearing service model do not encompass changing from temporary to permanent the Bankstown centre, I suggest to the parliamentary secretary and the minister that that should be undertaken. The significant numbers of people who are disadvantaged by the current situation need to have that addressed. It is a big problem for older people. Both the Prime Minister and, more particularly, the Treasurer, recently seem to have discovered the question of an ageing Australia and the difficulties that that will incur for the government in a fiscal sense. But the real difficulties are faced by people day after day—not in 10 or 20 years time, but right now, day after day.

If you do not have adequate and proper services it is very difficult for those people who are already, in this case, paying more than $30 a year for the maintenance of this equipment and who have the extra cost, not just monetary but also on their bodies—on their systems and their nerves—of having to go to that kind of trouble. It simply is not right.

It is not right that those Australians in my electorate of Blaxland who cannot afford adequate dental care are forced by this government to wait for up to five years to get that care. You will not find any provision of moneys in either the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 or the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 for that dental care. The reason for that is that this is a coalition set of appropriations. They wiped out any future moneys for dental care for the aged and people on pensions and beneficiaries when they concluded the four years of the Keating government program which put an extra $300 million or so into dental care for the aged. As an opposition we have pledged that we will put $300 million of new money towards addressing the very real health problems of Australians living in Blaxland and other electorates where they need the intervention of the Commonwealth government because they cannot get access to proper dental services.

Hearing and dental problems are two key difficulties for the aged. Anyone here in this room and anyone listening throughout Australia who has aged relatives or friends would understand the trauma that is caused to them through the loss of appropriate and adequate hearing and the difficulty it entails in terms of dealing with their everyday problems. People would also realise how significant it is for people to have dramatic dental problems that simply are not addressed because they do not have the money. The health impact upon those people who suffer is enormous. The final cost to the community, of course, is extremely significant.

If you let these problems build and do not either take preventative measures or have early intervention, dental problems can lead to dramatic problems which can, through abscesses that become extremely severe, occasion hospitalisation and the direct intervention of surgeons in order to fix those problems. I know that—I have seen it happen. I have been the victim of dental abscesses. The same problem has happened to my wife. If they get bad enough, you can be one or two days off dying if there is no intervention. I was lucky. In my personal experience, we were able to go and get direct intervention and ensure that we got the treatment that we needed. But there are many people who do not have that recourse.

That is why these appropriations should encompass moneys for more than 500,000 Australians who are on the waiting list and who can wait up to five years or more for appropriate intervention to fix their acute dental problems. These moneys are not here, because this government has not only contempt for us in terms of providing information but also utter contempt for all of those people on that waiting list, because it simply says to them, `It's a state matter—you can sit there and wait.' You can hope that you might get your problems fixed, but the federal government will take no direct approach to this.

The member for Werriwa, when addressing Labor's national conference in Darling Harbour, quite rightly took a copy of the Australian Constitution out of his pocket and referred to the section which directly says that both health and dental services are a direct responsibility of the federal government. That was why the Keating government was able to take direct action by supporting a four-year program to fix the problem the states did not have the capacity to fix. That is why it is right, proper and just that Labor has pledged to do so. The only hope, because of the heartlessness of this government, is the election of a Labor government to directly intervene to fix those problems.

Representing people in Bankstown, I know that we have had one service after another taken away from us. It does not really surprise me that the full and permanent service of Australian Hearing was converted to a temporary visiting service and that Liverpool has taken over. This government has a set against Bankstown, and it has a set against it primarily because the former Prime Minister was a boy from Bankstown, just like me. Our experience relates to not only the Australian Hearing Service but also the department of immigration, which was completely ripped out of Bankstown—one of the most multicultural areas in Australia. I know that we have a former shadow minister for immigration and also a former Minister for Veterans Affairs—someone who has visited the electorate of Blaxland, who knows how diverse that community is, and knows how crucial it is to have services where they are needed. You will not find those services in Bankstown now, because this government has ripped them out, just like they have taken away the permanent centre for Australian Hearing. You will not find the Australian Taxation Office in Bankstown now—that building is now inhabited by the state police because this government would not provide a full regional tax office, employing more than 650 people, in the City of Bankstown.

So I look forward to Labor coming back to government and I look forward to having services put back into Bankstown, into my electorate, and having appropriations—either budgetary or these extra appropriations—to directly service the people of Bankstown, who have been so badly dealt with by this government, which has treated them with utter contempt. It has done so for no reason other than the fact that the former member for Blaxland happened to be their representative and maybe, as a secondary issue, because I worked for him. What I can promise you is this: I trust that the representations that I have made on behalf of Mr and Mrs Garwood—which is just one example of the problems that people have faced with the rolling back of the permanent service of Australian Hearing in Bankstown to a temporary service—will be addressed by the appropriate minister and that it is put back into place, as it should be, so that all of those people in Bankstown who need that service can access it.

I hold out no hope whatsoever that this government, which has been appealed to time and time again, will restore full dental service to those 500,000 Australians who need it. I trust that the next Labor government will stick to its pledge with regard to that. If you look at the rest of these appropriations, which have been so poorly dealt with in terms of information, a Labor government will not only give the services back but it will explain why it is being done. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004 give members a forum to canvass the issues that are important to our constituents—issues which in many cases are being sadly neglected by this Howard government. I would particularly like to use this opportunity to place on the public record my continuing concern about the impact that this government's spending priorities—priorities that are dramatically out of kilter with those of the general community—is having on individuals and families living in my electorate of Bowman and, indeed, people around Australia.

speech.para: Almost two years ago, in his 2002 budget address, the Treasurer released the Intergenerational Report. He heralded the document as a landmark enabling the government to draft the budget, not simply with a view to achieving short- to medium-term policy goals but also in the context of the `challenges that lie ahead for our children, our society and our government'. It seems that when the government asked `What do we need to do now to prepare for generations ahead?' unlike the rest of the community, this government did not look at the report's prediction that aged care costs would rise from 0.7 per cent to 1.8 per cent of the GDP over the next 40 years, and that by 2031 the number of Australians aged 65 and over would increase from 12.7 per cent to 22.3 per cent of the population. They did not look at those staggering figures and think that health and aged care services are areas in need of immediate attention. As we saw with the Treasurer's speech last week, they finally realised that it is high time to re-examine pensions and superannuation in the context of our ageing society, but aged care seems to have been left way down the list of priorities.

The anecdotal evidence presented by my constituents, who continue to experience terrible difficulties trying to find a place for their elderly relatives in an appropriate aged care facility, is overwhelming. Their frustration is echoed by the service providers themselves. I recently met with Mr David Angell and Ms Anne Livingston of Aged Care Queensland, the peak industry body for aged and community care providers in Queensland. With members drawn from the residential, retirement living and community sectors, Aged Care Queensland has a comprehensive understanding of the issues confronting the aged care industry in Australia.

Mr Angell and Ms Livingston identified three crucial areas that need urgent government attention if the quality Australians demand of their aged care sector is to be preserved and the pressing issue of accessibility is to be addressed. Firstly, the industry believes that the Commonwealth Own Purpose Outlays formula, as it currently stands, does not reflect the real staffing and associated costs of operating aged care services. For example, wage compensation is only increased by the amount of the safety net adjustment, bearing no real relationship to wage fluctuations in the aged care sector. Under the current formula, aged care providers are being forced to find a balance between cutting costs and providing quality care—a situation which is unsustainable. Aged Care Queensland stress that, as most aged and community care providers are run on a not-for-profit basis, they are simply unable to afford to subsidise the gap between income and costs on an ongoing basis. The standard of care will almost certainly begin to slip if this situation is not addressed, and we will see more providers follow the example of the Salvation Army and bow out of the sector, as they can no longer operate on a viable basis—at least in some of the states.

What the aged care industry is asking for is not without precedent. The Howard government introduced a new indexation formula to rectify a similar disparity between costs and income for services provided by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The opposition, on the other hand, realise that it is untenable for aged care facilities to continue to shed staff in an effort to cut costs, thereby blowing out the staff-to-resident ratio. A Latham Labor government would oversee the introduction of minimum staffing requirements in the aged care sector to put an end to the current situation, in which the Health Services Union reports that one or two staff members can have responsibility for up to 70 residents at a time. We recognise that our seniors and our aged care workers deserve much better than that.

We heard the minister recently claim that the Howard government has increased funding to aged care by 100 per cent, but such a claim is vastly different to the picture painted by the people on the ground in the aged care industry. In an interview on ABC's AM program of Wednesday 11 February, Richard Gray of Catholic Health Australia said:

quote.para: There's been inadequate increases in funding for number of years now, and the current funding regime is not adequate enough to meet quality care needs ...

speech.para: Aged Care Queensland estimates that residential care providers are currently around $406 million behind the level of funding needed to meet the real cost increases that the sector has faced since 1997. At the recent summit of the National Aged Care Alliance, industry insiders suggested that an immediate rise in funding of $10 per bed per day is required to bring residential services back to a level at which they can comfortably meet service standards, maintain and upgrade facilities and equipment and retain an adequate-sized and appropriately skilled staff.

Of course, residential care is just part of the aged care industry. Many of the older members of the community would prefer to be able to remain in their own homes, living as independently as possible for as long as possible. This is where the third area at the centre of Aged Care Queensland's concerns comes in—that is, the underfunding of community care. Having absorbed a $120 million gap between funding and costs, the community care sector urgently needs a 10 per cent funding increase to cover the real costs in providing care to the estimated 400,000 aged and disabled members of our community who rely on community care programs.

Aged and Community Services Australia, on behalf of respected industry bodies including Alzheimer's Australia, the Australian Council of Community Nursing Services, the Australian Medical Association, Carers Australia and COTA—the Council on the Ageing—published A vision for community care: a discussion paper in August 2002. The paper observed:

quote.para: There is increasing recognition that community care programs can no longer be considered separately from the myriad of intersecting service sectors, including residential aged care, disability services and primary and acute health services. Changes in any one of these systems inevitably affect the others, as has been the case with the reduction of length of stay in hospitals increasing the care needs of some community care clients after discharge home.

speech.para: If the level of service provided by the community care sector decreases as a result of funding shortfalls, the pressure on residential care and hospital systems will increase. In other words, failure to invest in one part of the system is going to make the whole system less effective.

According to the independent report commissioned by the Myer Foundation—2020 Vision for Aged Care in Australia—it is community care in particular that requires a substantial funding boost. The report called for the expansion of community based care with a view to shifting the mix of health care options for older Australians towards a greater availability of community care, including a greater investment in preventative health care and housing features to allow seniors to live in their own homes as long as possible as they age.

The report also advocated improved integration between aged and community care and other related services. Similarly, the aged care industry has called for prevention and health promotion to be acknowledged as an integral component of community care services. They would like to see the funding system modified so that care is available not only to those with high care needs but also to seniors with less intensive or perhaps less immediate needs to prevent further functional decline.

Greater investment in these areas would make a significant contribution to delaying and reducing the need for ongoing services in high-intensity community hospitals or residential care. My friend and colleague the member for Franklin and you, Mr Deputy Speaker Mossfield, are, like me, at the age where we may be needing those services some time in the not-too-distant future! Investing in aged care is an investment in the future for all of us. Sadly, with this government we have heard a lot of lip-service but have seen a noticeable lack of action.

talk.start.para: —Where's the Hogan report?

—The Hogan report into aged care pricing, mentioned by my colleague, is an inquiry costing some $7.2 million. It was due in December last year. It is now March and we are still waiting for the report to be made public. While the government sits on its hands the aged care industry is left in limbo, with no certainty as to how their funding system will be altered and how that will impact on their capacity to ensure that, when they need it, all Australians can easily access high-quality care. This is a state of uncertainty that will continue once the Hogan report is finally released, while the government takes its time to respond. If the delays we have experienced waiting for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to issue a final response to the Clarke report are anything to go by—and, of course, the Prime Minister had to bail her out of that one and made certain announcements today—it looks like we are still at the beginning of a long, drawn out process. It is time for the government to take responsibility—to respond to the calls for action emanating from the industry and the growing numbers of seniors in our community and ensure that the imminent crisis in aged and community care is nipped in the bud.

speech.para: On behalf of Aged Care Queensland, the many dedicated workers in the aged care industry, and the seniors living in the Bayside and Redlands districts—and, indeed, in all of Queensland and Australia—I call on the government to look at these serious funding issues which are facing the aged care industry and act decisively to invest in this important sector and reverse the damage done before the situation deteriorates even further. Frankly, we are seeing the results of massive budget cuts after the 1996 election, when the public voted the Labor government out of power.

Another important area in which the government is guilty of sitting on its hands is, of course, that of families and Centrelink benefits. Disappointingly, although fully aware of the problems in this area—as evidenced by the Prime Minister's address to the National Press Club prior to the last election, which identified balancing work and family as a key priority for his third term, and the leaked cabinet documents that emerged recently setting out the deficiencies of the government's family policies—the government has nonetheless chosen to do nothing.

In the face of a damning report from the interdepartmental work and family task force, made up of representatives from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Family and Community Services, the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations, Finance and Treasury, which was before cabinet way back in December 2002, the government has done nothing. Even though it is aware that second earners in single-income families in the $30,000 to $40,000 income range are paying, for each dollar earned, 60 per cent plus tax and net child-care costs, that to solve the problem of the flawed family benefit system significant changes are needed, that many families have found the precise forward income estimation difficult and that the issue of debts has detracted from community recognition and that features such as this can be perceived by families as having impacts—these are all words used in that report—it has done nothing. My colleague the shadow minister for family and community services hit the nail on the head when he reflected:

quote.para: ... frustrated at the cover up, government bureaucrats have taken matters into their own hands by leaking key cabinet-in-confidence documents.

speech.para: Rod Whyte, formerly a senior manager with Centrelink, has written a book on the longstanding and appalling error rate within Centrelink and the agency's failure to fully investigate the causes of errors which lead to incorrect payment. Imagine that: enough errors, debts unfairly raised against clients who have done nothing wrong and adventures in mismanagement and inefficiencies to fill a book. In an interview with the Australian this week, Mr Whyte said:

quote.para: Many customers over the course of the next 12 to 18 months will pay dearly for Centrelink's mistakes, mainly through having to pay back sizeable debts that weren't their fault.

speech.para: Mr Whyte's criticisms have been backed by the Australian National Audit Office and by literally hundreds of constituents in my own electorate of Bowman who have suffered significant financial penalties due to Centrelink's inadequate performance. They are people like Mrs Gail Lee of Alexandra Hills, whose dealings with Centrelink have been quite an ordeal. I have written to Minister Anthony about the situation and hope that I will receive his response in the not too distant future. I might mention that I have given up writing to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Patterson, who, although reputedly the senior minister, has forwarded all my past correspondence regarding Centrelink to her junior minister for response. It seems that the government, embarrassed by her efforts in the health portfolio, thought it best to give her a title and pop her in a corner where she can do no harm.

As I set out in my letter to Minister Anthony, my constituent's problems began because of another area in which the government has failed to act to assist ordinary Australians—that is, the rising cost of housing and the difficulties first-time home buyers experience getting into the market. Mrs Lee's daughter was having trouble getting a housing loan, and so in June 2003 they decided that the mother would transfer the title of her unit into her daughter's name. This would allow the daughter to present herself at the bank with equity in property so that she could secure the loan she needed to purchase her own house. As a result of this transaction, Centrelink decided that Mrs Lee had gifted away $140,000 worth of assets. Accordingly, the agency deemed her to be earning an income of $90 a week, and on 6 June 2003 Centrelink cancelled Mrs Lee's entitlement to widow allowance. This decision was taken even though, under the income test, my constituent should still have qualified for a partial widow allowance and, under the assets test, as a non home owner, she also continued to qualify for this allowance. The decision meant that she was left without any income. She was left destitute. She was forced to sell her furniture and rely on the generosity of family and friends in order to survive.

Fortunately, Mrs Lee was able to secure temporary employment, but that position no longer exists and she is left again without any income. My constituent has advised me that, although she contacted Centrelink by telephone and in person, on three separate occasions she was refused any recourse or right of appeal against the decision taken in her case. By giving out misinformation like this, Centrelink not only undermined my constituent's basic right to seek a review but caused her undue stress and financial hardship. Unfortunately, it was not the only incorrect information given to Mrs Lee. She was also told that, in her circumstances, she would not qualify for a low income earners' health care card, yet when eventually she decided, given that she had nothing to lose, to put in an application she received the health care card she had been entitled to all along.

When my office contacted Centrelink about my constituent's situation, they had another look at her case and discovered that, instead of treating Mrs Lee as a non home owner, her entitlement to widow's allowance had mistakenly been calculated and declined on the basis of the home owners asset threshold. But, because my constituent was incorrectly advised of her review rights and tried to make her own way as best she could before, in desperation, she sought the assistance of my office, she is outside the three-month limitation period to obtain any compensation for the loss she has suffered as a result of Centrelink's negligence.

It is nothing short of disgusting that my constituent, through no fault of her own, has suffered months of stress, has been forced to sell off most of her assets simply in order to survive and is left with no course of redress, no back pay and no apology. Centrelink will not even reinstate her widow allowance because, having re-entered the work force, her circumstances have shifted and she would only be eligible for Newstart payments even though her position existed only briefly. As I mentioned earlier, I am hoping to receive a response to my representations soon and I hope that, in his response, the minister acknowledges the glaring inequity of the situation and acts to ensure a fair solution is found to Mrs Lee's problems which have occurred as a result of Centrelink's repeated errors in dealing with her situation.

This is the story of just one of many of my constituents who contact my office every week who are suffering as a result of this government's cutbacks, and it is just one of the many reasons why I support the second reading amendment moved by the member for Fraser which condemns this government for its budget waste, mismanagement and wrong priorities. As a former parliamentary secretary in the area of social security for something like four years, I know the dedication and work that is done by people that work at Centrelink, which used to be known as the Department of Social Security. In the vast majority of cases, they are good people. They do a good job and they help out as much as they can under very adverse circumstances. I must say that it must be absolutely trying for them with all these cutbacks and the amount of money that is taken away by the government from these sorts of services.

We heard my friend the member for Blaxland talk about how many services had been taken away from his electorate. I think just about every Labor electorate in Australia can say that that is the case. Medicare offices have closed all over the place and people have been forced to use expensive transport just to go and get a few dollars back. The reality is that it is not the fault of the public servants. I want to make that very clear here today. It is not the fault of the public servants; it is the fault of the government that does not give them enough money and tries to cut back. Now we have Mr Howard repeating the scenes of 2001, starting again to see if he cannot flip-flop on issues and start to buy the next election. You can see it happening now the way it did in 2001. But I say to him: `Don't just do it at election time. Pay the money out. Give it back to where it belongs. Don't forget that governments are here to service the electorates and the people in this country.' It is about time that we started getting back to reality. It is about time we started spending money on the services that the Australian public needs.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the amendment moved to the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 by the member for Fraser, which amendment covers the following vital family areas:

speech.para: (1) a costly Medicare `safety net' which does not protect families from increasing health costs and the declining level of bulk billing;
(2) inadequate funding and higher fees for students seeking access to higher education;
(3) a growing number of families who are financially squeezed and trying to balance work and family; and
(4) 500,000 Australians waiting for up to five years to get their teeth fixed.

The most important area of policy in Australia is the need to protect families. This is the direction that the Australian Labor Party is taking under the new Leader of the Opposition, Mark Latham. Before I cover those points as I go through my speech, I point out that today, 2 March, marks the eighth anniversary of my election to parliament. My intention is to take stock of the issues in my electorate. I have revisited what I said in my first speech and in other earlier speeches to see what I considered important then, comparing them to the major issues of today and how these have been addressed over that eight-year period.

One matter I mentioned in that very first speech was the massive residential development that was expected to take place in the northern part of the Greenway electorate around Parklea and Rouse Hill. I said on that occasion:

quote.para: The first stage of the Rouse Hill development centred on the Parklea release area is currently in the early stages of development and is eventually expected to house 50,000 people.

speech.para: This development has taken place as I predicted, and it is still taking place. Nearly 60,000 new residents have come to call Blacktown city home over the past 10 years. The local council has approved over 10,700 new dwellings in the past five years alone, the majority of which have been in the Greenway electorate. At 285,000 people—and growing by over 5,000 people each year—Blacktown city is the largest local government area in New South Wales and the third largest in Australia. Between the 1996 and 2001 census, Blacktown had the second largest growth of any LGA, and one in every 70 Australians now call Blacktown home.

I have seen my electorate grow in its population but shrink in its geography. This massive residential growth, as you can appreciate, Mr Deputy Speaker, has placed a considerable strain on the infrastructure needs of the region and, while much has been achieved, there is still very much more to be done. Mr Deputy Speaker, you can appreciate again that that area of infrastructure covers the whole spectrum of health, education, transport and roadworks. Much of the infrastructure work that has been completed so far has been carried out by the state Labor government. Windsor Road, which anyone from Western Sydney would be aware of, has been upgraded, but this was a long-time source of irritation and frustration to local motorists. Marayong railway station, the centre of an expanding area, has also been upgraded, with a modern lift complex to cater for wheelchair access, and the rail track has been duplicated to Quakers Hill, improving the rail service to that station. I called for this in my first speech in this place. Local residents now look forward to the completion of the duplication of the rail line right through to Riverstone, which is the last station in my electorate. Another project that urgently needs attention is the upgrading of the Quakers Hill railway station. As I said, much more needs to be done. Blacktown Hospital has been completely rebuilt by the state government and is now considered state of the art.

One other issue of infrastructure that I need to comment on is the Western Sydney orbital or, as it will become known when it is completed, Westlink M7. I have been a long-time strong advocate of this highway, even before I entered parliament. It is pleasing to see the speed at which it is now finally being constructed. I was also a member of the Greater Western Sydney Economic Development Board—a board of local businesspeople—which campaigned strongly for what we knew then as the Western Sydney orbital. I have supported the various arguments advanced by that organisation and various employer groups that the M7 would improve industrial road transport, which is vital, with many industries operating on a just-in-time principle, and its construction will lead to employment growth in the region. That will definitely be a good outcome once this road network is completed.

Unfortunately, the Howard government has ignored its responsibility to the people of my electorate with regard to this highway. The previous government had made plans to finance a certain section of it and had commenced work on it. The M7 will form the last link in the national highway system that stretches over 18,500 kilometres around Australia. Yet the Howard government ducked its responsibility to build it and basically demanded that the New South Wales government build it with a toll. The Howard government has, in effect, privatised the national highway.

In some of my earlier speeches I praised the work of the Quakers Hill family service, a joint program between Wesley Dalmar Child and Family Care and the Quakers Hill Uniting Church. This service was working with high-risk disadvantaged families and families in crisis. The 1998 annual report of this organisation indicated there had been increasing demand for counselling for families and children. Part of the stress on these families can be described by paragraph (3) of the amendment which simply says:

quote.para: (3) a growing number of families who are financially squeezed and trying to balance work and family ...

speech.para: This basically comes about because of the high mortgages families now have to contend with. There has also been an increase in the number of families with multiple problems in the area of direct family support. Reflecting on the slash and burn policies of the Howard government at the time, I said in one of my earlier speeches in this parliament:

quote.para: The reduction in department of community services funding as of July 1998 and less child care assistance to subsidise low income families being provided by the department of health and family services have brought changes to the service in the area of vocational care. As a result, fees have needed to be adjusted to accommodate the new system, which is confusing many families.

speech.para: That was clearly a problem that existed in the early period of my time in this parliament. I have here the report of the annual general meeting of 2002-03 for the Quakers Hill family service. The report shows the services the centre has continued to provide for needy families over the past 10 years. In particular, the report lists its future challenges, and I believe they really highlight what is required by low-income people in the area I represent. The future challenges for this organisation include the closing of Sundowner Village, which is a caravan park for low-income people, and the need to maintain a high level of support and advocacy with increased demands for affordable housing. Once again, I compliment the state Labor government. I have noticed in the press recently that they have introduced legislation that will make people who occupy these caravan parks a little more secure in their accommodation arrangements, and this is good news.

Other future challenges for this organisation include ensuring the sustainability of programs, developing opportunities for growth to reflect the increased population and their service provision needs and increased human services for the Rouse Hill strategic planning area. A challenge for Parklea Prison is a growth in beds from 600 to 1,200 in the women's wing. Another challenge is the potential explosion in mortgage stresses with interest rate increases. Once again, that reflects the increase in residential development of the area. On a sad note, the report also refers to the passing of Glenys Judd, a previous centre coordinator who, unfortunately, lost her fight against a major illness in January 2003. Glenys and I developed a fairly good working relationship, and I was happy to work through her to assist this organisation. Glenys made a major contribution to the work of the centre and will be sorely missed.

I return to the issue of child care, which is a major issue in my electorate. In 1996-97 there was an $820 million cut to child care which has led to increased fees and reduced child-care assistance, low-quality care and the closure of several services. At the time, child-care closures occurred in my electorate in Seven Hills, Marayong, Riverstone and Blacktown. If we move forward to the present day, we can see the results of this short-sighted policy of funding cuts. At a Senate estimates committee hearing in June last year, we learnt that there was a shortage of after school care in the Blacktown local government area of over 1,000 places. This was well in excess of any other area in New South Wales or Australia. The next highest shortfall was in the neighbouring area of Holroyd, which had almost half that number with a 590-place shortage.

As I have said, there has been a huge residential development, with a lot of young families moving into the area, yet there has been a reduction in the availability of child-care places. This has come about because of the slash and burn policies of the Howard government in the 1997 and 1998 budgets. Of particular concern is the dramatic shortage of child care for the zero to two age group in Blacktown. The electorate of Greenway has the third highest number of children in this age group, behind the neighbouring Western Sydney electorates of Werriwa and Chifley. This highlights the needs of the child-care sector in our area of Western Sydney. For this reason it is encouraging to see the response of the new Leader of the Opposition, Mark Latham, to this crisis. The member for Werriwa has called the rates of pay for child-care workers a national disgrace. He said:

quote.para: At $13 an hour it is impossible to attract the qualified teachers to run the education programs so it's more than child minding and becomes child development.

speech.para: I think that is a very important statement. It is not simply a question of childminding; it is a question of educating the children and educating their development in these early age groups. The Leader of the Opposition has committed an incoming Labor government to increasing the salaries of child-care workers, increasing the number of child-care places, reducing waiting lists and improving the affordability of child care for parents.

If I could just once again refer to the residential development which seems to be a major theme in what I am saying tonight, a key to sustainable living in the Western Sydney, of course, is more local employment opportunities. I have indicated that I believe the M7 will contribute greatly to this. Job growth in the region really has not kept pace with residential growth. In my first speech I said:

quote.para: It is important that we match the training that is available to young people in Greenway and surrounding areas with employment opportunities in local industries and the growth jobs of the future.

speech.para: In an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 6 June 2003, Bob Myer, of architects Cox and Richardson, who worked for 20 years on the implementation of the Sydney region outline plan—and he lists Parramatta and Campbelltown, but, quite clearly, this would go beyond those two suburbs—said:

quote.para: Job growth ... has been disappointing. Instead tertiary jobs have dispersed in an arc from West Ryde through the CBD to the airport to Botany Bay and people have resorted to private transport to reach their workplace.

speech.para: One of the important points on employment is, of course, the availability of local employment. Once again, the major problem in our area is that people have to travel outside the district to earn a living. One pleasing aspect is that, on information provided by the Blacktown Council, I find that, in 1996, 40.3 per cent of all jobs in the city were held by local residents. By 2001 this proportion had increased to 55.4 per cent. This highlights the increased ability of the city to provide jobs for its residents. Like any location, Blacktown city residential growth will create a demand and requirement for jobs, particularly in service industries such as retail, health, community service and business services.

With that in mind, I am very pleased to be able to report that the residential shopping centre at Blacktown is now being redeveloped. I would probably say that this has certainly been long overdue. But it is now being redeveloped under the leadership of Alan Pendleton, the new mayor. Once it is fully developed, this will create additional employment in the area. The commercial development will bring about a total rejuvenation of Blacktown city's heart and it will be one of Western Sydney's most significant commercial retail centres. As I said, that will help to increase local employment and provide jobs for local people.

With this need in Western Sydney for more employment opportunities, it was with somewhat mixed feelings that we received correspondence from ING Real Estate advising that, with the decision having being made to close Australia's Wonderland amusement park, the site would now be purchased to create a business park. The problem here of course is that Wonderland will be a loss to the area. It was a major tourist attraction—and out in Western Sydney we do need tourist developments that will attract people into the area and provide employment and amusement for local residents. It was a great employer of local people. There were some 130 permanent and 270 casual workers employed there. The closing of the amusement park will create more pressure on the labour market, particularly in the area of part-time work and young people wanting to get into the work force.

So it is a double-edged sword: that is happening and there is going to be pressure there, but on the other hand is the fact that the site will be developed by one of Australia's largest organisations in this field, with a prediction that there will be some 9,000 jobs created close to where people live. That is definitely good news. I am advised that, under the proposed plan, the industrial business park will be developed using best practice and environmentally sustainable development practices so that trees will be maintained and the natural environment protected. The potential for employment growth is well supported by the education facilities in the electorate of Greenway, which I have spoken about on many occasions previously.

They are the developments that have taken place over the eight years that I have been the member for the electorate of Greenway. I have seen massive changes. I have seen the state government making a gallant effort to provide the infrastructure that the new residents of Western Sydney need. However, I have seen the federal government cutting back funds, which has reduced medical services in the area. We have seen inadequate funding and the residents in the area that I live in having to pay higher fees for higher education. As I have been speaking about, a growing number of families are financially squeezed. On the one hand we have got the state Labor government providing infrastructure that is needed for the area, and on the other hand we have got the federal government cutting back on the funds that are so vital for the services that we need in Western Sydney. For that reason I am very happy to support the amendment moved by the member for Fraser.

talk.start.para: —In my remarks tonight on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 I want to specifically draw on the second reading amendment standing in the name of the member for Fraser, Bob McMullan. In doing so I want to touch on my shadow ministerial responsibilities for transport and regional services and issues raised in the second reading amendment going to the opposition's condemnation of the government for its budget waste and mismanagement.
