speech.para: I draw the House's attention this evening to the fact that 12 months ago the Secretary of the Department of Transport and Regional Services told his department that they were in a very difficult financial position. I contend that that arose from financial mismanagement and waste by the Department of Transport and Regional Services. The secretary informed the staff of the department that they would run out of money without major changes in the way they operated. The department posted an operating loss of $4.5 million in 2002-03, yet the figure did not tell the whole and honest story. Losses in 2002-03 were in fact more than $4.5 million. With the rollover funds from 2001-02 and forward into 2003-04 taken into account, the operating loss is more like $8.1 million. And this figure does not include the $13 million drawn down from the reserves since 1999.

Since then we have discovered that the response of the department and the government to the financial crisis has been to slash staff numbers and freeze expenditure on IT infrastructure, something fundamental to the operation of the department. Across the department the five administrative groups were forced to cut their operating expenses by 10.7 per cent to enable the department to turn around their financial crisis. Two weeks ago during the Senate estimates process we learnt that this whopping productivity increase has fallen squarely onto the staff of the department.

The department's definition of operating expenses appears to be limited to staff costs. We have learnt that staffing levels within the department have fallen by 13.8 per cent in just nine months. In addition, the tools that enable the department to perform its functions—its information technology systems—have had an expenditure freeze imposed on them. This is in spite of the fact that the secretary of the department clearly indicated on 14 May 2003:

quote.para: ... to make ends meet over recent years we—

speech.para: the department—

quote.para: have under-invested in infrastructure such as IT desktops.

speech.para: So not only have staff numbers been slashed by almost 130 but the remaining staff are required to put up with failing IT infrastructure. I think this is fairly important, because the Department of Transport and Regional Services is a very significant department. The staff within the department have been made the scapegoat for maladministration by the Howard government. It did not have to be and should not have been the case. A department properly resourced by government could have continued to provide sound administrative functions. The treatment of staff in the Department of Transport and Regional Services is yet another example of the wrong priorities of this government, its waste and its mismanagement—something that is seen generally across the Howard government.

For that reason I very much support the amendment moved by the shadow minister for finance, the member for Fraser that condemns the government for its budget waste and mismanagement and wrong priorities. These have clearly resulted in difficulties with respect to our costly Medicare safety net system; inadequate funding and higher fees for students in higher education; a growing number of financially squeezed families trying to balance work and family; and 500,000 Australians waiting for up to five years to get their teeth fixed, something which is a major problem in my electorate of Batman in the northern suburbs of Melbourne.

As a result of penny pinching and the 1980s style corporate management adopted by the government, officers of the Department of Transport and Regional Services are required to perform miracles to achieve government objectives. It is little wonder that the department is falling apart and there are serious problems with respect to the performance of the department, going to such fundamental issues as aviation safety in Australia at the moment. It is little wonder that the department—and, in essence, the Howard government—has not been able to respond to the regional business development analysis report delivered to the government in July of last year.

It is little wonder that the introduction of a new IT program management system for the Regional Partnerships program is beset with problems that are leading to increased frustration for program applicants all around Australia. It is little wonder that the Regional Partnerships program has been unable to generate the activity or applications envisaged when it was started in July 2003. As at the end of December this program has only been able to spend less than one quarter of the funds allocated, even though it brought forward more than $30 million expenditure from the previous financial year.

The litany goes on across a whole range of activities in the Department of Transport and Regional Services. It is little wonder, for example, that the much publicised AusLink white paper has yet to see the light of day. And it is little wonder that it has taken so long to get even close to the ARTC agreement with the New South Wales state government being nailed down by the federal government going to the upgrade of the national track on the east coast from Brisbane through to Melbourne. And, most importantly, the government's 20th-century response to departmental administration appears to be designed to silence criticism of the new National Airspace System.

The Australian Transport Safety Bureau is the organisation that conducts professional investigations into aviation accidents and incidents. It was the ATSB that first recommended a review of the flawed National Airspace System as a result of an investigation of a near miss incident over Launceston. The recent Senate estimates process confirmed the extent of the damage being perpetrated on the ATSB budget and the effect it is having on the preparedness to improve aviation safety for the travelling public. It was confirmed at Senate estimates that the ATSB is investigating only 60 out of 60,000 aviation incidents each year—and this is the organisation that is supposed to assist in maintaining air safety in Australia. This is a very serious issue when you think about the importance of the aviation industry to Australia at large.

In 2000-01, the ATSB was funded to conduct 118 new accident investigations, but this has now dropped to just 60. This is at a time when the government is introducing a whole new approach to aviation in Australia. The flawed National Airspace System is slated for fundamental review—and we are cutting back on investigations of aviation safety and near misses in Australia. This is the same airspace system that the ATSB acknowledges is responsible for 27 National Airspace System related incidents since its implementation in November 2003—a very short period. It is the same airspace system that is based on the American model that is clearly unsuitable for Australian conditions, as the near miss over Launceston proved beyond any doubt.

I note that, in a recent review of midair collisions in the US, it was found that the most common causal factor identified by the US National Transportation Safety Board was failure to—guess what?—see and avoid. It is interesting to note, as the member for Franklin is well aware because of the near miss in Tasmania just before Christmas, that the National Airspace System being pursued by the Minister for Transport and Regional Services is based on see and avoid and that is the system that we are expected to adopt in Australia. It concluded that see and avoid has inherent limitations as a tactical strategy for avoiding midair collisions. It also found that most midair collisions occur near airports, especially non-towered airports, which is pretty important when you think about regional Australia and the importance of aviation. The use of see and avoid, especially around non-towered airports, is one of the most fundamental changes to our new National Airspace System in stage 2B of the implementation of the NAS system.

It is also interesting that during the Senate estimate hearings a fortnight ago the Chief Executive Officer of Airservices Australia dropped his bombshell about the botched implementation of the NAS system—the system that the Minister for Transport and Regional Services continued to tell us in the House only a matter of a week and half ago is safer than the previous operating system. In his statement to the Senate committee on 17 February, the Chief Executive Officer of Airservices Australia said:

quote.para: Airservices recently formed the view that its process for considering the changes on 27 November 2003 may not have properly discharged all its responsibilities under the act. The nature of the gap in our processes relates, firstly, to the extent to which Airservices may have relied on the work of other parties—the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, the Aviation Reform Group, the National Air Space Implementation Group as examples—rather than its own comprehensive research and analysis. And secondly, to the way in which we chose to manage an identified risk related to the implementation of class E airspace.

speech.para: I simply say to the House this evening that that was a bombshell and it fell not only on me as the shadow minister but also on the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and his department. The Chief Executive Officer of Airservices effectively stated that the fundamental process for implementing NAS was flawed and hence there were serious questions about air safety in Australia. He stated that, despite the Minister for Transport and Regional Services responding in the House on the same day to a question from me by stating that the system was, in essence, the safest in the world.

Let us talk about how flawed it is—and that is not my view alone; it is now the view of Airservices and many other professionals in the industry who have long said to the minister, including prior to 27 November, that this system is a risk. I have come to the conclusion that, so flawed is this system as a result of these procedural oversights, Airservices has now undertaken a design safety case for the system's full implementation last year and it will also undertake a more extensive risk analysis of the changes that were implemented last year. The ATSB has identified that the National Airspace System contributed to a serious incident near Launceston airport in December last year. It appropriately recommended that the National Airspace System procedures and communication requirements be reviewed and, where necessary, there be revision and updating of education, training and sharp frequency material. Then Airservices Australia acknowledged that it had not properly discharged its responsibilities under the act—in effect, it had acted illegally—and it will therefore initiate a design safety case of the full program for reform and also undertake a more extensive risk analysis of the changes.

But what have we heard from the person who should be shouldering responsibility for the introduction of the NAS system; what have we heard from the Minister for Transport and Regional Services? I am sorry to report this evening that he has been silent. He has continued to give the House an undertaking that this is the safest system we as a nation could have. The same day that he last answered a question without notice in the House, Airservices Australia—an independent regulatory authority that had belled the cat—owned up to the fact that it had not done the job it was required to do under the act and that the air safety system in Australia, which we depend on, was flawed and had to be completely overhauled. I would have thought that the minister would have made a statement to the travelling public about where this review is up to and why Airservices have had to take it on. I think the minister stands condemned for not accepting those responsibilities and, in essence, not coming clean.

But, as far as I am concerned, it is worse than that. The minister has failed to reassure the Australian public that serious incidents like the one in Launceston will not happen again. I think we are entitled to know that that is the view of the minister: that serious incidents such as the one that occurred at Launceston will not happen again—because do you know what that is about? That is about duty of care, from a government point of view. It is time for the minister to fulfil his responsibility by acknowledging the concerns that have been raised time and time again by highly informed members of the aviation industry and by the opposition in parliament and outside.

This evening I call upon the minister to accept his responsibility and release a full statement of what really happened with the introduction of the National Airspace System. He must explain why he let Dick Smith, an enthusiastic amateur—his good mate and an even better mate of the Prime Minister—and a known advocate of the US air space model, lead the charge in the design of Australia's new airspace regime. The minister must come clean on the exact role of the Airspace Reform Group and whether it will start to have another go at trying to fix its botched NAS system. I contend that we need to get rid of the enthusiastic amateurs and hand the review of the National Airspace System over entirely to the experts—the professionals—and let them do the job, just as they should have been allowed to do it in the first place.

The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services must also fess up, swallow his pride and let the travelling public know his plans for the future management of Australia's airspace system. The minister has deliberately hidden from public scrutiny in relation to the changes that he is responsible for and has left the taxpayers to take the blame. This must end. He can no longer hide from his responsibilities. The Chief Executive Officer of Airservices should not have been the fall guy because the minister will not accept his responsibilities. The ATSB should not be forced to accept massive resource reductions in an attempt by the minister to silence the investigator—and this is a very serious accusation.

Therefore, on behalf of the opposition this evening, I call on the Minister for Transport and Regional Services to come into the House—if anything I demand that he do so—and explain how and why the National Airspace System has been implemented in the botched way that it has been. The parliament deserves that explanation from the minister and, more importantly, so does the travelling public—and I will tell you why. This is not just about budget waste and mismanagement; it is about the fundamental responsibilities of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. The Commonwealth Minister for Transport and Regional Services has a variety of responsibilities, but a number of them go to the safety of the travelling public, be it a responsibility in the investigation of road and rail accidents or, alternatively, the development and implementation of a safe air system in Australia.

This is about duty of care as a minister of the Crown. NAS has put the travelling public at risk. Our air system is not safe, as has been acknowledged by Airservices Australia during Senate estimates just over a week and a half ago. Minister, accept your responsibilities, come clean and help clean up your mess because, if you do not and a serious accident occurs, you will be at fault not only morally but also legally because of a failure to accept your duty of care to protect the travelling public with respect to the implementation and operation of the National Airspace System. I have given the minister sufficient warning and a chance to do what is right by the travelling public. Front up to your responsibilities, Minister: accept your duty of care and do the right thing by the travelling public.
Debate interrupted.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 2003:

quote.para: How many applications for temporary protection visas has his Department received from followers of Falun Gong or Falun Dafa and how many of these applications have been approved to date.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: Under Australian migration legislation persons apply for a protection visa and the decision as to whether a permanent or temporary protection visa is granted is made on the facts of each individual case and depends on whether particular regulatory criteria are met.

From July 1999 until 30 June 2003 the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) received 4,385 applications for a protection visa from PRC nationals. Of these 4126 have been refused by DIMIA as at 30 June 2003 and a number of applications are awaiting a decision.

A substantial number of refused applications have sought independent merits review by the Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT) of the DIMIA decision. Taking account of cases where a DIMIA protection visa refusal decision was set aside by the RRT, as at 30 June 2003 there have been a total of 125 protection visas granted to this group.
DIMIA electronic systems do not record the detailed grounds advanced by individuals seeking protection.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 4 June 2003:

question.para: (1) How many detainees at the Curtin Detention Centre have had their applications to the Refugee Review Tribunal refused in the last 24 months.

(2) For each instance, can he say (a) what was the date of the determination, (b) what was the date the determination was conveyed to the detainee, and (c) whether the detainee was able to access legal advice by (i) phone, (ii) post, and (iii) in person.

(3) Is it the case that when detainees have filled in forms to initiate Federal Court Appeals (without access to legal advice) and posted them in the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs box on site within days of being notified of such decisions, that these documents were not forwarded in time to comply with the mandatory 28 day appeal period so that the detainee was denied legitimate access to the appeal process.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) From 1 June 2001 until the centre's closure on 22 September 2002, a total of 155 immigration detainees had the refusal of their Protection Visa application affirmed by the Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT) whilst the detainees were in Curtin Immigration Reception And Processing Centre (IRPC).

(2) (a)-(b) In only exceptional circumstances, eg detainees in hospital, were detainees advised of the RRT's determination on a day later than the Department. (c) Detainees have the choice of how they access legal advice. The initial contact is generally by phone and follow-up contact by post.

(3) Standard procedure at the Curtin IRPC was that detainees placed their applications for appeal to the Federal Court in the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) box within the mandatory 28 day appeal period. DIMIA checked the box each working day at approximately 8.30 am to ensure that all documents in the box were processed the same day the box was checked. Detainees were continually reminded that they were required to submit their applications with DIMIA prior to the 28 day cut off to ensure that the court would receive the application within the mandatory 28 day appeal period.

There were a number of occasions where the court did not receive applications within the mandatory 28 day appeal period. Generally this was a result of detainees placing their applications in the DIMIA box without allowing sufficient time for the applications to be forwarded to the court. However, on a small number of occasions DIMIA's actions delayed applications, which led to them being received by the court after the 28 day appeal period had elapsed. Where this occurred the Department liaised with the court to seek acceptance of the late applications. On each occasion the court acceded to DIMIA's request.

question.para: (1) Can he confirm that Aladdin Sisalem is being detained at the Manus Island detention centre.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Mr Sisalem is the responsibility of the Papua New Guinea (PNG) authorities and presently is accommodated at a facility on Manus Island.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 18 September 2003:

quote.para: Further to the answers to questions Nos 1620 to 1635 and 1637 (Hansard, 12 August 2003, page 18168) what are the Chief Executive Officers of the Minister's departments and agencies doing to ensure that they do not retain the services of any barrister or solicitor who has previously been made bankrupt.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: Engagement of Counsel on behalf of the Commonwealth is subject to the Legal Services Directions. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs requires law firms engaged to provide legal services to comply with these Directions when engaging Counsel.

The Australian Government Solicitor has developed a database called the `Counsel Engagement System'. When briefing Counsel this Department uses Barristers who are included on this system. In addition, in 2001 the panel firms undertaking litigation on behalf of the Department were instructed to advise us immediately they became aware of any counsel briefed in our litigation becoming bankrupt. To date we have not been so advised.

The law firms with which the Department and portfolio agencies have contracts are all major national law firms of high standing. Such firms would not knowingly engage or retain any barrister known to be acting in disregard of their obligations under taxation law.

In a number of matters relating to native title, counsel has been briefed directly. Section 203FB of the Native Title Act 1993 requires that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission appoint a reviewer of Native Title Review Board decisions. In some instances a barrister has been appointed as a reviewer. These barristers are appointed as they have the necessary skills and knowledge in relation to the Native Title Act.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 16 October 2003:

question.para: (1) For each of the last two financial years, (a) how many people have arrived by ship as stowaways and, of these stowaways, (i) how many applied for protection in Australia, (ii) what was the citizenship of each applicant, and (iii) how many were successful.

(2) For each of the last two financial years, (a) what was the cost of processing the stowaways in detention, including the cost of processing protection visa applications, and (b) was any of the cost of handling such unauthorised sea arrivals recovered from the shipping company involved; if not, why not.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) The number of people who arrived by ship as stowaways in the financial years 2001-2002 and 2002-2003 are 29 and 15 respectively. This number of stowaways who came to notice in 2001-2002 differs from the number previously given in response to Question 2331. The difference reflects an additional stowaway that had previously been incorrectly coded in the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA's) systems. (i) Of the 29 stowaways who arrived in 2001-2002, 10 applied for Protection Visas (PVs) in Australia. Of the 15 stowaways who arrived in 2002-2003, 3 applied for PVs in Australia. (ii) Of the 10 PV applicants in 2001-2002, 5 are from Iraq, 2 are from the Democratic Republic of Congo, 2 are from Burundi and 1 is from Somalia. Of the 3 PV applicants in 2002-2003, 1 is from Burundi, 1 is from Iraq and 1 is from the Democratic Republic of Congo. (iii) Of the 10 PV applications in 2001-2002, 8 have been successful and 2 have been refused. Of the 3 PV applications in 2002-2003, 1 has been refused and 2 have not yet been finally determined.

(2) (a) The Department does not keep separate costs associated with the processing of stowaways in detention, including the cost of processing PV applications. Costs vary considerably depending on the time taken to process an application. The average cost of keeping an unlawful non-citizen in a detention centre in 2001-2002 and in 2002-2003 was $160 and $273 per day respectively. Based on volume, the average cost of processing a PV applicant in onshore detention in 2001-2002 was around $3,500. The average cost of processing a PV applicant in onshore detention in 2002-2003 was around $6,000. (b) While the Department infringes shipping companies for bringing stowaways without reporting them on arrival, it does not recover the cost of detention and processing of stowaways who seek protection and make PV applications on arrival. This policy is applied to ensure that there is an incentive to notify the presence of the stowaway. Shipping companies are, however, liable for the costs of removing stowaways whose PV applications have been unsuccessful.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 5 November 2003:

question.para: (1) How many Special Purpose Visas (SPV) have been granted to date in 2003.
(2) How many people breached the conditions of their SPVs in (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001, (g) 2002, and (h) 2003 to date.
(3) What action is taken to apprehend a crewmember not holding a SPV who jumps ship.
(4) What steps are taken to confine a crewmember not holding a SPV to the ship the crewmember arrived on.
(5) Who is responsible for notifying Australian authorities if a crewmember denied a SPV jumps ship.
(6) What penalties apply for failing to notify Australian Authorities if a crewmember denied a SPV jumps ship.

(7) Does legislation require ships to provide information on their crews prior to their departure from Australia; if not, does the Government seek to obtain this information voluntarily and, if it does, how.
(8) Further to the answer to question No. 274, (Hansard, 14 May 2002, page 2139) what action is the Minister taking to secure the passage of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 2002.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Special Purpose Visas (SPV) come into effect through operation of law by virtue of persons holding a prescribed status. No applications are required and no grants are recorded.

(2) SPV holders are subject to specific legislative visa limitations. In the case of crew of ships, the limitations are that they must depart Australia within 30 days if they sign off a ship and that while here they are not to perform any type of work other than that normally performed in the course of their crewing duties. As such, if an SPV holder overstays this will be included in other statistical data, as a number may apply for other visa classes. However, some statistics we do hold such as SPV holders who do not return to the ship come under deserter statistics that we have provided previously.

(3) Members of the crew of ships hold a SPV on arrival at an Australian port. If the SPV of a crewmember is ceased the crewmember is normally restricted on board their vessel. If they then leave that vessel, the crewmember is considered to have escaped from immigration detention and normal compliance action is taken.

(4) As advised above, crew of ships will normally hold a SPV on arrival at an Australian port. If the SPV has been ceased under subsection 33(9) of the Migration Act, a notice under s.249 of the Migration Act may be issued to the Master of the vessel requiring that they prevent the crewmember from leaving the vessel.
(5) Under s.228 of the Migration Act, the Master of the vessel is responsible for reporting any unauthorised absences of members of the crew whether or not the SPV of the crewmember has been ceased.
(6) Under s.228 of the Migration Act, failure to report the absence of a crewmember may incur a penalty of up to $4,000.

(7) Regulation 3.17 of the Migration Regulations provides that a master of a vessel may be required to provide information on the crew at any time at any port of call in Australia. Australia facilitates the movements of crewmembers into and from Australia through special immigration processing measures. Masters of vessels provide details of any crew joining the vessel while in Australia in order for those crewmembers to access Australia's special measures. The details of all crewmembers who sign on and sign off ships while in Australian ports are copied to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) for monitoring the crewmembers' movements.
(8) The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 2002 is currently before the Senate.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 24 November 2003:

question.para: (1) What action has been taken to reduce or eliminate serial sponsorships of brides or partners.
(2) To what extent can the Minister say they have been effective.
(3) Is there any scrutiny of Visitors Visas to detect the potential for serial sponsorship.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) On coming into office in 1996, this Government, in response to growing concerns about abuse of the partner visa categories as an avenue for people to gain permanent residence in Australia, introduced a package of measures limiting the number of sponsorships that may be lodged by people sponsoring a spouse, prospective spouse or interdependent partner. This package provides that:

the number of approved spouse, prospective spouse or interdependency sponsorships are limited to two per person, a minimum of five years apart (approved sponsorships are those which resulted in the grant of any spouse, prospective spouse or interdependency visa, irrespective of when the visa was applied for);

people who have been sponsored as a spouse, prospective spouse or interdependent partner will be restricted from sponsoring a partner under one of these visa classes for five years, counted from the date their application was lodged;

a woman granted a Woman at Risk (Subclass 204) visa will not be able to sponsor a former spouse from whom she declared she was divorced or permanently separated prior to the grant of the visa, or who was not declared in her visa application, for a period of five years; and
the total number of people that may ever be sponsored by one person in any of these subclasses is two.

quote.para: In support of this package, my Department has also introduced a range of measures to minimise possible misuse of the partner visa process, including:

answer.para: The introduction of a Best Practice Model for processing partner visa applications. The Model was introduced in Australian offices in 1999 and subsequently at overseas offices in Novem-ber 2001. It aims to reduce partner visa processing times and enhance integrity of the program.

The establishment of specialist Bona Fides Units (BFUs) in all Australian offices at the beginning of 2002, to undertake more intensive checking in cases where possible fraud has been identified. Benefits flowing directly from the establishment of the BFUs are already apparent. They include: better reporting on emerging fraud trends; greater cooperation between Australian and overseas offices in the identification and prevention of immigration fraud; and checks of onshore sponsors on behalf of overseas offices, leading to the discovery of non-bona fide applications where the sponsor was found to be living with another partner.
A requirement that at least 85% of Spouse visa applicants, and all applicants for a Partner visa on the basis of a de facto or interdependent relationship, are interviewed.

quote.para: My Department is also working towards progressively improving departmental IT systems to facilitate better monitoring of people who sponsor visa applicants.

answer.para: (2) While the legislation does not allow a person to sponsor more than two partner visa applicants in their lifetime, there remains the possibility that a sponsor may seek to avoid identification as a previous sponsor by provision of misleading information.

quote.para: My Department closely monitors the partner visa caseload and decision-makers have the facility to cross-check departmental records for information concerning any previous sponsorships by a particular sponsor. My Department is also continually refining its processes to ensure that the risk of sponsors breaching the limitation on sponsorship is minimised.

Information available to my Department indicates that the implementation of the sponsorship limitation provisions has been very successful in preventing sponsorship beyond the limit provided in the legislation.

answer.para: (3) Where an applicant for a Visitor visa declares an intention to be visiting an Australian citizen or permanent resident who has previously sponsored at least two persons on Partner visas, this is a matter that would be closely scrutinised in terms of whether a genuine visit was intended. However, not all Visitor visa applicants would necessarily declare the names of all the persons they were intending to visit while in Australia.
At a more generic level, it should be noted that:
The non-return rate for visitors coming to Australia has fallen very significantly over recent years while at the same time the approval rate has increased; and
The rate at which visitors are applying for Partner visas after entering as visitors has also declined.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 25 November 2003:

question.para: (1) Can the Minister say whether requests under Freedom of Information (FOI) legislation are used routinely as an essential part of migration agency practice in affording migration assistance and making migration representations on behalf of visa applicants.

(2) Can the Minister say whether there have been staff cutbacks in the Department's Public Access Unit at any time during the financial years ending (a) 30 June 2002, and (b) 30 June 2003; if so, (i) when did these staff cutbacks occur, and (ii) why.

(3) What were the staffing levels in the Public Access Unit immediately prior to any cutbacks during the financial years ended 30 June 2002 and 2003 and what is the staffing level of the Public Access Unit now.
(4) What was the total number of requests to the Department under the FOI Act for the financial year ended 30 June (a) 2001, (b) 2002, and (c) 2003.
(5) What was the average processing time for FOI requests during the financial year ended 30 June (a) 2001, (b) 2002, and (c) 2003.
(6) What is the current average processing time of FOI requests.
(7) Is the Minister able to say whether a failure to respond to an FOI request within 30 days is a breach of the FOI Act.
(8) What steps is the Minister taking in respect of staffing levels to ensure that FOI requests are processed within the statutory time period of 30 days.

(9) In respect of the recent amendments to the Migration Act proposed in the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Integrity Measures) Bill 2003, will a failure of a visa application by conduct of an agent who is unable to obtain information under the FOI legislation within the prescribed 30 day period, nonetheless, count towards a visa refusal; if not, why not.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Requests for access to documents under the Freedom of Information Act 1982 (the FOI Act) are used to varying degrees by visa applicants and their agents. The Department is unable to comment on whether migration agents consider such requests to be an essential part of migration agency practice.
(2) There were no staff cutbacks in the Department's Public Access Units throughout Australia at any time during the financial years ending (a) 30 June 2002, and (b) 30 June 2003.
(3) The staffing level in the Department's Public Access Units was:
(a) 26.85 full-time equivalent employees as at 30 June 2002;
(b) 35.20 full-time equivalent employees as at 30 June 2003.
The current staffing level is estimated as 41 full-time equivalent employees.
(4) The total number of requests to the Department under the FOI Act for the three financial years to 30 June 2003 was:
(5) Average processing times for FOI requests in the years ended 30 June 2001, 2002 and 2003 are set out below.
(6) Average processing times for FOI requests in the 2004 financial year to date are set out below.
(7) Section 15 of the Freedom of Information Act 1982 sets out statutory time frames for a response by the Minister or an agency to an FOI request which has been made in the proper form.
Subsection 15(5) provides that the Minister or agency must:
within 14 days (if not earlier) take all reasonable steps to notify the requestor that the request has been received; and

as soon as practicable, but in any case by the end of 30 days from when the request is received, take all reasonable steps to notify the applicant of a decision on the request (including a decision under s21 of the Act to defer provision of the document).

Section 15(6) provides that the Minister or agency may extend the period for a decision by a further 30 days when the requested documents are likely to affect Commonwealth-State relations, relate to business affairs or contain personal information of a third party. The applicant must be advised of any such extension as soon as practicable.
Section 31 of the Act provides that certain periods are to be disregarded for the purposes of processing requests.
The fact that an FOI request has not been decided within 30 days of receipt does not necessarily mean that the legislative requirements have not been met.

(8) As part of its ongoing commitment to client service and process improvement, the Department is developing a centralised FOI processing unit. The centralised unit is expected to facilitate the development of staff expertise in FOI processing and provide greater responsiveness in caseload management.

To date, the Department's central office has taken over processing FOI requests that previously would have been done in the ACT, NT, Tasmania and SA offices. Transfer of the FOI function from Qld and WA offices will take place over the next few months. In all cases, the state/territory offices remain responsible for finalising their existing FOI cases.

New South Wales and Victoria offices will continue processing FOI requests due to the high volume of FOI applications received in these states and the costs that would be involved in transferring the files to central office. This will be re-evaluated in the future, following trial of a system for scanning files to CD-ROM.

(9) The purpose of the proposed Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents Integrity Measures) Bill 2004 is to strengthen and improve the regulation of migration agents. These amendments are necessary to ensure that the Migration Agents Registration Authority (MARA) has adequate powers to protect consumers and that migration agents operate ethically, professionally and competently when assisting people to come to or stay in Australia. It will provide the MARA with new powers to sanction migration agents, particularly those agents who lodge a high number of vexatious, unfounded or incomplete applications. The Senate inquiry into the Bill was finalised in December 2003, with the Committee suggesting some further amendments to the proposed Bill. The Bill will now be reintroduced into the Senate in February 2004 for enactment.
The Department understands the honourable member's question as being whether a migration agent could be disciplined under the proposed powers if:
the agent has multiple failures of visa applications due to incomplete applications; and
those applications were incomplete due to the Department not meeting the processing times set out in the FOI Act.

Decisions under the Migration Act 1958 and the Freedom of Information Act 1982 are separate and independent. However, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs' (DIMIA's) policy is that if an FOI applicant has a substantive visa application under consideration, the Department will endeavour to process the FOI before finalising the substantive visa application.

Nevertheless, as detailed in the Department's FOI Handbook, there are circumstances where DIMIA staff may decide to process the substantive visa application before finalising the FOI request, such as when:
access to all the documents requested through FOI has already been given;
the decision maker is required by law to finalise the substantive application within a statutory time limit;

the applicant is in immigration detention, and processing the FOI request alone either protracts the period a person spends in detention or puts greater pressure on the decision maker to release the detainee against their better judgement;
the FOI applicant has agreed that the substantive application should be decided first and a speedy decision is possible.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 1 December 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2186 (Hansard, 13 October 2003, page 21279) in respect of the application of section 5 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 (ADJR) to decisions of an administrative character under the Migration Act 1958 that are not privative clause decisions within the meaning of subsection 474(2) of the Migration Act, is the Minister aware of the judgment of the High Court of Australia in R v Hickman; Ex parte Fox and Clinton (1945) 70 CLR 598.

(2) Notwithstanding the privative clause provision in section 474 of the Migration Act, does section 5 still permit judicial review of decisions in which it can be established that there exists (a) Jurisdictional error, (b) Mala Fides, and (c) Constitutional Grounds.
(3) Are there any other grounds known to the Minister in which the provisions of section 5 of the ADJR Act apply notwithstanding the provision of section 474 Migration Act; if so, what are they.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) I am aware of the decision of the High Court of Australia in R v Hickman; Ex parte Fox and Clinton (1945) 70 CLR 598.

(2) and (3) Paragraph (da) of Schedule 1 to the ADJR Act excludes a privative clause decision within the meaning of subsection 474(2) of the Migration Act from those decisions to which the ADJR Act applies. This has the effect of restricting the jurisdiction of the Federal Court and the Federal Magistrates Court under the ADJR Act in respect of migration decisions to those decisions set out in subsection 474(4) of the Migration Act and any decisions specified in regulation made under subsection 474(5). Whether a particular decision made under the Migration Act would be excluded from judicial review would be a matter for the Court to determine.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 4 December 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2190 (Hansard, 2 December 2003, page 23139), to which previous questions does he specifically refer.

(2) Is he aware of Section 13 of the Preliminary Draft Master Plan (PDMP) for Sydney Airport 03/04 submitted by Sydney Airport Corporation Limited (SACL) in which it states, inter alia, at paragraph 13.1 that (a) “Land use and planning within the airport site is regulated under the Airports Act 1996 and not under the EP+A Act”, (b) “Particular language is used in the Master Plan to comply with Airports Act 1996 requirements only, and is not intended to import or apply any state land use planning or zoning requirements or obligations on either SACL or Sydney Airport” and (c) “where the concept of `development' is used in this Master Plan, it describes a `building activity' as set out in the Airports Act 1996 (rather than the definition of `development' in the EP+A Act)”.

(3) Is the position taken by SACL on the application of NSW planning and environmental law as described in Chapter 13 of the PDMP different from his previous responses to the earlier questions on notice to which he refers; if so, how; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Questions 1724, 2056, 2058 and 2188 part 1.
(2) Yes.

(3) No. The preliminary draft master plan is Sydney Airport Corporation's strategic plan for the development of the airport. This is not a Commonwealth document. Previous responses have referred to the requirements specified in section 71 of the Airports Act.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 4 December 2003:

question.para: (1) Is he aware of an initiative by a group of Vietnam veterans who have established on Kalpower Station a respite area known as Pandanus Park for the use of all returned war veterans.
(2) Is he aware of reports that, in contrast to many government counselling services, this project is producing beneficial outcomes for the physiological well-being and mental health of veterans.

(3) Would the Government consider purchasing Kalpower Station from the Queensland Government, which intends to embark on a course that would preclude such a handover, and arranging for it to be held in trust for Vietnam veterans and returned servicemen from other wars.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I have not received any formal representations on this specific initiative. I am advised that the initiative has been brought to the attention of the office of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon Danna Vale MP.

(2) I am not aware of any reports regarding the mental health outcomes of the Pandanus Project. However the government's many counselling services for veterans are in fact of great benefit. For example the Vietnam Veteran Counselling Service (VVCS) is a specialised, free, confidential service for all veterans and serving Australian Defence Force personnel. The VVCS has recently expanded and its success is evidenced by the year on year increasing numbers of veterans participating in the counselling, and recent surveys indicating high satisfaction levels amongst veterans.

(3) I am advised that the Queensland Government purchased the land in 1995. I further understand that the Queensland Government has offered alternative sites to the veterans, all of which have been turned down. It is inappropriate for the Australian Government to comment on the future use of the land as current control lies with the State of Queensland.

question.para: (1) What has been the total cost of the preparation, publication and distribution of “Resolving Deadlocks: a discussion paper on section 57 of the Australian Constitution”.

(2) What was the total cost, including travel costs and advertising, of the work of the consultative group, chaired by the Hon. Neil Brown QC, which convened public meetings to discuss the “Resolving Deadlocks” discussion paper.
(3) How many people attended each of the public meetings held to discuss the “Resolving Deadlocks” discussion paper.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard

answer.para: (1) I am advised that the total cost was $12,386.56. This figure does not include the salaries of employees who worked on the preparation, publication and distribution of the paper or postage, as these costs are not readily identifiable from other departmental expenses.
